Choose Ten
Identity of creator.
Sun-god as creator.
Grandfather as creator.
Stone-woman as creator.
Brahma as creator.
Multiple creators.
Three creators.
First human pair as creators.
Creative mother source of everything.
Reason for creation.
Gods make earth to have place to rest their feet.
Creator’s descendants.
Creator has two sons.
Invisible creator.
Invisibility of creator learned from the impossibility of staring at the sun, his servant.
Hermaphroditic creator.
Male and female creators.
Animal as creator.
Beast as creator.
Cow as creator.
Bird as creator.
Raven as creator.
Eagle as creator of man.
Black-winged bird as creator.
Insect as creator.
Spider as creator.
Beetle as creator.
Reptile as creator.
Snake as creator.
Worm as creator.
Human creator.
Female creator.
Old woman as creator.
Brothers as creators.
Old man as creator.
Old man with staff as creator.
Artisan as creator.
Potter as creator.
Angel as creator.
Pictorial representations of creator.
Creator with dragon’s head.
Creator with two horns on head.
Dwarfish creator.
Creator clothed in bear-skin (or in leaves).
Creator with hammer and chisel in hands.
Creator with sun and moon in hands.
Nature of creator--miscellaneous.
Sun and moon (man and wife) as creators.
Creator with appearance of Negro.
Creator from above.
Woman who fell from the sky.
Old man from sky as creator.
Creator comes out of chaos.
Creator offspring of dual powers of nature.
Creator from below.
Creator emerges from lake.
Creator comes from certain direction.
Creator comes from east.
Creator born from egg.
Creator’s grandmother.
Creator‘s family.
Creator’s son.
Creator‘s daughter.
Creator’s wife.
Creator‘s wife seduced by his son.
Creator beats his wife while intoxicated from beverage he invents.
Animal as creator’s companion.
Beast as creator‘s companion.
Creator’s dog.
Bird as creator‘s companion.
Insect as creator’s companion.
Bee as God‘s spy.
Other animal companions of creator.
Armadillo as creator‘s companion.
Creator’s companions: unicorn, phoenix, tortoise, and dragon.
Joint creators.
Falcon and crow as joint creators.
Heavenly bodies as creator‘s companions.
Creator’s companions: sun and moon.
Men as God’s advisers.
Angels as God‘s advisers.
Seraphim as creator’s advisers.
God consults two angels on creation.
God consults mercy on his right and justice on his left.
Devil as adviser of God.
Tora as God’s adviser.
Souls of pious as Creator‘s advisers.
Creation of angels and devils.
Creation of devil(s).
Creation of angels.
Angels created to execute God’s will.
Degraded gods become angels.
Angels existed prior to creation.
Angels are transformed souls of the pious.
Angels created from three elements.
Angels created from words uttered by God.
God drops water from his finger and the drops become angels.
God created angels by striking one small stone with another.
Creation of individual angels.
Angel of death created by God.
Angel Michael created from fire.
Angel Gabriel created from snow.
Angel Raphael created from water.
Angel of destruction created from hail and fire.
Time of creation of the angels.
Angels created on first day of creation.
Angels created on second day of creation.
Angels created on third day of creation.
Archangels created on first, angels on third day of creation.
Angels created on fifth day with other winged creatures.
Material of which angels are created (fire, water and snow).
Rebel angels.
Angel of sea rebels at world‘s creation; put to death by God.
Coyote as marplot at creation.
Devil as marplot at creation.
Devil works during God’s sleep at creation.
Devil plans to drown God at time of creation.
Devil and God wrestle at time of creation.
Devil and God create animals.
God and the devil torment each other with their creations.
Lucifer causes fall of man.
Satan seduces Adam to sin because he is jealous of him.
Devil in serpent form tempts first woman (Satan and Eve).
Rebel god is author of all poisonous things.
Poisonous water created by the devil.
Satan attempts to create another world.
God makes

Supreme god.

Reign of peace and justice (under certain king).

Formerly men plowed and cattle were their masters.

Impounded water.
God promises never again to destroy world by water.
Why the sea is salt.
Why the sea is salt: because of wrecked salt ship.
Why the sea is salt: magic salt mill.
Why the sea is salt: heavy rain showers on ashes of wood burnt by primeval fire.
Origin of sea-waves.
Sea-waves are (manes of) sea-god’s horses.

All qualities of animals appear with their creation.
Animal characteristics: accidental action of ancient animal.
Lynx views country from mountainside: cause of his squint.
Rabbit laughs: cause of hare-lip.
Wolf falls out of nest: cause of straight back.
Why some whales die on land: first whale did so.
Shrew blows nose into snout.
Spider carries large stone on head and drops it: hence spiders under stones.
Birds cling to sky in flood: cause of tail colors.
Lizard dips head in palm-oil: cause of red head.
Lizard swallows fish bone: hence head bobs up and down.
Tortoise left out in rain: hard shell develops.
How rattlesnake became harmful: earthworm feeds him chili pepper.
Buffalo helps tiger quench fire: white mark left on buffalo‘s neck where tiger held on while being ducked in water.
Stag defeated by snail vomits his gall-bladder.
Rat defecates on octopus’s head: origin of tubercles on head.
Goddess scatters pubic hairs on fish: why he has so many bones.
Animal characteristics from great fear.
Frightened rabbit puts head in charred tree: hence black ears.
Frightened animals scatter: cause of present habitat of each.
Animal characteristics from squeezing or stretching ancient animal.
Ancient animal squeezed: hence small size.
Animal pressed: hence facial or bodily marks.
Wildcat’s (Lynx‘s) face mashed in.
Tortoise pressed into earth: hence humpy back.
Baboon pressed on hot, flat rock: hence bald place on his back.
Why lobster is shallow: insulted cattle step on it.
Animals‘ size increased by stretching.
Animal characteristics changed by stretching.
Coyote’s muzzle pulled out long.
Fox‘s tail pulled out long.
Mouse’s nose pulled out long.
Animal characteristics from being struck.
Mole struck on head in attempt to steal fire: hence his flat head.
Fish struck by coconut: hence flat tail.
Animal characteristics from dropping ancient animal from air.
Swallow thrown on his tail: cause of split tail.
Ant thrown from heaven: hence narrow waist.
Unicorn thrown from ark and drowned: hence no longer exists.
Crab thrown to ground: breaks into small pieces.
Tortoise hurled on rock: half falls on land, half in water.
Tortoise dropped by eagle: hence cracks in his shell.
Bat falls from high perch due to extreme heat of sun’s rays, breaks bones, etc.
Animal characteristics from throwing members at ancient animal.
Stick (leaf) thrown at animal‘s rump: hence tails.
Hare runs away at creation; almost loses tail.
Bowl placed on turtle’s back: hence his shell.
Red fruit thrown at rail‘s (bird’s) head: hence red lump on head.
Fox struck with churn-dash: hence white tail.
God throws diver‘s feet after him; hence his feet reach backward.
Animal characteristics: members bitten or cut off.
Bear fishes through ice with tail: hence lacks tail.
Devil pulls off goats’ tails: hence lack tails.
Moon splits hare‘s lip with hatchet: hence hare-lip.
Bush-rat bites off tortoise’s tail: hence tortoise‘s short tail.
Hawk’s tail cut in two by sword as he is being transformed.
God as falcon has tail cut off: hence falcon‘s short tail.
Formerly animals have ears like elephant’s: hare bites them off.
Appearance of animal from marking or painting.
Birds painted their present colors.
Chipmunk‘s back scratched: hence his stripes.
Marks on certain fish from fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from St. Peter’s fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from devil‘s fingerprints.
Animal characteristics from burning or singeing.
Raven caught in smoke-hole: hence is black.
Animal scorches self while putting out fire in land of fire, woe and darkness.
Jackal carries sun in bag on back; burns his back black.
Animal who steals fire scorched: cause of his color.
Coyote burnt when hay is set afire: hence yellow patch behind his ears.
Robin steals fire, has breast scorched.
Raven singes feet on hot stones: why its wings clap when it flies.
Rabbit burns self under chin when he steals an ember.
Eel burned by torch: hence red eyes.
Other accidents to ancient animal.
Animal has color spilled on him: cause of his color.
Cow swallows book; cause of maniplies in stomach.
Only one serpent had sting: fed poison to the rest.
Hedgehog’s skin reward for good deed.
Animal characteristics reward for pious act.
Animals blessed for honoring infant Jesus.
Animals blessed for good services at crucifixion.
Flies on Christ‘s body rewarded.
Blood from cross on robin redbreast: He helps Jesus; rewarded with red breast.
Blood of scourged Christ on certain spiders.
Swallows lift Christ‘s crown of thorns from his brow: why their nests are not destroyed.
Swallows put on mourning at crucifixion: have never taken it off.
Crossbill, attempting to draw thorn from the crown of thorns, twists bill in the attempt.
Markings on animals as recollections of Christ’s life and sufferings.
Ant collects incense and myrrh for Christ: grows thin in middle.
Animal blessed for helping holy fugitive.
Ox helps patriarch who in joy kisses him on the lips: hence no hair on ox’s lips.
Animal blessed for obedience to deity.
Bird coloring as reward for obedience to deity.
Dove returns to ark in obedience to Noah: receives sheen of raven.
Squirrel‘s markings and immunity from falling as reward by deity.
Why sheep walk with bowed heads: they have remained so after having bowed to God.
Sheep helpful to the Lord: get wool.
Deity rewards animal for bringing him water: cause of present characteristics.
Animal characteristics reward for hospitality.
Thrush‘s hospitality to peacock rewarded by being given motley coat of feathers.
Animal characteristics reward for helpfulness.
Cat helps man build house: may occupy chimney corner.
Bird carries deity (his daughter) home from land of skulls: given brilliant plumage.
Mouse gathers rice for man: may eat a little of his rice daily.
Pike helps Christ cross stream: made king of fishes.
Dog guards master’s life and wealth: may eat before other animals.
Tortoise given hard shell when it ferries rice-goddess across stream.
Ravens show Adam how to bury dead: are born with white feathers.
Chameleon saves hero’s life: may change color.
Animal characteristics as reward--miscellaneous.
Dog rescues cow‘s teats from fire: origin of his black muzzle.
Dog lets devil into church to steal: rewarded with dog-skin.
Owl will not betray curate: therefore may live in steeple.
Fly steals fire from spider: may eat everywhere.
Cuckoo delivers other birds from their cruel king: they agree to hatch out cuckoo’s young.
Bird has red spot on its tail as reward for having moved woman‘s organ to its present position.
Animal characteristics: punishment for impiety.
Animal characteristics: punishment for discourteous answer to God (saint).
Discourteous answer: why cow (horse) is always eating.
Discourteous answer: flounder’s crooked mouth.
Discourteous answer: why crab has eyes behind.
Discourteous answer: tortoise‘s shell.
Animal characteristics: punishment for hostility at crucifixion.
Crane will not weep at crucifixion: must suffer thirst in August and break bills.
Swallows torment Christ on cross: lose voice.
Animal characteristics: punishment for working on holy day.
Cuckoo builds nest on Annunciation Day: has no nest.
Bees work on Sabbath: may not get honey from red clover.
Frog fails to honor infant Jesus: loses tail.
Spider vies with Virgin Mary in spinning: cursed.
Spider steals thread from Christ: has thread in back of body.
Animal harmful to holy person cursed.
Animal cursed for betraying holy fugitive.
Beetle cursed for betraying Holy Family on way to Egypt; beetle now has its eyes always on the ground.
Animal cursed for refusing to carry holy fugitive across stream.
Tortoise cursed for going under water while ferrying rice-goddess: people will be able to kill it with iron-made spears.
Toad refuses to weep over its dead children: dries up when dead.
Fish in deluge deride God: are flattened with blow.
Crab beats deity‘s forbidden drum: eyes lift out of body.
Beetle demands return of gold from God: must hum.
Buffaloes fail to come at god’s leavetaking: now are killed by tigers.
Loris refuse to look at sun who comes out when they are dancing: hence never looks at sun.
Animal characteristics: punishment for immoderate request.
Camel asks for horns: punishment, short ears.
Bees pray for sting: punishment, first sting suicidal.
Beetle makes immoderate request; ant moderate: inverse awards.
Griffin disdains to go on ark; drowned: hence extinct.
Animals ask for goddess‘s perfume: punishment, bad odor.
Birds who aspire to blackbird’s coat punished.
Peacock given ugly feet so as to prevent too great arrogance.
Dog‘s embassy to Zeus chased forth; dogs seek ambassador: why dogs sniff each other under leg.
Ants ask God to give them wings: wind blows them away.
Raven attempts to imitate dove: punished with awkward gait.
Donkeys ask immediate reward from God: eat their own excrements.
Animal characteristics: punishment for laziness.
Animals refuse to help dig well (make road) and are punished.
Animals refuse to help dig well: may not drink from river or spring.
Snake refuses to help make road: dies on road.
Shrew refuses to help make road: dies on road.
Sloth refuses to help make road: may not look upon sun.
Dog will not help build house: must remain out of doors.
Too cold for hare (dog) to build house in winter, not necessary in summer: must go without house.
Owl as watchman goes to sleep: does not see by day.
Grasshopper builds no house for winter; ant strikes him blind: therefore born blind.
Bird neglects to build nest: goes without.
Animal characteristics: punishment for disobedience.
Raven does not return to Noah: must suffer thirst and break bill.
Raven does not return to ark in obedience to Noah: black color is resulting punishment.
Animals eat deity’s forbidden fruit: punished.
Lemur looks where forbidden: has big eyes.
Hare weeps for mother when forbidden: moon hits him and cleaves lip.
Animal characteristics caused by animal‘s lateness at distribution of qualities.
Animal characteristics: punishment for planning man’s downfall.
What creature has sweetest blood: gnat‘s tongue torn out.
Animal characteristics: punishment for carrying devil into paradise.
Snake carries devil into paradise: loses feet.
Peacock has snake carry devil into paradise: cursed with ugly voice and feet.
Animal punished for not warning of devil’s temptation in Eden.
Magpie tells man he is to die next day: no tongue and long tail.
Animal punished for not heralding dawn.
Nit tries to bore through man‘s head: must remain at edge of hair.
Jay carries sulphur to devil in hell: must be quiet at noon.
Cat commanded to pray so as not to slay man: why cat purrs.
Animal characteristics punishment for meddling.
Animal reveals mistress’s adultery: punished by master.
Animal characteristics: punishment for greed.
Rabbit (frog) eats seed-grain from fields: nose closed during sowing season.
Ring-dove eats man‘s grain: man may kill him.
Fish eat other fish: guilty must swim deep.
Diver eats nests of small birds: must not nest away from water.
Animal characteristics from miscellaneous punishments.
Hare punished for perjury: eyes deep in head.
Fly punished for failing to answer question: is speechless, buzzes and associates with foul things.
Ass betrays deity’s secret: hence his ugly bray.
Owl reveals deity’s secret: power of speech removed.
Woodpecker punished for stinginess.
Animals punished for assaulting women.
Ass has cross on shoulders from being struck by Balaam.
Crocodile is punished for trying to attack man he is carrying: has only half tongue.
Animal punished for hardheadedness (frog toothless, mole sightless).
Why mouse is crushed whenever she crosses a road: elephant‘s curse.
Why elephant hurts himself when running through the grass: mouse’s curse.
Animal characteristics: borrowing and not returning.
Stag’s horns borrowed from dog.
Owl‘s wings borrowed from rat (or other animal).
Partridge’s voice borrowed from tortoise.
Cuckoo borrows food from other birds.
Nightingale borrows blindworm‘s eye.
Jay borrows cuckoo’s skin.
Squirrel borrows coney‘s tail.
Boy borrows python‘s hands and feet: hence python lacks them.
Hornbill borrows tomtit’s bill.
Beaver borrows muskrat‘s tail and never gives it back.
Monkey borrows tail from deer and refuses to return it.
Animal characteristics: obtaining for feast and not returning.
Animal characteristics: lending and refusing to receive back.
Spider hands box to ant and refuses to take it back: hence ants carry huge loads.
Animal characteristics: stolen from another animal.
Thrush steals woodcock‘s song.
Animal characteristics: exchange of qualities.
Buffalo and cow exchange hides: hence bad fitting hides.
Snake and turtle exchange head for fangs.
Rhinoceros exchanges his red hide for hippopotamus’s black.
Dove and magpie exchange eggs--dove‘s seven for magpie’s two: why dove has two eggs.
Toad trades his tail for mole‘s eyes.
Beaver and muskrat exchange tails.
Cock and ptarmigan in contest: winner to live in town.
Man and tiger in contest: winner to live in town.
Lizard wins contest with toad: why snakes and lizards change their skins.
Animal characteristics from contest in carrying.
Ant carries load as heavy as himself.
Animal characteristics determined by race.
Race of animals to see where each shall live.
Race of ox and horse: ox must labor.
Race of culture hero with ostrich: ostrich loses beautiful feathers.
Flounder complains in race: crooked mouth.
Animal characteristics from jumping contest.
Dog burned in jumping contest over fire: enmity between dog and hare.
Bird characteristics from flying contests.
Animal characteristics result of lawsuit.
Wool on his forehead awarded sheep in lawsuit.
Lizard loses lawsuit: must bob his head.
Animal characteristics from contest in watching.
Hare and man contest in watching for leaf to fall off tree.
Animal characteristics from duel.
Why tiger does not attack wild boar until latter is old: result of duel.
Animal characteristics: as a result of quarrel.
Animal characteristics from transformation of animal.
Shepherd transformed to bird still calls sheep: explanation of bird cries.
Spider transformed for greediness: now occupies dark corners.
Catfish transformed from woman still carries women‘s tatoo marks.
Catfish transformed from children still carry marks of children’s knife holder.
Woodpecker transformed from stingy woman: therefore stingy.
Weeping man turned into owl; still bewails sorrows.
Snipe messenger for warriors because he was a messenger when a man.
Animal characteristics from transformation of implement (or other object).
Horse originally had eyes on feet: put out and became eyelike marks.
Pegs driven into backs of baboons become tails.
Serpent steals from God‘s coat a stick for his back.
Animal characteristics learned from another animal.
Thrush teaches dove to build nest.
Sparrow taught to sing by lark but not sufficiently: where sparrow got voice.
Animal characteristics: imitation of other animal or object.
Animal cries: imitation of sounds.
Nightingale hears boy call oxen: learns her song.
Cricket hears water hiss on hot iron: learns his song.
Garden warbler hears smith beat iron: learns his song.
Lizard’s tail imitated from snake‘s.
Animal habit a reminiscence of former experience.
Animal cries a lament for person lost when animal was transformed.
Animal cries a lament over animal’s transformation.
Animal cries reminiscent of former life as man.
Animal cries recall ancient adventure.
Green pigeon cheated out of its chick: is always mourning.
Animal‘s seeking attitude from ancient loss.
Hog loses pancake in mud: still seeks it.
Hawk (vulture) loses grandmother: still hovers and seeks her.
Bat, diver, and thornbush shipwrecked.
Dolphins seek King Solomon’s ring.
Dog loses his patent right; seeks it: why dogs look at one another under the tail.
Son accidentally kills father, who returns to life as cuckoo and tells people when to sow grain.
Enmity between animals from original quarrel.
Cat loses dog’s certificate: enmity between cats and dogs.
Cat garbles message from man to tiger: enmity between man and tiger.
Quarrel of dog and cat about which was higher caste.
Squirrel steals dog’s needle: enmity between them.
Why cat and dog fight: dog ate up cat‘s part in master’s reward.
Present habitat of animals result of ancient quarrel.
Two animals learn songs together--one successfully, the other unsuccessfully.
Origin of animal characteristics: animal persuaded into self-injury.
Animal persuaded to amputate limb: therefore lacks it.
Bustard persuaded to kill all but two children: has but two eggs.
Worm, thinking that world is coming to end, blinds self so as not to see calamity.
Elephant tricked into eating own testicles.
Coyote persuaded to break leg: therefore has thin right leg.
Jackal persuades hyena to jump and break foot.
Animal characteristics established by deity.
God makes serpent ugly.
Creation interrupted since God must go to a fire.
Animal characteristics because creator had not enough time to finish what he began.
Creation of hog incomplete since God has to go to a fire: cause of hog‘s round snout.
Animal characteristics result of contest between God and devil.
Devil’s animals devour God‘s.
Devil gives horse four eyes; God reduces them to two.
Devil’s cows one-horned; God makes them two-horned.
God changes color (tails) of devil‘s cows.
Jesus causes animal characteristics.
Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence short snouts.
Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence “toes” on back of foreleg.
Animal characteristics obtained during deluge.
Animal characteristics: change for convenience.
Wild animals lose their ferocity through fear of Behemoth.

Devil throws sand at aspen: hence rough bark.

Christ puts knots in wood.
Plant characteristics from accident to original plant.
Bean laughs till it splits: cause of black stripe.

Sky rests on top of trees: hence flat leaves.
Bush loses clothes in shipwreck: hence catches passerby looking for clothes.

Plant characteristics from exchange of qualities.
Plant characteristic because plant belongs to the devil.

Fanciful qualities of snakes.
Snake takes tail in mouth and rolls like wheel.
Snake lays aside his crown to bathe.
Snake sucks poisonous dew from grass.
Snake milks cows at night.
Snake attaches itself to a woman’s breast and draws away her milk while she sleeps.
Snake crawls from sleeper‘s mouth.
Snake eats milk and bread with child.
Snake drinks milk.
Jointed snake can join its segments when it is broken into pieces.
Snakes may be killed, but do not die.
Snake grows back together after it has been severed.
Snake sucks poison from bite it has itself made.
Poisonous snakes in certain region have no venom.
Snake cracks self like coach whip and chases man.
Snake‘s venom kills tree.
Venomous snakes play with precious stones.
Copperhead guides rattlesnake to its prey.
Snake has hypnotic stare: person cannot move.
Serpent reduces man to a heap of ashes by its fiery gaze.
Snake stands up, whistles.
Snake has stinger.
Bullets have no effect on giant serpent; only stroke of lightning effective.
Snake avoids object.
Snake avoids white ash.
Snakes will not cross rope made of hair.
Snakes will not cross a ring made of Irish earth.
Detached snake fang kills person or animal.
Snake kills man who has killed snake’s mate.
Snake revives snakes which have been injured (the doctor snake).
King snake: kills and eats any snake that does not accept his authority.
Snake with legs.
Dragon fly serves as snake‘s servant, feeds snake; it is called snake-feeder.
Dragon fly acts as doctor to injured snakes.
Female snake seven years pregnant.
Palm tree grows on serpent’s body.
Fanciful dangers from animals.
Cat mutilates corpses.
Cat must be kept from dying person because it will catch the person‘s soul issuing (from mouth) in form of mouse.
Cat sucks sleeping child’s breath.
Toads suck blood.
Bite of white she-mule causes certain death.
Animals attracted by music.

Animal lives in person‘s stomach.

How animal gets into person‘s stomach (or body) (various methods).
Person drinking from brook swallows animal eggs (frog or newt).
Person swallows pebble on beach; snake grows in stomach.
Person swallows snake semen or egg while eating watercress.
Girl swallows frog spawn; an octopus grows inside her with tentacles reaching to every part of her body.
Swallowed blackbeetle reproduces inside person’s body.
Girl eats plums and maggots in them; maggots multiply inside her body.
Scaly lizard jumps into person‘s mouth.

Means of ridding person of animal in stomach.
No remedy possible.
Patient fed salt: animal comes out for water.
Snake (frog) in human body enticed out by milk (water).
Husband ties a cock near wife’s feet: snake-parasite in her stomach comes out to catch the cock and is killed by husband.

A Classification of Narrative Elements in
Folktales, Ballads, Myths, Fables, Mediaeval Romances,
Exempla, Fabliaux, Jest-Books, and
Local Legends
Indiana University
ISBN 0-253-33882-4
5 89
complete set ISBN 0-253-33887-5

Sound of ethereal music.
Ground trembles or rumbles when ghost rises from grave.

Dead cannot rest because of sin.
Hand of sinner sticks out of grave.
Unquiet dead sinner taken to priest for absolution.
Return from dead to do penance.
Unconfessed person cannot rest in grave.
Horse unable to draw evil dead man.
Dead body cannot be moved from where it lies.
Sinner wanders between earth and heaven.
Other dead drive sinner from graveyard.
Rich man dragged from grave by demons in hallowed ground and flung into grave in unblessed ground.
Earth rejects buried body.
Demons cast evil man from grave leaving only his shroud.
Saint‘s body miraculously moves so that it is laid properly north and south, not northeast and southwest.
Murderer cannot rest in grave.
Suicide cannot rest in grave.
Suicides must walk the earth until time for their natural death.
Adulterous person cannot rest in grave.
Priest’s concubine cannot rest in grave.
The devil‘s concubine haunts after her death.
Perjurer cannot rest in grave.
Usurer cannot rest in grave.
Swindler cannot rest in grave.
Person who never said “good morning” cannot rest in grave.
Monk who dies without his cowl cannot rest in grave.
Pilate appears periodically at Mt. Pilatus and washes his hands.
Magician who has sold his soul to the devil hires his servant to bury him properly: the coffin bursts.
Persons who die violent or accidental deaths cannot rest in grave.
Person under religious ban cannot rest in grave.
Excommunicated person cannot rest in grave.
Unbaptized person cannot rest in grave.
Unchristened person cannot rest in grave nor enter heaven.
Mother of unbaptized child cannot rest in grave.
Dead without proper funeral rites cannot rest.
Dead man comes back because he was buried without a cap.
Naked ghost asks for shirt and promises luck on market for man.
Ghost asks to wash his shirt.
Dead man asks for shoes (was buried without them).
Child cursed by father cannot rest in grave.
Ghost of church desecrator cannot rest.
Murdered person cannot rest in grave.
Drowned person cannot rest in peace.
Person otherwise killed by accident cannot rest in grave.
Dead cannot rest until certain work is finished.
Ghost returns to hunt lost article.
Ghost unlaid until iron he hid in life is found.
Return from dead to uncover secretly buried treasure.

Ghost of priest cannot rest because he failed to say certain masses for the dead.
Dead cannot rest until money debts are paid.
Man who removes landmarks cannot rest in grave.
Dead person speaks from grave.
Other restless dead.
Soul wanders and demands that a temple be built for him.
Dead find no rest since someone daily knocks at grave.
Dead find no rest since grass is pulled on grave.
Dead move when cemetery is moved.
Dead arise when one plays organ for first time in church.
Lovers buried apart found in one grave each morning.
Person with missing bodily member cannot rest in grave.

Precautions at funeral against revenant.
Test for presence of demons in corpses.

Ghost deceived.

Why living cannot go to land of the dead.
In land of dead the dead walk on grass without bending it and on mud without sinking.

Course of wild hunt.

Wild huntsman blows horn.
Wild huntsman has his horse beaten.
Wild huntsman makes people carry him on their backs.

Addressing the dead.
The dead cannot speak until spoken to.

A Classification of Narrative Elements in
Folktales, Ballads, Myths, Fables, Mediaeval Romances,
Exempla, Fabliaux, Jest-Books, and
Local Legends
Indiana University
ISBN 0-253-33883-2
5 89
complete set ISBN 0-253-33887-5

Fairies protect selves by means of smoke.
Fairies hate clerics.
Playful or troublesome fairies.
Fairies sport with mortal.

Good spirits.

Acquisition of familiar spirit.

Army of spirits and ghosts.
Means of summoning spirits.

Conjuring spirits.
Means of combating spirits.

Spirit (demon) baffled by scolding and getting last word.

Dogs protect house from spirits.
Grain scattered as a means of dispersing spirits.
Spirit leaves when report is made of the death of one of his kind.
“Tell to mill-mouse that the field-mouse is dead.”
Spirits leave when report is made of fire at their home.
Spirit overcome by driving stake through body it inhabits.
Demons flee stone (when saint steps upon it).
House spirit leaves when gift of clothing is left for it.
Demons flee from fire.
Man captures spirit by hiding his stick and leg-wrappers of copper.
Evil spirit laid after it is tormented by exorciser.
Spirits propitiated.
Doors left open to let night creatures pass to and fro.
Food left out for spirits at night.
Spirits allow people with faces to ground to pass.

Form and appearance of water-spirits.
Water-spirit as man.
Water-spirit appears as handsome man.
Water-spirit appears as black man.
Water-spirit as small gray man.

Water-spirits have one eye.
Water-spirit as woman (water-nymph, water-nix).
Water-maidens are of unusual beauty.
Water-maidens mute.
Water-spirits in animal form.
Water-spirit as toad.
Water-spirit as fish.

Water-spirit as horse.
Water-spirit as bull.
Water-spirit as stork.
Water-spirit as cat.
Water-spirit as goat.
Water-spirit as mouse.
Water-spirit as snake.
Water-spirit as frog.

Water-spirits in abnormal form.
Body of water-spirit is half human and half fish or snake.
Water-spirits have body covered with fish scales.
Water-spirits as dwarfs.
Water-spirits have hunchback.
Water-spirits with human body and webbed feet and hands.
Water-spirits with horse feet.
Water-spirits with green hair and beard.
Water-spirits with green teeth.
Water-giants.
Water-spirit with extraordinarily long hair.
Water-spirits invisible.
Invisible water-spirit claps hands and speaks.
Mysterious voice--water-spirit--is calling from sea.
The seas become heavy without natural cause.
Dress of water-spirits.
Water-spirits are dressed like people of surroundings.
Water-spirits are clad in clothes of gold and silver.
Water-spirits wear precious adornment.
Water-spirits wear wreath of flowers and reed on hair and dress.
Water-maidens have long veil.
Color of water-spirit‘s clothes.
Water-spirits are clad in red.
Water-spirits are clad in gray.
Water-spirits are dressed in green.
Water-spirits are dressed in white.
Water-spirits are dressed in blue.
Water-spirits are nude.
Water-spirits appearing like human beings are recognized by traces of water.
Corner of water-spirits‘ dress is always wet.
Coat pockets of water-spirits are dripping with water.
Water-spirits leave trace of water when standing or walking.
Home of water-spirits.
Water-spirits live in castles of crystal under water.
Water-spirits’ under-water castle is luxuriously furnished.
Water-spirits live in village under water.
Water-spirits have garden.
When water-spirits are outside their homes the seas are heavy.
Water-spirits have hearth made of three human skulls.
Social life among water-spirits.
Water-spirits have family life under water.
Water-spirits have likings and occupations like human beings.
Water-spirits dance.
Water-maidens dance at village fair.
Water-women come to market and store.
Water-women wash and hang up laundry on beach.
Water-spirits bake.
Water-spirits mend clothes.
Water-maidens spin.
Water-man cuts osier to make wicker basket.
Water-spirits have kingdom under water: queen, king, attendants, vassals.
Water-spirits have laws.
Water-spirits must be in water before midnight; delay is punished with death indicated by blood in water.
Water-spirits must be in water before dawn; delay is punished with death.
Water-spirits visited by mortal.
Characteristics of water-spirits.
Water-spirits possess magic power.
Protean transformation of water-spirit.
Water-spirits have supernatural lapse of time: days seem like years.
Water-spirits are cannibals: devour mortal victim, suck blood.
Water-spirits are grateful.
Water-spirits are jealous.
Water-man is rendered powerless if kept away from water.
Water-women are powerless when their garments are taken.
Seeing and observing of water-spirits has fatal consequences.
Water-spirits have treasures under water.
Water-spirit controls water-supply.
Water-spirits are prophetic.
Deeds and actions of water-spirits.
Kind water-spirits.
Water-spirits protect and warn sailor against storm and in tempest.
Water-spirits save shipwrecked people.
Water-spirits help poor.
Water-spirits help lovers.
Water-spirits work as servants for mortal for small compensation.
Water-spirits work as servants for mortal but disappear when compensation is offered or origin suspected.
Water-spirits work at night in home of mortals.
Water-spirits give gifts to mortals.
Water-spirits give money, gold, or precious stones.
Seemingly worthless gifts of water-spirits turn to gold.
Water-spirits give magic gifts.
Water-spirit returns to the woodchopper a silver axe in place of the one he has lost.
Water-spirit gives mortal fish.
Water-spirits give advice.
Water-spirits adopt human foundling.
Water-spirits save man from drowning.
Malevolent water-spirits.
Water-spirits lure mortal into water.
Water-maiden enamors man and draws him under water.
Water-spirits lure children into water, offering objects.
Hero drowned by water-spirits, who draw him down as he crosses ice.
Water-goddess allows body of drowning person to come up three times.
Water-spirit drags children into river.
Water-spirit claims a life every seven years.
Water-spirits kidnap mortals and keep them under water.
Water-spirit returns kidnapped man in return for release of his long hair.
Mistreated boy sings unto water spirits to take him: waters rise up in tank to engulf him.
Water-spirit keeps souls of drowned persons in dishes in his home.
Water-spirits steal children and leave changeling.
Water-spirits interfere with building bridges, dams.
Water-spirits take revenge on mortals.
Water-spirits take revenge if yearly tribute is not given.
Water-spirits take revenge for trespassing on ground they claim as theirs.
Water-spirits take revenge for being harmed.
Water-spirits avenge selves on mortal who fails to keep promise.
Water-maidens avenge selves for scorned love.
Water-spirits take revenge on mortals for pollution of water.

Water-spirit crushes boat.
Water-spirit shakes ship.
Water-spirit wrecks ship.
Water-spirit holds ship back.

Water-spirits lead travelers astray.
Water-man sits on back of persons as heavy burden.
Water-spirits cause blindness.
Water-spirit causes illness and death.
Other actions of water-spirits.

Water-spirits call human godmother.

Nix flees from benediction in church.

Dwarf.
Luchrupбin (leprechauns) (as fairies).

Dwarfs are ugly.

Home of dwarfs.
Dwarfs live under the ground.

Dwarfs resentful that mortals shoot at birds above Hibichenstein, because this crumbles away the cliff.

Dwarfs request that cow stable be moved because it is above their home and the seepage strikes their dining table.

Dwarfs are ruled by a king.

Dwarfs suffer abuses by mortals.
Dwarfs thwart efforts of mortals to get additional favors.

Dwarfs exact promise from mortals.
Dwarfs tease mortals.

Names for dwarfs.
Common names for dwarfs.
Proper names for dwarfs.
Dwarfs emigrate.
Why dwarfs emigrate.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals put caraway seeds into bread.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals are false.
The three sevens in 1777 drive dwarfs out of the land.
Dwarfs emigrate because of industrial development.
Dwarfs promise to emigrate if captured dwarfs are released.
Dwarfs emigrate because Christianity offends them.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals tease them.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals object to their stealing.
Dwarfs emigrate because they dislike peasants‘ dancing and loud music.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals curse.
Dwarfs emigrate because mortals desecrate holy day.
Dwarfs emigrate because of mortals’ ingratitude.
Frederick the Great drove dwarfs across Black Sea.
Dwarfs forced to flee by deity.
Dwarfs emigrate when their king dies.
The destination of emigrating dwarfs.
Dwarfs emigrate to unknown place.
Dwarfs emigrate to the Orient.
Dwarfs emigrate New Year‘s Eve of 1800 to return New Year’s Eve of 1900.
As dwarfs emigrate each deposits coin into kettle for mortals.
Emigrating dwarfs are ferried across water.
Dwarfs emigrate unseen but heard.
Dwarfs and other supernatural beings.
Giants and heroes created for the protection and aid of dwarfs.
Giants and dwarfs in contest.
Dwarfs kill giantess by dropping millstone on her head.
Dwarfs in love with other supernatural beings.
Dwarfs make weapons and other precious objects for the gods.
Trolls.
Home of trolls.
Trolls live in howe (barrow, grave).
Trolls live in cliffs.
Appearance of trolls.
Trolls the size of ten or twelve year old child.
Trolls are usually ugly, hideous, big and strong.
Trolls are black (dark).
Trolls dressed in skins.
Troll in human form.
Troll in human size.
Trolls frightful.
Troll with snout for nose.
Troll in animal form (cat, dog, pig, hen).
Troll as whirlwind.
Great age of trolls.
Characteristic activities of trolls.
Trolls skillful as smiths.
Trolls dance.
Trolls ride.
Troll rides on dog.
Troll rides in whirlwind.
Trolls ride on men and cattle.
Trolls spin and weave fine cloth.
Trolls bake.
Trolls go about at night.
Possessions of trolls.
Trolls‘ riches.
Trolls’ riches inside mountain.
Trolls‘ food.
Trolls’ food gives man supernatural strength.
Trolls eat from golden dishes, but food is frogs and snakes.
Trolls live on food humans have failed to bless.
Visibility of trolls.
Trolls invisible but heard.
Invisible troll attends wedding and eats food.
Trolls have cap of invisibility.
Certain persons can see trolls.
Animals can see trolls.
Trolls visible to unconfirmed children.
Trolls seen through another‘s arm (or the like).
Trolls and men.
Trolls’ friendship with men.
Trolls‘ lending and borrowing.
Troll repays loan with costly or magic object.
Trolls steal from humans.
Trolls steal fish at Christmas.
Theft from troll.
Troll’s costly cup stolen.
Troll‘s treasure obtained by casting steel on it.
Trolls visit men.
Trolls visit people Christmas Eve.
Trolls carry off people.
Stolen woman saved from trolls’ dance.
Trolls as changelings.
Trolls help men.
Trolls help with grain harvest.
Trolls as the constant enemies of humans.
People possessed by trolls.
Trolls and Christianity.
Trolls flee before Christianity.
Troll helpless before sign of Cross.
Trolls may not utter holy names.
Troll killed.

Trolls killed by lightning.
Banning trolls.
Certain persons can ban trolls.

Test of troll child.
Offspring of trolls.
Mine spirits.
Knockers (Tommy Knockers, spriggins).
Origin of knockers or spriggins.
Knockers as ghosts of Jews who crucified Christ and who were forced to work Cornish tin mines as punishment.
Knockers as ghosts of giants who formerly lived in area.
Knockers as spirits of dead miners.
Actions of knockers.
Malicious actions of knockers.
Knockers bring ill luck if one whistles in the mine.
Knockers hide tools of miners.
Knockers tamper with dynamite fuses in mine.
Knockers kick rungs out of ladders, cutting off escape of trapped miners.
Knockers lame miners who bother them unduly.
Helpful actions of knockers.
Knockers lead men to the richest lodes in the mines by knocking in those areas.
Knockers do miner‘s work at night while he is gone.
Knockers test entries and supports by tapping them with hammers.
Knockers appear to miners before accidents occur: the sight of one serves as a warning to leave mine.
Other actions of knockers.
Knockers hold midnight mass deep in mines on Christmas Eve.
Knockers (ghosts of Jews) are compelled to sing carols in mines at Christmastime.
Knockers refrain from work on Saturdays and other Jewish holidays.
Mining spirit: “Bluecap.”
Bluecap moves coal-tubs for miners.
Mining spirit: “Cutty Soams”.
“Cutty” cuts cords by which miners pull tubs full of coal.
Miscellaneous mine spirit motifs.
Fairies operate coal mine.
Mountain spirits as souls of dead.
Appearance of mountain men.
Mountain-man in animal shape.
Mountain-man in shape of hog.
Mountain-wife has breasts so long that she throws them over her shoulder.
Mountain-man carries shears at side like sword.
Dress of mountain-men.
Mountain-men in white caps.
Mountain-men in red caps.
Huldra-woman’s cap.
Huldra-women have cow‘s tails.
Huldra-men with long teeth and nose.
Huldra invisible.
Characteristics of mountain-men.
Mountain-folk afraid of thunder.
Mountain-folk ride through air on horses.
Mountain-men cannot enter house till light is quenched.
Mountain-man has stack of butter before his door.
Huldra have lake.
Huldra live like people.
Huldra have drum.
Huldra have cattle.
Huldra have drinking-horn.
Huldra tend herds in mountains.
Mountain-man must die six times to be dead.
Huldra sing songs.
Mountain spirits eat raw food.
Mountain spirits change sex at will.
Amusements of mountain-folk.
Mountain-folk dance.
Mountain-men play games.
Relation of mountain-men and human beings.
Mountain-girl marries mortal man.
Mountain-men as lovers of herding-girls.

Helpful mountain-men.

Mountain-men give children a book.
Huldra trade cattle with men.
Mountain-men leave broken implement for man to mend.

Mountain-folk steal from peasant.
Mountain-men drive off man‘s herds.
Mountain-spirit causes shipwreck.
Mountain-men borrow from peasant.
Failure to bless mountains gives mountain-men power.
Mountain-man as godfather.
Visit to mountain-men.

House-spirit in form of a sow.

House to make household-spirit (cobold) surrender his booty.

Cobold.
Acquiring a cobold.

Impossible to rid oneself of cobold.

Fishing under sea.
Sea changes color.
Sea fettered.
Passing through sea unscathed.

Sea flows sweet water.
Sea bears fruits.

Sea piles up to height of sixteen hundred miles.
Speaking sea.

Extraordinary occurrences connected with rivers.
River pursues fugitive.
River arches over saint’s body like a vault.
Stream becomes hot in which saint performs his ascetic devotions.
Well of oil runs into river.
River acts as messenger.
River carries object to saint.
River ceases to flow.
River dries up for a day.
River dries up its waters out of sympathy.
In dead of night waters of stream cease flowing and stand perfectly still.
River boils.
River boils when ashes of hearts are cast into it.
River rises and overflows.
River rises to prevent body’s being carried over it against dying man‘s wish.

Extraordinary occurrences connected with springs.
Miraculous spring bursts forth for holy person.
Spring bursts forth where saint spills water from his bell.

Well rises so holy person does not have to draw from it.
Well rises so maiden can draw without exerting herself.

Dry spring restored by removal of certain stone.
At certain time sheep thrown into well become crimson.
Severed head of impious man in well causes water to become bitter during part of each day.
Rushes uprooted reveal spring.
Spring miraculously breaks forth against wrongdoer.
Desecrated well overflows.
Well floods when gazed upon until mass is said over it.
Bones of bird constantly thrown up from well.

Lake disappears.

Mountebank undertakes to bring the city’s incurables back to health.

Monsters.
Demons.
Origin of demons and their companions.
soul of the giants who perished in the flood.

Devil.
The origin of the devil and his companions.
The devil originates from God.
God creates the devil (Satan) from his own shadow.
Devil originates from God‘s spittle.
The devil originates from the spittle of an evil man.
God changes an angel into the devil, because he tried to imitate God in creating the world.
God creates the devil by striking a stone with his whip.
God discovers the devil.
God finds the devil sitting under a tree which was made by his throwing his staff into the water.
God finds the devil under a stone.
God discovers the devil in a piece of solid foam.
The devil is created without the special aid of God.
The devil is developed from man.
The devil is created out of a bubble.
The devil is created out of sea-foam.
Pagan gods became devils.
Satan created out of hell fire.
The devil creates other devils.
The devil creates devils by casting water behind himself.
Devils are created from sparks produced by Satan’s striking two stones together.
Five devils created by Adam create other devils in the same manner.
Devils are created from sinful priests.
Tuatha De Danann as demons (fallen angels).
Two devils (male and female) extracted from corpse‘s belly.
Names applied to the devil.
Devil calls himself ”Puss“.
Devil is called ”the black one“.
Devil says his name is ”Millearces“ (thousand ways to lead men to sin).
Gaelic titles given to the devil:
Forms in which the devil appears.
Devil in hideous form.
The devil in human form.
Devils in guise of human beings require remarkable quantity of food.
The devil as a large, strong man.
The devil as a well-dressed gentleman.
The devil as a distinguished-looking knight.
Devil as a ribald traveler.
Devil appears in the form of a man who is repugnantly ugly.
The devil as a little, gray old man.
The devil as a black man.
Devil as a huntsman.
Devil in form of priest.
Devil as a hermit.
Devil as ascetic.
Devil in form of pilgrim.
Devil as a peasant.
Devil as three gentlemen.
Devil in form of woman.
Devil in form of woman lures and punishes women.
Devil as a beautiful young woman seduces man.
Devil appears as a beautiful black wench.
Devil appears as old woman to seduce monk from cloister.
Devil (in queen’s form) insatiable, although she copulates with all men and horses.
Devil as cook.
Devil as student.
Devil appears as a Jew.
Devil appears as a child.
Devils appear as ladies and gentlemen.
Devil as shoemaker.
Devil as merchant.
Devil appears in shape of a dead man while hidden in his corpse or skin.
The devil as a great hairy man.
Devil as astrologer.
Satan disguised as beggar.
Satan as very old man.
Satan disguised as king.
The devil in superhuman from.
Devil appears as Christ.
Devil as crucifix.
Devil (Satan) appears as an angel.
Devil as a dwarf.
Devil in form of dragons and monsters of various sorts.
Devil appears as Virgin Mary.
The devil in animal form.
Devil in form of domestic beast.
Devil in form of dog.
Devil in form of a cat.
Devil as horse.
Devil in form of cow (bull, ox).
Devil in form of swine.
Devil in form of goat.
Devil in form of ram.
Devil in form of wild beast.
Devil in form of wolf.
Devil in form of fox.
Devil in form of hare.
Devil in form of mouse.
Devil in form of lion.
Devil in form of squirrel.
Devil in form of monkey.
Devil in form of deer.
Devil in form of hyena.
Devil in form of a terrifying elephant.
Devil in form of bird.
Devil in form of raven.
Devil in form of crow.
Devil in form of black bird.
Devil in form of woodcock.
Devil in form of cock.
Devil in form of owl.
Devil in form of insect.
Devil in form of gnat.
Devil in form of spider.
Devil in form of wasp.
Devil in form of fly.
Devil in form of fish.
Devil in form of reptile.
Devil in form of snake.

Devil in form of toad.
Miscellaneous other animal forms in which the devil appears: bear; ant; wild goose.

Devil in form of wheel on wagon.
Devil as a black ball.
Devil as a ball of fire.
Devil (Black Donald) as a bunch of ferns.
Devil as wind.
Devil as whirlwind.
Devil as a barrel.
Devil in shape of a stone.
Devil in the form of a sheaf.
Devil in form of round bowl.
Devil in form of house.
Devil in form of ungainly bundle.
Devil as stream of water.
Devil changes shape.
Devil becomes larger and larger.
Devil becomes smaller and smaller.
Devil becomes heavier and heavier.
Forms into which the devil cannot change.
Devil cannot change into pike.
Devil cannot change into dove.
Devil cannot change into lamb.
The devil cannot change into a sheep.
The devil’s physical characteristics.
The devil‘s head.
Devil has ninety-nine heads.
Devil’s eyes.
Devil with eye in middle of forehead.
Devil with glowing eyes.
Two beams of fire shoot from devil‘s eyes.
Devil has saucer eyes.
Devil has passionate look in eyes.
Devil has no eyebrows.
Devil is blind.
Devil’s beard.
Devil has a red beard.
Devil‘s nose.
Devil has a long nose.
Devil has only one nostril or is without nostrils at all.
Devil’s teeth.
Devil has shining teeth.
One of devil‘s teeth grows down to the earth; another to sky.
Devil has horns.
Devil has two horns.
Devil child born with horns.
The devil’s face.
Devil‘s face is black.
Devil’s hair.
Devil‘s hair blood-red.
Devil has three golden hairs.
The devil’s wings.
The devil has six wings.
The devil has twelve wings.
The devil‘s thumb.
Devil has glowing thumb.
Devil’s thumb the size of two fists.
Devil has claws.
Devil has five claws.
Devil has claws on his feet.
The devil‘s feet and legs.
Devils have only one leg.
Devil has only one foot.
Devil‘s shoes are empty.
Devil has a broken foot.
Devil has horse’s foot.
Devil detected by his hoofs.
Devil’s footprints without any toes.
The devil has goat feet.
Devil is betrayed by his goat hoofs.
Devil has pig’s foot.
Devil‘s knees are backwards.
Devil has no heels.
Devil has club foot.
Devil has cock’s feet.
The devil‘s tail.
A little girl recognizes the devil by his tail.
Boy recognizes devil when he fans fire with his tail.
Devil speaks with voice of a he-goat.
Miscellaneous characteristics of devil.
Devil has sulphurous odor.
Devil holds molten coin in mouth.
Devil holds fire in his hands.
Devil claims to be 7,777 years old.
Devil never eats in an inn.
Devil carries a thorn stick.
Devil is swift of foot.
Devil with pitchfork.
Devil laughs (weeps) when men weep (laugh).
Devil all speckled and spotted.
Devil’s hand marks person he touches.
Devil in animal form cannot be hit by bullets.
Devil picks up live coals to light pipe.
Devil invisible.
How the devil is dressed.
Devil is dressed in black.
Devil in a black cloak.
Devil is dressed in green.
Devil in green clothing with hat.
Devil as a hunter in green.
Devil wears a bright green coat.
The devil dressed in red.
Devil dressed in blue clothes.
Devil dressed in hunting clothes.
Circumstances of the devil‘s appearance.
When the devil appears.
Devil appears at midnight.
Devil comes when called upon.
Devil writes into book names of those who call on him.
Devil appears to claim soul offered to devil in jest.
Devil appears when a woman looks at herself in the mirror after sunset.
Devil appears when cards are played.
Devil invoked through medium of a black dog.
Devil appears on Hallowe‘en.
People to whom the devil appears.
Devil appears invisible among dancers.
Devil appears at meetings of witches.
Devil appears among youths who jest while they say their evening prayers.
Devil visible to one who walks in minister’s (or minister‘s wife’s) holy shoes (galoshes).
Devil appears to persons ready to abandon their integrity.
Devil appears to minister‘s serving man to warn of impending disaster to the house.
Devil appears to girl who prays over pit where she has thrown the bodies of her babies.
Devil appears to dying man.
Devil appears to saint (cleric).
Saint is able to see devils.
Devil appears to scholar.
Devil appears to Eve.
Devil hides in clothes of people running from storm.
Devil appears to person who cuts both ends off loaf of bread.
Devil appears to Sabbath breakers.
Devil appears when person steals.
Devil causes boy to make noise of wind breaking after he has stolen bushel of corn to pay for shoes.
Natural phenomena accompanying the devil’s appearance.
Devil is followed by a thunderstorm.
The devil appears during thunderstorm, seeking shelter among people.
Devil comes in the whirlwind.
Devil and the wind travel together.
Devil appears in an intense light and with strong odor of sulphur.
Devil‘s coming heralded by piercing whistle.
How the devil travels.
Devil rides horse.
Devil rides on black horse.
Devil‘s horses are transformed men.
Devil’s horse has human feet.
Devil (gentleman) invites traveler into his wagon.
Devil (gentleman) invites girls into his sleigh.
Devil rides horse at night hunting lost souls over the heath.
Devil rides away on an ass.
Devil drives horse and wagon.
Devil in wagon drawn by two black horses carries off impious people.
Devil drives carriage drawn by horses whose nostrils shoot fire.
Devil in coach drawn by headless horses.
Devil pursues man from carriage drawn by four white horses.
Devil travels in coach drawn by four blood-red horses, the hoofs of which strike fire from the pavement.
Devil comes in a cart.
Devil drives several teams of oxen.
Devil rides on hog, drives another.
Devil drives six he-goats.
Devil rides cow until she goes mad.
Devil flies like bird.
Devil‘s expulsion from heaven and his present haunts.
Devil driven from heaven.
God has Elias drive devils from heaven.
Archangels Michael and Gabriel drive Satan and other devils from heaven to earth.
Devil becomes an angel.
Devils carry away the sun when they fall from heaven.
The devil in hell.
Devil is thrust into hell by God.
Devil builds himself a castle and calls it hell.
Devil‘s house is visible on the way to hell.
Devil lives in a church.
Devil bound with huge chain near northern side of Tamdrup church.
Devil in each stone of church built with ill-gotten wealth.
Devil in interior of earth.
Devil and his servants live where perjurers dwell.
Devil‘s abode is between hoofs of swine.
Devil lives in the water.
Devils in woman’s train.
Devil in fold of knight‘s cloak.
Devil in dragon’s head on a shield.
Devil in a stone.
Devil in the stable wrapped in horse-hide.
Devil in the woods.
Youth meets devil in woods.
Forest devil the one which fell in the forest when driven from heaven.
Devil in woods to gather nuts on Christmas Eve.
Devils dwell in heathen idols, as well as portraits and images.
Devil hidden in a corpse.
Deeds of the devil.
The devil as a builder.
Devil as builder of bridges.
Devil as builder of dams.
Devil as builder of mill.
Devil as builder of walls.
Devil as builder of palaces (chвteaux).
Devil as builder of churches.
Devil builds a road.
Devil builds a ditch.
Devil builds two islands in a lake.
Devil builds an inn for a man in competition with a church being built.
Devil builds Mont Saint Michel.
Devil helps build Halberstadt Cathedral thinking a tavern is being built.
Devil builds a building.
Satan builds idol.
Satan builds another world.
The devil performs deeds of unusual strength.
Devil pulls up tree to goad his oxen.
Devil builds road for farmer in one day.
Devil plows and plants grain for farmer in one day.
Devil and Drake carry waters of English Channel from Dartmoor to Plymouth.
Devil and Michael Scott carry tide an additional five miles up River Wansbeck.
The devil hires out.
Devil hires out to a farmer.
The devil takes service with a farmer in return for the bread he stole.
Devil is employed as a midwife.
Devils help people at work, but are feared nevertheless.
The devil is always to blame.
The devil as a tempter.
Satan causes storm to destroy property of man he tempts.
Satan smites man he tempts with leprosy.
Devil gives Eve two grains of corn.
Devil persuades man to commit suicide.
The devil teaches man how to hang himself.
Devil tries to get man to kill his bride (wife).
Devil tempts cleric (hermit).
Devils appear to knight to try to call him from doing penance.
Devil by trick conjures vision to make idolators of believers.
Disguised devil as messenger to adulterous people.
Satan stops men from praying.
Devil tempts saints.
Devil instructs saint on virtues by which to attain Heaven.
Devil tempts girl.
Devil and girl.
Devil tempts youth to deny Virgin.
Devil tries to move repentant sinner to despair.
Woman worships the devil.
The devil as an abductor.
Devil abducts girl: has her hang about his neck and he flees to hell.
Devil carries away a lord on his back.
Devil compels two miners to follow him.
Devil carries man through air as swift as wind (thought).
Devil combs Mme.
Man temporarily abducted by devil.
Devil carries a Jew to hell.
Devil takes violinist when he needs a good fiddler in hell.
The devil fights.
The devil is armed.
Devil fights with man.
Devil is overcome by man in fight.
Satan fights Israel.
Satan attacks saints.
Devil inflames saint’s injured eye.
The devil advises human beings.
Devil advises young girl not to go to a castle.
Devil exhorts youth to enjoy himself and not to think of God.
The devil advises a suspicious husband.
Devil disguised as man tells of trip to heaven and hell.
Miscellaneous actions of the devil.
Devil spins and knits.
Devil plays fiddle at wedding.
Devil sings (dances) on grave.
Devil causes salamander to appear in glass of rum, drinks it.
Devil engages in drinking contest with man for purse of gold.
Satan asks God to put man into his power (Job).
Satan makes wager with God about mortal‘s piety.
Satan prays to God.
Satan chants songs of praise to God.
Satan weeps.
Satan as blasphemer.
Pranks played by the devil.
Devil prevents moving of little stone by sitting on it.
Devil interrupts mass by pretended battle.
Devil steals knight’s cloak.
Devil takes an unbaptized child out of the cradle and lays a wooden log in its place.
Devil piles sand in ocean so that vessels may run aground.
Devil leads and misguides people.
Trying all night to catch an animal (really devil).
Taking snuff with the devil.
Devil challenges boys to play a disc-game.
Exchanging things with the devil.
The devil as tailor to a dandy.
Devil engages in horse race with man.
Devil flies away with sentry box.
Devil drinks church well dry at one draught.
Devil stampedes horses of general.
Devil takes place of girl man is embracing in private place.
Devil as crow misleads travelers, puts out their lights.
Devil moves seats in church.
Devil plays marbles in church.
Satan entangles ram’s horns on the altar.
Satan liberates caught deer.
Allies and possessions of the devil.
Cat as follower of the devil.
Toad as follower of the devil.
Snake as follower of the devil.
Dancers as followers of the devil.
Devil haunts dance halls.
Devil dances with a maid until she dies.
Two devils come to a dance-loving maid and play when she bathes.
Devil teaches a dance-loving maid to dance.
Devil appears to girl who wants an escort for a dance.
Devil dances with maid and puts his claws through her hands.
Where the devil can‘t reach, he sends an old woman.
Devil in league with a freemason.
Devil gives luck with fishing and hunting.
Horses are offspring of the devil.
An all-red, all-black, or all-white calf the property of the devil.
Lizards are offspring of the devil.
The spurge-laurel is the devil’s bush.
The devil owns the reeds.
Thistles and nettles are the devil‘s vegetables.
The bagpipe is the devil’s bellows.
Devil has a hound.
Devil has a servant.
Bird as messenger of devil.
Angels of Satan.
Devil’s well.
The relatives of the devil.
The devil’s wife.
The devil‘s son is with his mother at night in his father’s place.
The devil‘s son.
The devil and his son fight over division of the earth.
The devil‘s children and grandchildren do his work for him.
The devil’s mother.
Devil’s mother rides a goat.
The devil‘s grandmother.
Devil‘s grandmother keeps house for devil.
Devil’s grandmother is bleaching when it snows.
The devil‘s daughter.
The devil and his nine daughters.
Marital experiences of the devil.
Devil wooes an innkeeper’s daughter.
Devil marries a widow who maltreats him.
Devil marries old maid who proves to be a termagant and a miser.
Devil visits woman and founds a family.
Devil marries girl.
Girl married to a devil.
Devil marries disdainful girl; she escapes.
Devil marries girl whose rich mother refuses to let her marry common young men of community.
Devil wooes woman;
Girl married to devil escapes with answers to his riddles.
Girl wooed by devil is saved by magic herb she wears.
Devil takes form of girl‘s lover and takes advantage of her.
Devil in guise of woman woos man.
Man marries a she-devil He catches her as succubus and marries.
Devil‘s sexual relations with mortals.
Satan’s sexual intercourse with Eve.
The stupid devil.
Devils do not know or understand thoughts of men.
Devil works backward.
Devil tries to wall in too large a piece of ground in a night and fails.
The devil tries to learn a trade; he fails miserably at all but versemaking.
Simple-minded devil indicates how he can be driven away.
Devil’s unfinished work cannot be completed by human hands.
The devil destroys by night what is built by day.
Devil destroys Adam‘s work by night.
Devil builds bridge except for one stone.
Places haunted by the devil.
Devil haunts premises about to be visited by calamity.
Granary now haunted because of devil’s defeat.
Devil haunts a house.
Devils haunt tree.
Particular species of tree abode of devils.
Ruins of a palace haunted by Satan.
Satan appears at a feast where the poor are absent.
How the devil‘s power may be escaped or avoided.
By the help of the Virgin Mary the devil may be escaped.
Devil’s power over one avoided by prayer.
Devil cannot take one who has read the Pater Noster.
Devil cannot enter person who is thinking of God.
Person saved from devil by prayer to Virgin.
Devil‘s power avoided by blessing.
Man escapes devils by reading Lord’s blessing.
Devil flees at pope‘s blessing.
Devils disappear when priest blesses bread.
A nun eating unblessed lettuce eats a demon.
Blessing reveals seemingly pure stream to be devil‘s trap which kills whoever drinks from it.
Devils driven away by hymn (psalm).
Demon cannot hurt holy man or woman.
Devil’s power avoided by the cross.
Devils driven away by cross.
Devil cannot endure cross made by straps of knapsack.
Devils put to flight by cross made of leaves.
Devil made to disappear by making sign of the cross.
Knight dismisses devil in name of cross.
Devil made visible by making sign of cross.
Words of religious comfort cause devil and his crew to vanish.
Administering sacrament destroys devil’s power.
Chaplain administers sacrament and saves woman‘s soul from devil.
Devil disappears when offered host.
Man is rescued from devil by baptism.
Devil is chased by holy water.
Devil leaves at mention of God‘s name.
Devil is made impotent by confession.
Angels save person from the devil.
Various holy persons save one from devil.
Devil is driven out of a man by Peter.
Devil prevented from revenge by pious priest.
Person chases the devil away.
Saint expels devil to hell.
Saint’s dispute with devil.
Ringing of churchbell causes devil to lose his power.
Devil may be escaped by going to church every day.
The devil exorcised.
Priest chases devil away.
Priest separates girl from devil‘s claws.
Devil chased by the fumes of burning arsenic.
Devil exorcised by burning wood.
Devil overpowered or chased with a stick of rowan-tree.
Why the devil fears the rowan-tree.
The devil is exorcised with bell, book, and candle.
Devil avoids cockscomb flowers.
Devils leave hermit who turns other cheek when struck.
Devil is cheated of his reward when priest dismisses mass early.
Devil cannot enter a house with horseshoe over door.
One must not whistle after sunset, else the devil will go along with one.
Christians are prohibited from whistling in dark lest the devil appear.
Miscellaneous ways in which the devil may be escaped or his power destroyed.
Man secure from devil on horse.
Devil goes with one if one spits on old castaway brooms.
One is freed if he can set a task the devil cannot perform.
Task for devil: sweeping and winnowing peas on ice.
Task for devil: making needles.
Task for devil: washing a Jew (Jewess), to rid him (her) of the evil smell.
Devil (Satan) flees when cock is made to crow.
Man imitates cock crowing: devil is deceived.
Demon has to serve girl whom he cannot persuade to break vow of chastity.
Man protected from devil by holding three-year old child through night.
Devil comes out of man when monk recognizes devil‘s voice in man.
Knight saved from devil by friends.
Devil becomes powerless when called by name.
Devil exorcised at time of Christ’s Nativity.
Devil frustrated by charity.
Devil can‘t approach Christian girl.
Devil cannot follow man over running water.
Devil escaped by injuring him with silver bullet.
Devil cannot enter magic circle made to keep him out.
Devil can be driven away by sacrifice.
Devil disappears because he is frightened.
Devil frightened by a woman.
Catching the devil.
Beating the devil.
Devil is killed by hunter.
The devil’s disappearance from the world.
When the devil disappears.
Devil disappears when cock crows.
Devil rebels and disappears on last day.
Devil disappears after erection of Tabernacle.
Physical circumstances of devil‘s disappearance.
Devil detected, goes up chimney in smoke.
Devil disappears in a whirlpool.
Devil goes out through stove with great noise.
Devil and sinful priest disappear amid blaze of fire in the river.
Devil retreats into hell amid thunder and lightning.
Devil disappears in a puddle.
Devil disappears amid terrible rattle.
Devil disappears amid terrible stench.
Devil disappears in carriage drawn by four black horses.
Why the devil has disappeared from the world.
The devil dies of a nosebleed resulting from overheat.
The devil dies when he is fastened in hell’s door by his beard.
Wolf eats the devil; therefore, devil no longer lives in the world.
Devil has not been seen since he created the bramble.
Satan punished in hell fire.
Devil enters body of another.
When devil leaves dead sinner‘s body, only bones remain.
Devil enters body of dead boy.
Devil in place of dead man in shroud (in dead man’s skin).
Devil blows skin off man who belongs to him and goes in the skin.
Satan enters the Golden Calf.
The devil takes the hindmost.
The last belongs to the devil.
Farmer has devil aid in reaping contest, loses his shadow when devil attempts to take hindmost.
Ways in which the devil kills people.
Devil kills man with fiery sword.
Devil destroys hunting party with terrible wind.
Devil strikes man dead with iron bar.
Devil strikes man dead with disease.
The devil unpeels a bold woman’s skin.
Devil as black dog kills people.
Satan swallows victim.
Satan injures man.
Satan slays the first born of the Egyptians.
The devil‘s money.
Devil’s money becomes ashes.
Devil’s money becomes manure.
The devil‘s money is hot.
The devil helps people.
Devil repays a kindness: returns coat lent him and brings the one who had shown him kindness back home when imprisoned.
Magician recovers lost object with devil’s help.
Student is helped by devil when he can answer three questions in rhyme.
Devil helps man place cart wheel when it becomes unfastened.
Devil exhibits benevolence to impious people (to people who make an alliance with him: gives them riches, helps them in need).
Devil helps person to steal.
Devil helps ugly man win wife.
Devil helps journeyman win wager with master.
Devil comes and works with man who continues to work after night.
Devil serves knight faithfully.
Devil as advocate of falsely condemned men.
Devil promises help to mistreated apprentice if youth will meet him by night in lonely spot.
Devil saves heretic from fire, until priest brings host.
Devil as helper in battle.
The devil and the ark.
Devil gets into the ark by hiding in shadow of Noah’s wife.
The devil in church.
Devil accuses congregation of sins.
Devil shows priest long parchment roll of sins of congregation.
Devil writes faults of man on goat skin.
Devil writes down names of men on a hide in church.
Devil stands in church door and writes down names of his own people on a sheepskin.
Devil in church fills his sack with dissolute songs.
Devil writes down all idle words spoken in church.
Devil writes names of those who sleep in church.
Devil disturbs people in the church.
Devil writes down names of those who look backwards in church.
Devil writes down names of those who whisper in church.
The devil has two books--one book small for sins of
Devils worship host.
Devil vexing friars caused to repent by singing ”Te sanctum dominum“.
Devil destroys church steeple.
Devil as dog chews up Bibles, hymnbooks, church accounts in church.
Miscellaneous devil motifs.
Wolf is the devil‘s craftiest enemy.
Devils fear St. Isaac.
Devil likes negligence in men more than anything else.
Devil cooks folk in kettle.
Devil’s chair in hell made from thrown-away nail parings.
From the parings of man‘s nails devils make little caps for themselves.
Old woman gives chickens to devils.
Man shoots the devil with a silver gun.
Devil shot with silver bullet.
Devil follows corpse when a lawyer is buried.
Devil follows corpse of a procurator.
Ship with devil aboard sinks.
Devil is blamed by monk for taking what does not belong to him.
Devil takes place of woman who went to spend night with a priest.
A farmer who trades horses with the devil is cheated.
Devil buys a woman’s hair; the silver coin which he gives in payment is changed to a piece of wood and she dies.
The food and drink of the devils.
Hideous food and drink at the night-spirits‘ (devils’) feast.
Devil roasts a toad.
The devil’s animals.
Tailless fish as devil‘s hog.
Possessions of the devil.
Devil’s pipe, gun or music.
The devils‘ dances and feasts.
Devil as gentleman invites a traveler to the feast (wedding).
A musician engaged to play for the night-spirits (devils) dances.
Devils arrange a wedding feast for a woman who hanged herself.
Devil can touch man’s body, not his soul.
Parliament of devils.
Troll as ogre.
Appearance of troll (ogre).
Troll in animal form.
Troll as fox.
Troll as hare.
Troll as goose.
Troll as crow.
Troll in form of object.
Troll in form of cloud.
Troll in form of key.
Many-headed troll.
Characteristics of trolls.
Fire-producing troll.
Troll lights fingers.
Troll stretches neck so long that fire comes from lips.
Troll’s food.
Troll‘s food gives men strength.
Special powers of troll.
Locks spring open for troll.
Antipathies of trolls.
Trolls cannot endure churchbells.
Trolls afraid of bears.
Troll bursts when sun shines on him.
Troll‘s possessions.
Troll’s castle.
Golden door to troll‘s castle.
Troll’s animals.
Troll has team of mice.
Troll drives two he-goats.
Troll has bear in stable.
Troll has hares in stable.
Earl king.
Rainbow as ogre.
Jinn.
Where jinn comes from.
Jinn always appears out of strong wind.
Form of jinn.
Jinn can take any human form he chooses.
Jinn unseen by anyone except person(s) he wishes should see him.
Jinn kills whoever tries to occupy house he has chosen to live in.
City infested by jinns deserted.
Sea monster.
Fight with sea (lake) monster.
Water-monster.
Herds of sea monsters on surface of sea.
Lake made dangerous by haunting serpent (dragon, pйist).
Shark-man ogre, eater of children swimming.
Lake monster has power to attract victims.
Clam shell invites man down into sea so he can be eaten.
Monsters of the sea: two whales of human parentage.
Demon-octopus.
Old man of the sea.
Cannibal ogre.
Pisaca.
Spirit-woman in rock devours men and cattle.
Flesh-eating spirits live in trees.
Man-eating ogre fries his victims in kettle of oil.
Bhrat, fierce flesh-eating creatures made by Creator in fit of anger.
Ogre eats only men’s hearts.
Ogress devours horses.
Procrustes.
Pine bender.
Cycnus.
Giant robber with club.
Wrestling ogre.
Cliff-ogre.
Pusher-into-hole.
Ogress at a spot along the road takes toll of lives.
Piercer-of-souls: fishes men.
Giant fisherman.
Brother-Dead.
Swinging ogre.
Rectum snakes.
Serpent inside man‘s body eats all his food.
Pot-tilter.
Sucking monster.
Ogre sucks victim’s finger and drinks all his blood.
Path between monsters.
Ogre keeps human prisoners.
Ogress has twenty captive princesses in cave.
Ogre
Ogre draws victims under water.
Demon drags beneath the water any person whose shadow falls on surface of water.
Sharp-elbowed women.
Ogre with sharpened leg.

Girl given enigmatic commands must do the opposite.
Three young men arrested tell who they are.
Arrested man tells who he is: before his father the great incline the head and give blood and money (barber).
Arrested man tells who he is: the hospitable fire of his father is sought (bean merchant).
Arrested man tells who he is: father throws himself into the ranks and holds them (weaver).
Arrested farmer tells who he is: one son is thief (priest), second beggar (teacher), and third murderer (doctor).
Riddling answers betray theft or adultery *BP I 198, II 361f.
Riddling answer betrays theft.
The full moon and the thirtieth of the month.
Riddling answers betray adultery.
Enigmatic statement betrays incest.
Woman‘s question to her husband disguised as woman, how many men she had in one night.
Clever youth (maiden) answers king’s inquiry in riddles.
King: What do you see? Youth: One and a half men and a horse‘s head.
King: Are you alone at home? Youth: Not now; I see the half of two quadrupeds.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: He is in the vineyard and is doing good and bad.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes an evil greater.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes many out of few.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes better from good.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: Cuts wood which was burnt last year.
King: What is your father doing? Youth: He fences thorns with thorns.
King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He hunts; he throws away what he catches and what he does not catch he carries with him.
King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He runs back and forth.
King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He sits between heaven and earth.
King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She does for another what the latter cannot do for her.
King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She shows the light of the world to one who has not yet seen it.
King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She is baking the bread we ate last week.
King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She cuts off the heads of the well to cure the sick.
King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She drives away the hungry and compels the filled to eat.
King: What are your mother and father doing? Girl: Mother
King: What is your mother doing? Girl: She has gone to turn one into two (to split peas).
King: What is your sister doing? Youth: She is mourning last year‘s laughter.
King: What are you doing? Youth: I boil those which come and go.
King: Where shall I tie my horse? Maiden: Between summer and winter.
Maiden (to king): The house has neither eyes nor ears.
Maiden (to king): Shall I feed you with loss or gain.
Girl to king: Should it (the flood) come I shall not come; should it not come, I shall come.
Other riddling answers.
Enigmatic conversation of king and peasant.
The four coins.
King: Why did you not do it (marry so that sons could help
Riddling remarks of traveling companion interpreted by girl (man) at end of journey.
Man helps traveler and makes riddling remarks.
Traveler says he is going to the city to see what has become of the seed he sowed in the street.
Traveler says he is going to seek a hind that he saw in the woods ten years before.
Traveler says he must look after his net to see if it has taken fish.
One traveler to another: Let us carry each other and shorten the way.
One traveler to another: That field (uncut) is already harvested.
One traveler to another (as they see corpse borne by): He is not entirely dead.
One traveler to another (when asked how he crossed an unbridged stream): I cross on an ashen bridge.
One traveler to another: Is this cup valuable or not?
Boy says that travelers should catch the mares (walking sticks that are in the jungle).
King gives enigmatic order to minister.
Enigmatic letter of king must be explained on pain of death.
King: Show me a ruby eight for a pice, nectar eight for a pice, and a faithless creature worth one-eighth of a pice.
Enigmatic counsels of a father.
Father-in-law gives daughter-in-law enigmatic permission to go home.
Father’s counsel: walk not in sunshine from your house to your shop.
Father‘s counsel: let pilav be your daily food.
Father’s counsel: marry a new wife every week.
Father‘s counsel: on wishing to drink wine go to the vat and drink it.
Father’s counsel: if you want to gamble, then gamble with experienced gamblers.
Father‘s counsel: dress up the trunks of trees, cover the road.
Father’s counsel: find treasure within a foot of the ground.
Father‘s counsel: the four wells.
Father’s counsel: dam up the outlets.
Father‘s counsel: don’t stay too late with a concubine, nor tell her any secret.
Always eat bread with “honey”.
“Never greet anyone.”
“Always wear new shoes.”
“Have a black look” (frown).
“Bite the ear” (do state affairs secretly).
“Take people by the locks” (use your influence to make people subservient to you).
“If you have to go to a prostitute, go early in the morning.”
“When you go to the bazar, eat your morning meal first.”
“A father should always check and never forgive; a mother should always forgive and never check.”
“Do not plant a thorny tree.”
Enigmatic advice: take only salt and water as food.
Extraordinary actions explained.
Man puts on shoes only when he wades river.
Man uses umbrella under trees.
Man cuts hooks for the revenge of his father (Hamlet).
Enigmatic statement made clear by experience.
“Love like Salt.”
“Love like wind in hot sun.”
Poison in nectar: wife who betrays husband to his enemies.
Nectar in poison: mistress who saves her lover.
Dogs in human shape: friends who seduce man‘s wife.
Donkey ruling a kingdom: king condemning man unjustly.
Suitors receive enigmatic answers.
Inhospitality reproved enigmatically.
Enigmatic statement: roof has no eaves.
Enigmatic statement: the tank (pond) does not belong to you.
Enigmatic statement: the flocks are only rocks and grass.
Enigmatic welcome of host.
Symbolic invitation to continued liberality.
Enigmatic counsels of relatives (other than father).
Enigmatic counsels of a brother.
Enigmatic counsels of older brother.
Other enigmatic statements.
Girl will not drink of water which had no father or mother

Clever flatterer: Sir, you are a full moon, and my
Man asked to kill thousands, press hundreds beneath his arm, etc.
Enigmatic counsel: uproot old trees and plant new ones (dismiss old governors and appoint new).
Give coals orange color, let glimmer of gold appear like expanse of heaven, prepare two heads of darkness.
Wise carving of the fowl.
Wise division of the goat (similar).

Symbolic meaning of numbers one to seven (ten, twelve).
