Symbolic meaning of spiced and bitter tongue served at dinner.
Angel gives symbolic interpretation of value of work as well as of prayer.
Symbolic interpretation of sin.
Discussion by symbols.
Discussion between priest and Jew carried on by symbols.
Discussion between two poets (sages?) carried on in poetic obscure language.
Learned professor from one university examines by signs a professor at another university (actually shoemaker or miller or the like).
Princess declares her love through sign language: not understood.
Is town too full of anchorites?
Symbolic interpretation of official robes.
Symbolic interpretation of points on a bishop’s hat.
Youth asks for branch of tree; promised root.
Melons ripe and overripe analogous to girls ready for marriage.
Sign message sent by girl to enamored prince; interpreted by prince‘s friend.
Chief asks another for cutting of yams to complete his yam patch (daughter in marriage).
Explanation of enigmatic phenomenon.
Explanation of phenomenon; a man who not only picks up wood but everything that lies in his path (a miser).
Explanation of phenomenon: large pond emptying itself into several smaller pools (man may spend without getting any return).
Symbolic interpretations of dreams.
Other symbolic interpretations.
Symbolic interpretation of chairs in heaven.
Symbolic interpretation of church and image therein.
Roots and branches of World-tree explained symbolically.

Symbolical interpretation of fight between one-legged bird and twelve-legged bird.
Skillful companions create woman: to whom does she belong?
Skillful companions resuscitate girl: to whom does she belong?
Girl rescued by skillful companions: to whom does she belong?
Hare and pig race across ditch.
what is the strongest?
What is the strongest? A horse.
What is the strongest? God.
What is strongest? Earth.
What is strongest? Woman.
What is strongest? Truth.
What is mightiest? Rain.
What is strongest? Necessity.
What is strongest? Wine.
What is strongest? The king.
what is the swiftest?
What is swiftest? Thought.
What is swiftest? The eye.
What is swiftest? The sun.
what is sweetest?
What is sweetest? Sleep.
What is sweetest? Peace in heaven.
What is sweetest? Mother’s breast.
What is sweetest? One‘s own interest.
What is sweeter than sugar? The princess’s speech.
what is the sweetest song?
What is the sweetest song? Angel song.
what is the sweetest sound?
What is the sweetest sound? Bell-ringing.
What is the sweetest sound? God‘s Word.
what is the richest?
What is richest? Autumn.
what is the hardest?
What is hardest? Parent’s heart
What is the hardest? Death.
what is costliest?
What is costliest? The earth.
what is most beautiful?
What is most beautiful? The spring.
What is most beautiful? Earth.
what is highest?
What is highest? Sun, moon, and stars.
what is deepest?
What is deepest? The heart of man.
what is longest?
What is longest? The way through the world.
what is the heaviest?
What is heaviest? Lead.
what is greenest?
What is greenest? The Month of May.
what is the most beloved?
What is most beloved? Life.
What is most beloved? Health.
what is best?
What is best? God.
What is best? Water.
what is brightest?
What is brightest? The sun.
What is brightest? Mother‘s eyes.
what is softest?
What is softest? The hand.
What is softest? Mother’s bosom.
what is the fattest?
What is the fattest? The earth.
Riddles of the superlative--miscellaneous.
what is oldest?
What is oldest? God.
what four things are hardest to hold?
What four things are hardest to hold? Wolf by eyebrows, bear by claws, snake by tail, hawk by beak.
what are best and worst stones?
What are best and worst stones? Best: altar, whetstone, millstone; worst: hailstone, stone in the eye, gallstone.
what is the best fowl?
What is the best fowl? The goose, since it makes the cabbage sweet and the bed soft.
what is best religion--Christian or Mohammedan?
What is best religion--Christian or Mohammedan? They are equally good:
what kind of work occupies most men?
What kind of work occupies most men? Healing, for every sick man practices this.
what is greatest?
What is greatest? Fame.
What is the greatest? A sense of shame.
What is the greatest? Charity.
What is the greatest villainy? Stealing.
What is moistest? The south wind.
what is wisest?
What is wisest? Time.
what is most general?
What is most general? Hope.
what is most useful?
What is most useful? Excellence.
what is most shameful?
What is most shameful? Cowardice.
what is most pleasant?
What is most pleasant? Love.
what is easiest?
What is easiest? The natural.
what is the hardest to skin?
What is the hardest to skin? The male member.
Who are the best painters? Women
what is the best time to eat? For the rich man, when he wishes; for the poor man, when he has something to eat.
What are the most accursed things?
What are the most accursed things? A thriftless wife, a
What is the most difficult to find and the most difficult to lose? The truth.
Who are really irresistible? Meat and drink.
Who are really meek? Cows and daughters.
Which is best, domestic or ascetic life? With good wife domestic life is best.
Which is the best of flowers? Cotton.
What is the finest jewel?
What is most faithful thing in world?
What is most faithless thing in world?
what is swifter than a bird, the wind or lightning? The eye.
what is dearer than gold? Mother love.
what is whiter than a swan? An angel.
what is sweeter than honey?
what is softer than swan down?
what is harder than stone?
Who is greater than God? Man‘s purpose.
Riddles of terrestrial distance.
how far is it from one end of the earth to the other (east to west)?
How far is it from one end of the earth to the other? A day’s journey, since the sun makes it daily.
how deep is the earth (or how far to lower world)?
How deep is the earth? It is deep: my grandfather went into it (died) years ago and has not yet returned.
How deep is the earth? My father went five years ago to measure it (died); when he returns I shall tell you the result.
what is the center of the earth?
Where is the center of the earth? Here; if you don‘t believe it, measure it yourself.
Where is the center of the earth? Here, for the earth is round and any point can serve as center.
how deep is the sea?
How deep is the sea? A stone’s throw.
How deep is the sea? At first, knee-deep; further on, waist-deep, neck-deep; and beyond that over the head.
Riddles of heavenly distance.
how far is it from earth to heaven?
How far is it from earth to heaven? A day‘s journey, since Christ went to heaven in one day.
How far is it from earth to heaven? A day‘s journey, since there is no inn to stop at on the way.
How far is it from earth to heaven? So and so high, and if you don’t believe it, measure it yourself.
How far is it from earth to heaven? As far as you can see.
How far is it from earth to heaven? As far as from heaven to earth.
How far is it from earth to heaven? Not far; when it thunders there it can be heard here.
How far from earth to heaven? A calf‘s (fox’s) tail, if it were long enough.
How far from earth to heaven? A leg‘s length, for it is written, Heaven is my throne and earth my footstool.
How far from earth to heaven? One step, for they say, He stands with one foot in the grave and one in heaven.
How far from earth to heaven? The devil knows for he has fallen this distance.
how wide is heaven?
How wide is heaven? So and so wide, and if you do not believe it, go measure it yourself.
How many exits from paradise?
how far is it from happiness to misfortune?
How far is it from happiness to misfortune? One day; yesterday I was herdsman and now I am abbot.
Riddles of weight.
how much does the moon weigh?
How much does the moon weigh? A pound, for it has four quarters.
How much does the moon weigh? So and so much, and if you don’t believe it go and weigh it yourself.
how heavy is the earth?
How heavy is the earth? Take away all the stones and I will weigh it.
Riddles of measure.
how much water is in the sea?
How much water is in the sea? Stop all the rivers and I will measure it.
How much water is in the sea? So and so much, and if you don‘t believe it, go measure it yourself.
How much water is in the sea? A tub-full if the tub is large enough.
How many measures of water are in the river?
how many seconds in eternity?
How many seconds in eternity? A bird carries a grain of
how many stars in the heavens?
How many stars in the heavens? As many as the grains of sand; if you don’t believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heaven? Two million; if you don‘t believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heavens? As many as the hairs in the head; if you don’t believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heavens? As many as the hairs in the goatskin (on a donkey).
How many stars in the heavens? As many as the points on paper; if you don‘t believe it, count them yourself.
how many hairs are in the head?
How many hairs are there in the head? As many as are in the
how many drops in the sea.
how many leaves are on the tree?
How many leaves are on the tree? As many as there are stems for.
How many leaves are on the tree? So and so many; and if you don’t believe it, go count them.
How many leaves are on the tree? Counterquestion: how many stars in the sky?
how many days have passed since the time of Adam?
How many days have passed since the time of Adam? The seven days of the week.
Riddle of dates.
When were you born? Its beginning is like its end, its top like its bottom (1691).
Are there more men or women in the world?
how much am I (the king) worth?
How much am I (the king) worth? Twenty-nine pieces of silver, for Christ was sold for thirty.
how much is my beard (king‘s) worth?
How much is king’s beard worth? The months July, August, and September.
How much is king‘s beard worth? A May rain (three rains in summer).
how much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace) worth?
How much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace) worth? A rain in May.
how much does the sun earn for his daily work?
How much does the sun earn for his daily work? A day’s wages.
how much is a certain crucifix worth? Twenty-nine pieces of silver.
Riddle of the year.
tree with twelve branches, each with thirty leaves, black and white.
tree with leaves white on one side and black on other.
twelve cypresses with thirty boughs each.
palace consisting of 8760 stones; twelve trees, thirty branches, each with black and white cluster of grapes.
Riddle of the day and night.
white brother, black sister: every morning brother kills sister; every evening sister kills brother; they never die.
black and white horses chasing each other.
Riddle of the course of the sun.
bird nests on top of one cypress in morning, on top of another in evening.
who are the real travellers? The son and the moon.
Riddle of king and courtiers.
king in red; courtiers in white.
king in white; courtiers in white.
king in red; courtiers in different colors.
what is the mother who devours her children when they grow up?
Riddle white field, black seed.
two legs, three legs, four legs.
four hang, four walk, two show the road, one wags behind.
six legs, four ears, two faces, etc.
bill white, horns on feet, knob on head (cock).
who of fourfold beard is he, of azure foot and neck so ruddy? Arrow.
Riddle of the Sphinx: what is it that goes on four legs in the morning, on two at midday, and on three in the evening.
two are better than three (two legs better than man with staff in old age).
what is the creature that is of all countries, that is loved by all the world, and that has no equal?
the father not yet born, the son already at the top of the house.
bird without feathers flies on tree without leaves.
From wooden spring iron bucket makes stones from which water flows.

what is that thou passest over with haste?
What house

why are there more days than nights?
why are there more living than dead?
why are there more women than men?
a fish was my father; a man was my mother.

seven tongues in a head.

what does God do?
What does God do? He brings low the proud and exalts the lowly
What does God do? God is astonished that I sit on a horse and the king on an ass
one killed none and yet killed twelve.
deaths from sleepiness, anger, and greed.
from the eater came forth meat and from the strong sweetness.

drink this wine which a bird took to nest.
Formerly I was daughter, now I am mother; I have a son who was the husband of my mother.
who first spun and when?
what were the clothes of Adam and Eve?
who, having neither father nor mother, are dead?
who, having had father and mother, is not dead?
who, having had father and mother, is not dead like other mortals?
who has had, here below, two names?
what was the walking tomb with the living tenant?
what is the land that has seen the sun only once?
What is the land that has seen the sun only once?

what is that which has drunk water for its sustenance and eaten after its death?
the king is surrounded by his nobles; what is this like?
what did Christ do in his 30th year?
what does the king of the world of the Devas do?
What three not born of male and female ate and drank on earth?
what house was full of dead?

worth of the animal.
what animal is good living but not dead?
what animal is good dead but not living?
what animal is good living and dead?
what animal is not good living or dead?
animal qualities.
What animal which lives in sea-water will drown if taken out of it?
What animal which lives in fire will burn if taken out of it?

what are the two fixed, the two moving, the two joined, the two separated by jealousy, the two eternal enemies?

what are the two combatants without hands or feet or words?

what do crows do when they are five years old?
what six things are not worth doing?

Tasks contrary to the nature of objects.
Task: hatching boiled eggs.
Task: hatching boiled eggs; countertask: sowing cooked seeds and harvesting the crop.
Task: hatching eggs immediately; countertask: sowing seeds and bringing in crop next morning.

Task: carrying water in sieve; sieve filled with moss.
Task: carrying water in sieve; pious child able to do so.

Task: carrying water in leaky vessel; vessel repaired with clay or gum.

Task: bringing berries in winter.

Task: washing black wool (cloth, cattle) white.
Task: washing large heavy quilt covered with ghi and oil without aid of soap or anything.

Task: sewing together a broken egg.
Task: sewing together a broken ship.
Task: fixing the two pieces of a broken sword together.
Task: mending a broken jug.
Task: mending a broken jug; countertask: turning it wrong side out as one does a shoe.
Task: skinning a stone.
Task: skinning a stone; countertask: first let the stone bleed.
Task: putting a large squash whole into a narrow-necked jar.
Task: catching a noise.
Task: catching a man’s broken wind.
Task: splitting a hair with a blunt knife.
Task: turning fruit into gold.
Task: making sun and moon shine in the north.
Task: sowing rye and bringing crop next morning.
Task: putting peaches back on tree.
Task: bringing bundle of faggots without rope to tie them.

Task: catching a sunbeam.
Task: tying the sun with a stone chain.

Task: milking a bull.

Task: making a bull bear a calf.
Task: placing frogs in a tree.
Task: chasing a hare into every trap in a high tree.

Task: procuring bird out of season.

Task: teaching horse to speak.
Task: spinning wool still on goat’s back.
Task: obtaining fat (bacon) from swine that never was farrowed.
Task: changing the course of time.
Task: naming those things which have not yet happened.
Task: bringing past time to present.
Task: showing picture of a voice.
Task: eating the moon.

Task: getting fruit from top of tall tree without cutting tree.
Task: bringing a plantain leaf from the garden without tearing it.
Task: recalling a dream someone else has had.
Task: filling a sack full of lies (truths).
Task: going to get nothing and bringing it back.
Task: carrying woman across river without wetting feet.
Task: dipping water without wetting dipper.
Task: cutting and bringing leaves from thorn thicket without tearing them at all.
Task: drinking beer without touching pot.
Task: bringing melon 12 cubits long with seed 13 cubits long.

Task: bringing the foam of the ocean in a large piece of cloth.

Task: setting back sun.
Task: stopping the rain.

Task: standing neither inside nor outside of gate.

Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot.
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot.
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot.

Task: coming neither naked nor clad.
Task: coming neither naked nor clad.
Task: coming neither naked nor clad.

Task: coming neither barefoot nor shod.
Task: coming neither with nor without a present (game).
Task: coming neither by day nor by night.
Task: standing between summer and winter.
Task: coming neither with nor without a companion.
Task: coming neither washed nor unwashed.
Task: coming neither hungry nor satiated.
Task: coming laughing and crying at once.
Task: bringing best friend, worst enemy, best servant, greatest pleasure-giver.
Task: sweep the floor and do not sweep it.
Task: light fire but do not light it.
Task: making bed but do not make it.
Task: eat bread but bring it back whole.
Task: give sheep good care but do not let it fatten.
Task: filling glasses with water that has neither fallen from heaven nor sprung from the earth.
Task: furnish beef which is neither male nor female.
something ever-decreasing
and something which both increases and decreases

Test of fidelity by feigning sleep in same bed as calumniated hero or alone in the forest with him.
Tests of obedience.
Obedience of sons tested by offering them apple.

Pope tests women’s disobedience: not to look into box.

A Classification of Narrative Elements in
Folktales, Ballads, Myths, Fables, Mediaeval Romances,
Exempla, Fabliaux, Jest-Books, and
Local Legends
Indiana University
Shipwrecked shepherd distrusts the sea.
Man bitten by snake fears snake-like rope.

Young sparrows have learned to avoid men.
Old racehorse in mill laments vanity of youth.
Serpent (bird) having injured man refuses reconciliation.
Dove disregards experience and loses brood.
Animal learns through experience to fear men.
Tiger, jackal, and bear each learn to fear man.
Wisdom acquired from beating.
Counsels proved wise by experience.
Wise words of dying father.
”Consider the end“:
”Do not act when angry“:
”Never attack anyone before unsheathing and returning sword three times“:
Sleep before committing suicide.
”Do not draw your sword against the innocent“:
”Do not uncover weapon in an assembly“:
”Do not shed the blood of women“:
”Control your anger at the beginning“:
”Do not go where an old man has a young wife“:
”Do not marry a girl from abroad“:
”Do not leave the highway“:
”Do not prefer a new road to an old one.“
”Take side road rather than main one where three roads meet“:
”A way short yet long“:
”Do not ask questions about extraordinary things“:
”Do not cross a bridge without dismounting from your horse“;
”Never wager more than a groat“:
”Do not bet“:
”Do not visit your friends often“:
”Do not prolong a friendly visit.“
”Do not lend out your horse“:
”Do not walk half a mile with a man without asking his name“:
”Rue not a thing that is past“:
”Never believe what is beyond belief“:
”Never try to reach the unattainable“:
”If you wish to hang yourself, do so by the stone which I point out“:
”Go to Goosebridge“:
”Stay at church till mass is finished“:
”Do not trust the over-holy“:
”Start your journey early in the day“:
”Prepare for night camp while it is still day“:
”Do not cross a swollen stream until it has run down“:
”Do not tell a secret to a woman“:
”Rise earlier“:
”Do not make a horse run down hill“:
”Do not keep bad company“:
”Don‘t be too greedy in making a trade“:
”Do not adopt a child“:
”Do not trust a ruler who rules by reason alone“:
”Keep head dry, feet warm, and eat meat“:
”Never have to do with a woman unless wed to her“:
”Do not marry a woman before seeing her and finding her to be your equal“:
”Do not marry more than one woman“.
”Bathe by yourself and not in the common bathing place“:
”Move stool before sitting on it“:
”When in a strange place look about you“:
”Do not sit on a bed without touching it first“:
”Ruler should follow advice of majority“
”Neglect not what four or five people say“:
”Do not go alone on journey“:
”Do not take a woman’s advice“:
”May God spare you from an evil man or evil woman.“
”Do not travel without money“:
Don’t require honor from a strange country”: counsel proved wise by experience.
“Be cautious before allowing yourself to fall asleep in a strange place”:
“Sleep not in an inn”:
“A stranger does not close his eyes in sleep lest he close them in death”:
“He who lies awake gains; he who sleeps loses”:
“Before eating food at a strange place throw some at an animal and watch”:
“A country not examined in disguise will always be ruined”:
“Lean upon no relation in the hour of distress”:
“Do not undertake to be an arbitrator without being asked”:
“Do not make friends with a policeman (soldier)”:
“You can only call your wife your own so long as she is with you”:
“Do not send your wife for a long visit to her parents”:
“Don‘t do anything without investigation”:
“Never give a cup made of a single ruby as a present to the king”:
“Idleness begets woe; work brings happiness”:
“Do not stand and watch two people fighting”:
Counsels proved wise by experience--miscellaneous.
Disciple who stays in a city where everything is sold at one price finds justice is not even there.
“Never be rude to a self-made man of low birth”:
“Hardened clay is hard to mold”:
“Never publish a man‘s sin if you can help it”:
“Never dismiss and old servant for his first fault”:
“When a man attacks you, kill him whether he be king or prince”:
Boy who says “I know” gets into all sort of difficulties; now says “I don’t know.”
“Nothing happens that does not work for one‘s good”:
“He who throws himself against a wave is overthrown by it”:
Precepts of the lion to his sons.
Precept of the lion to his sons: beware of man.
Precept of the lion to his sons: honor the woods.
Precept of the lion to his sons: keep peace with the neighbors.
Merchants try honesty for a year and find that it pays.
Fools learn to be peaceable.
Why great man plays with children.
Enemies can be won more by kindness than cruelty.
Man learns the fear of Death by meeting Life.
Encounter with clever children (woman) dissuades man from visit.
Cleverness of men disguised as peasants dissuades rivals from dispute.
Arrow as man‘s message shows lion how terrible man himself must be.
Blind man who feels young wolf recognises his savage nature.
Odor of the wine cask.
Sight of deformed witches causes man to release wife from spinning duty.
King observes retaliation among animals: becomes just.
Understanding of universality of death from watching animals prey on one another.

Ruler learns lesson from seeing city governed by king as uncharitable as he.

Observation of dying people for a year takes man‘s thoughts from lust.
Ducklings take to water from instinct.
Birds having learned their possible dangers are forced from nest by mother.
Drops of water make hollow in stone: thus repeated impressions penetrate mind.
Lazy pupil determines to be more diligent by watching man

Man kills nest of ants: so God punishes man.

Ass refuses to drink after it has had enough.

Tree of knowledge.
Wisdom from books.

Inscription on walls for condensed education.
Proverbial wisdom: counsels.
Counsel: if you take it you will be sorry; if you don‘t you will also be sorry.
King questions six doctors.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth? That man has not what he wishes to have.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth? That all joys are mixed with sorrow.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth? That all evil and hypocrisy will have an end.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth? That those who are most respected are the biggest fools.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth? That those who speak of spiritual matters are usually the most depraved.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth? That man lives in a state in which he cannot die.
Other maxims.
Crow flying away says, “A wise man remains not in the place of calamity; but a fool stays there, and sups fear and sorrow.”
Proverbial wisdom: “Seek to win over the accuser, so that he causes you no annoyance.”
Account of punishments prepared in hell brings about repentance.
Wisdom taught by suicidal example.
Good and bad in all books.
Wisdom from young man.
Wisdom from evil spirits.
Wisdom from brother-in-law.
Wisdom from robbers (thugs) who disguise selves and show cruel princess how she should treat her husband.
Other means of acquiring wisdom (knowledge)--miscellaneous.
Humble Brahmin teaches king the difference between “mine” and “thine.
Wisdom learned in underground kingdom: the passions of a human being could not be satisfied on earth.
Wisdom from neighbors.
Wisdom from fasting.
Possession of wisdom.
The years not counted.
Varieties of wisdom.
“Forty-nine gates of wisdom”
Seventy-two kinds of wisdom.
Wisdom wins contest of wisdom and wealth.
Minister‘s clever daughter-in-law uses wisdom to defeat Brahmin’s wealth.
Wisdom lost by accepting bribes and gifts.
Acquisition and possession of wisdom--miscellaneous.
Wise men.
Solomon as wise man.

Wise nations.
Wisdom from “Children of the East.”
Wisdom from Egypt.
Wisdom from the Greeks.
Wisdom from the Hebrews.
Hobson’s choice: choose what is put before you or nothing.
Choice between eggs: one egg or none.
Four choices, all of which are evil; man to make one choice only.
free poverty or enslaved wealth.
Philosopher chooses poverty with freedom.
Man gives all his wealth away, for it is better to die than to give up virtue.
Town mouse and country mouse.
Fly jeers at king‘s elephant for his lack of freedom.
plainness with safety or grandeur with danger.
Ass envies horse in fine trappings.
loss of beauty or speech.
suffering in youth or old age.
Present evil preferred to change for worse.
Don’t drive away the flies.
Don‘t set a hungry guard over food.
King refuses to exile gossipers.
Do not pluck off the well-fed leeches.
Old man chooses to be annoyed by occasional and loud chirp of swallows than by never-ending but soft chirp of sandpipers.
Oxen decide not to kill butchers, since inexpert killers might replace them.
Old woman prays for safety of cruel tyrant for fear a worse one will succeed him.
Heathcock prefers home with hardships to travel in foreign lands.
Monk goes to wilderness to escape work on material things.
Choice of deaths.
Army faces enemy rather than the anger of their king who would kill them if they returned in flight.
Lamb prefers to be sacrificed in temple rather than to be eaten by a wolf.
Crab would rather be killed outright than imprisoned and starved.
Soldier asks to be stabbed in chest.
Early death with fame preferred.
Saint chooses to die “after pride of youth” and before “misery of old age.”
Captivity preferred to death.
Unsatisfactory life preferred to death.
Trickster overhears man praying for death to take him;
Escaped lamb delivers himself to shepherd rather than to slaughter.
Discontented ass longs for death but changes mind when he sees skins of dead asses at a fair.
Enemies make peace rather than slay each other.
Lion and wild boar make peace rather than slay each other for benefit of vulture.
Hostile dogs made friendly by having them fight common enemy, the wolf.
small injustice permitted rather than to cause troubles of state.
King overlooks wife’s unfaithfulness rather than to cause troubles of state.
Senator overlooks wife‘s adultery rather than impair his reputation.
Man rebukes servants for telling him of his wife’s unfaithfulness.
King chooses small inconvenience of personal troubles to great troubles for his kingdom.
Man would rather pay 500 florins he did not owe than have it said he did not pay debts.
Rescue alone from shipwreck chosen over drowning with goods.
Choice between evils: pay tribute or lose both money and life.
apparent injustice over greater wrong.
Angel and hermit.
Angel explains to hermit why God lets a sinner die in peace and have big funeral while holy hermit is slain by a wild beast.
God punishes many men because of one sinner, like a man who kills hive of bees for stinging of one.
Angel in form of young man shows skeptical hermit that ways of providence are inscrutable.
Youth made lame: had kicked his mother.
Lion sent to kill a man: frees him from possibility of sinning and sojourn in purgatory.
Angel takes cup from old man.
Angel (Jesus) kills man.
Angel kills man because he loves his child too much.
Saint gives liberally to gambler, little to beggar.
Forestman who longs to do evil is sent to hell: writer, who repents, is sent to heaven.
Evil mother has fine funeral, good father poor.
Difficult choice between relatives.
Choice of freeing one son: adopted son or long-missing son.
blind son with long life or healthy son with short.
foolish son always with him or four wise daughters who will leave him.
Death preferred to other evils.
Death preferred to captivity.
Death preferred to dishonor.
Choice between evils--miscellaneous.
staying at home with loving wife or going to tavern and having unfaithful wife.
Sheep and ignorant shearer.
a big piece of cake with my curse or a small piece with my blessing.
Better send an ugly woman to the devil than a pretty one.
Choice between bad master, bad official, or bad neighbor.
Bad choice between poor and miserly man.
Rower prefers to be stoned by his master rather than remain out in the storm.
Contentment with evil master for fear of worse successor.
Weaver prefers master with one hedgehog.
Man retains questionable bride for fear of getting one who is worse.
The smaller the evil the better.
Take money instead of revenge.
Prisoners given choice between emasculation and blinding.
God‘s punishment: the sinner may have twelve years of famine or twelve hours of heavy rainfall.
Physical pain preferred to poverty.
Wisdom chosen above all else.
Solomon, permitted by God to make any request, asks wisdom.
Choice between love and wisdom.
Health chosen as the most precious thing.
Choice between desire and duty.
Fruitful tree chosen.
Athena chooses olive tree because of fruitfulness.
Peasant leaves honey tree standing.
Useful wins contest over beautiful.
Contest between rose and amaranth: worth lies not in beauty.
Pine and thornbush dispute as to their usefulness.
Fox and panther contest in beauty.
Peacock proved to be bad king.
Peacock and crane in beauty contest.
Contest in beauty between swallows and crows (ants and flies): worth lies not in beauty.
Choice of a learned crow: a dead cat better than a golden crown.
In dividing property clever younger brother takes hind part of buffalo, upper part of tree, and use of curtain during night.
Usefulness better than speed.
Dog and hog dispute over their children: worth lies not in speed.
Goodness preferred to beauty.
Father with handsome son and hideous daughter.
Useful and ugly preferred to expensive and beautiful.
Millstone preferred to jewels.
King who experiences the cultural civilization of an empire in dream would rather be poor and primitive.
Strength preferred to cleverness.
Man criticizes the devil because his deeds are not fair.
Hero, despising weapons, fights with fists alone.
Goodness preferred to wealth.
Man advised to choose good poor man for his daughter’s husband rather than rich man.
Practical knowledge more vital than theoretical.
The bookman and the boatman: each ignorant of other‘s work.
Learned person worth two unlearned.
Loudest mourners not greatest sorrowers.
Noisy things often empty.
Fox and noisy but empty drum.
Little coin in empty bottle noisy.
Among many vain words may be found some of wisdom.
Apparent beauty may be of the least importance.
Choice between short and dangerous or long and sure way.
Choice between flattering lies and unflattering truths.
Raven drowns his young who promise to aid him when he becomes old.
Quality of offspring preferred to quantity.
“Only one, but a lion”.
Heed not the past.
Count only the waves before you.
Do not ask: “Why were the former days better than the present ones?”
Not what you were but what you are counts.
Wasp twits butterfly with coming from ugly chrysalis: unimportant where you come from.
Present possessions preferred to future possibilities.
A bird in the hand foolishly given away in hope of greater gain.
Today’s catch of fish traded for prospective larger catch tomorrow.
Little fish in the net kept rather than wait for uncertainty of greater catch.
Lion leaves sleeping hare to follow the shepherd.
Present possessions preferred to future.
Don‘t injure yourself to insure your family’s future.
Man wagers he can run with his head off.
Man to be reforged chooses present unhappiness.
Children choose father they know rather than real father they do not yet know.
Man prefers servant girl who is present to her absent mistress.
Soldier prefers to live rather than die and be avenged on enemy.
Weight of bodily member chosen rather than its loss.
Fox prefers to bear weight of his tail rather than give part of it to ape.
High wages bring expensive living.
Barber leaves inexpensive village for high wages in city.
In spite of master‘s advice disciple stays in country where everything has cheap price.
Wise man refuses income of half a kingdom since expenses will outweigh gain.
Man refuses cure which brings greater inconvenience.
Drunkard refuses cure of fever if it is to take away his thirst.
What one has is neglected in search for other things.
The monkey and the lost lentil.
Host wants to learn Hebrew even at risk of forgetting his own language.
The valuable neglected for the interesting.
Herdsman neglects his she-goats in favor of wild-goats.
Man leaves farming for fishing.
Better be content with what you have, than try to get more and lose everything.
Wealth and glory sacrificed for freedom and virtue.
Man refuses vast wealth because with it will come covetousness.
King lays aside crown since it brings too many cares.
Prince chooses exile and honor to foul life at his father’s court.
Rich merchant is poorer in happiness than poor man.
Man refuses rich marriage with house filled with dangerous wild animals.
Choices: small inconvenience, large gain.
Bodily member(s) sacrificed to save life.
Beaver sacrifices scrotum to save life.
Inconvenience disregarded when booty is in sight.
Wolf does not mind the dust.
Snake is willing to suffer the indignity of serving frog king as mount because frog king gives him frogs to eat.
Slight inconvenience in weather, large gain.
The widow‘s meal.
Less inconvenience in fighting though tired than in losing all for a little rest.
Priest sells his donkey because worry for its safety distracts him from prayer.
Small inconvenience, large gain--miscellaneous.
Solomon refuses water of immortality for himself when he cannot have it for his possessions also.
Ape throws away nut because of its bitter rind.
No time for minor fights when life is in danger.
Bull refuses to fight goat.
King ridiculed for inventing trifle of musical instrument but praised for constructing a great mosque.
Kind foster-parents chosen rather than cruel parents.
Lamb chooses her foster-mother, the she-goat.
Scarcity of real friends.
“A friend is known in need.”
Socrates builds himself a little house.
Great refuse to associate with lowly.
Boar refuses to fight with lowly ass.
Zeus refuses wedding present from snake.
Prince refuses to play with common children.
Noble poets refuse to associate with truly good poet because of his lowly birth.
Peasant ashamed of being thrown off by ass.
Wolf tries to make friends with lion: killed.
Dolphin and whale scorn crab as peacemaker.
Laurel and olive tree scorn thornbush as umpire in their dispute as to who is most useful.
Mouse on lion’s mane.
Knight disregards insult by servant.
King refuses to quarrel with bird.
Leopard ashamed of having been bitten by lizard.
Rich man refuses to associate with poor sister.
Profitable association of great and lowly.
Prince of democratic tastes chosen.
Unprofitable association of unequals.
Lion licks sick man, who is thereby disgusted.
Marriage with equal or with unequal.
Wife chosen instead of fairy mistress.
Prince prefers first love to princess he later marries.
Unsuccessful marriage of jackals and turtles (different habits).
One‘s own kind preferred to strangers.
Bird refuses to maintain friendship with bird of different habits.
Man prefers to live with ordinary rather than with pious man.
Subordination of weak to strong.
Lion as king makes ass his lieutenant.
Lion makes lame goat his lieutenant.
Stupid fear company of clever.
Jackal realizes that the partridge was too clever for him and leaves.
Weak fear company of strong.
Earthen and brazen pots in river.
Buffalo refuses tiger’s invitation to dinner.
Association of rat with cat ceases as soon as mutual danger has passed.
Association of mouse with cat ceases as soon as mutual danger has passed.
Friendship of snake and frog ceases when snake wants to eat frog.
Association of cow and tiger: tiger eats cow as soon as she is hungry.
Association of tiger and crane.
Association of strong and weak--miscellaneous.
Association of swan and swallow: swan unable to fly away from danger.
Associating with a bad friend is fatal: swan and crow.
Profitable association of young and old.
Old ox yoked with young ox.
Foolish association of young and old.
Foolish youth in love with ugly old mistress.
Foolish marriage of old man and young girl.
Contagiousness of bad company.
Ass buyer returns ass which has associated with lazy companions.
Stork killed along with cranes.
God of wealth in bad company.
Mirror begrimed by snail.
Bad associates bring death to bishop.
Harm of association with flatterers.
Senseless debate of the mutually useful.
The belly and the members.
Tail and head of serpent quarrel as to usefulness.
Fortune, Intellect, Knowledge, and Health dispute as to which is the greatest.
Debate of tongue and other bodily members.
Common wives of man debate as to which has helped him most.
Tobacco, pipe, and match debate usefulness to smoker.
Deer, opossum, and snake each render indispensable aid to man.
Rice, wheat, and dal dispute as to which is the best.
Dispute of hammer and anvil.
Wealth and wisdom dispute as to who is greater.
Elephant and ape debate about superiority.
Unnecessary choices of belief.
Unnecessary choice of gods.
Unnecessary choice of philosophies.
Unnecessary choice of religion.
Father leaves sons three jewels--Christianity, Judaism, Mohammedanism.
Father gives son three rings.
Unnecessary choice: to go uphill or downhill.
Unnecessary choice: praying or reading.
Senseless debates about usefulness.
Pomegranate and apple tree dispute as to which is worth most.
Senseless debate: which is the greater, St. John the Baptist or St. John the Evangelist?
Inflicters rather than receivers of wounds chosen.
King advised to marry maid rather than widow.
Woman refuses second marriage.
Woman refuses second marriage.
Widow refuses second marriage so her brother cannot kill a second husband.
Better to marry ugly than fair wife.
Better to marry a man lacking money than money lacking a man.
Young man advised to choose as wife a girl whose mother was chaste.
to do that which one knows or to learn something.
Enjoyment preferred to wealth.
Three sins of the hermit.
Death preferred above God and Justice.
Tame dog prefers food basin to fleeing hare.
Fox had rather meet one hen than fifty women.
Old sweetheart chosen in preference to new.
Little men preferred to big men.
death and revenge preferred to life.
Monk chooses solitude and loneliness to company and temptation.
Choice of friend over mistress.
Eagle prefers own offspring to changeling.
One should not attempt to change his color.
Negro tries in vain to be washed white.
Animal should not try to change his nature.
Crab comes ashore: killed by fox.
Kite tries to neigh like a horse.
Camel tries in vain to dance.
Ass tries in vain to play lyre.
Wolf tries in vain to be doctor.
Crow tries to imitate partridge‘s walk.
Mouse, bird, and sausage keep house together.
Elephant, giraffe, snake, and ant try keeping house together: requirements different.
Ass tries to get a cricket‘s voice.
Lizard tries to make himself as long as snake.
Fox tries to mask as dove, but loses all thoughts of murder.
Camel and jackal exchange food: camel is led by his good friend to thorny fruit and thorn sticks in his throat.
Frog wants to be shod like a horse.
Jackal accidentally made king but joins other jackals in howling at night.
Snake wants to act as pet like parrot: killed.
Frogs want to collect honey like bees.
One should let well enough alone.
Birds seeking richer lands are nearly all killed.
Barber tries unsuccessfully to become a trader.
One should not be too greedy.
Kite tries to carry off so many partridges that he drops them all.
Wolf tries to eat bowstring.
Greedy man keeps demanding one more thing from complacent man;
Greedy pig looks up into tree for figs.
Greedy man dissatisfied with gold looks for jewels;
Fowler wants two rubies as ransom for a caught goose;
Peacock spends so much time preening for coronation that birds become impatient and make the owl king instead.
Good shepherd shears his sheep; does not skin them.
Intemperate zeal in truth-telling.
Cocks who crow about mistress‘s adultery killed.
Bird warns mistress against committing adultery: gets neck wrung.
Fool given the truth on his back.
Doctor loses a horse for the sake of the truth.
Man asked to tell truth says that his host, his hostess, and the cat have but three eyes between them.
Magpie tells a man that his wife has eaten an eel, which she said was eaten by the otter.
Only youngest son tells king truth when asked where they got their food: banished.
Honest servant tells people that shop does not have many customers: dismissed.
Intemperate pugnacity.
Noblemen who quarreled over a device.
Noblemen being ruined by long lawsuit decide wisely to join their families in marriage and save their fortunes.
Bishop fond of lawsuits is ordered by king to settle them: bishop pleads for a few to be left so that he will have something to live for.
Serpent (weasel) tries to bite a file.
Helmet left for woman to quarrel with.
Brothers compose quarrel and save umpire‘s fee.
Boast at home.
Intemperance in work.
Aesop with the unbent bow.
Ruler interrupts meeting of Senate to amuse his small son.
Intemperance in service.
Intemperance in obedience.
Cum grano salis.
Intemperance in honesty.
St. George teaches the poor man, “Who steals somewhat and lies somewhat will be rich.”
Forget God for five years and you will become wealthy.
Intemperance in undertaking labor.
Monk discouraged by large amount of work to be done persuaded to undertake but a small amount each day.
True penance for even a day is effective.
Intemperance in sacrificing.
Intemperance in pursuit.
Man tracking gorilla sees animal’s strength.
Cow-herd looking for cattle thief recognizes him in the lion.
Intemperance in charity.
Man resuscitates a lion which devours him.
Intemperance in worship.
Intemperance in fasting.
Fool fasts on roof till he becomes so weak he falls off.
Avoid hasty judgment.
When in anger say the alphabet.
King given three wheels to control his anger.
King in anger punishes misdeed on Easter day.
Avoid hasty punishment.
Man has disinterested party punish servant for him lest he himself be unfair in his anger.
Master when angry will not punish servant who has ruined him.
King restrained from hasty judgment by being told story.
Judge not that you be not judged: thus judge upbraided when he is later accused in court and claims mercy.
Answer questions of a fool the next day.
Unpaid servant refuses to blame master: later rewarded.
Wisdom of deliberation in fight.
Bravest know how to wait.
Foolishness of noise-making when enemies overhear.
Wolf as dog‘s guest sings.
Paramour who insists on quarreling with mistress about escape caught by her husband.
Monk’s enemies quarrel and thus save him.
Drones dispute possession of honey.
Kites and crows quarrel over division of wounded fox.
Foolishness of premature coming out of hiding.
Hidden goat discovered by his horn protruding above ground.
Hidden stag discovered when he begins to eat grapevine too soon after hunters have passed.
Caution in eating.
Clever girl refrains from eating figs which would bring on magic sleep.
Wise man before entering a quarrel considers how it will end.
Wise man considers whom he is attacking.
Flea and fever exchange night-lodgings.
Wise fear of the weak for the strong.
Frogs fear increase of sun’s power which will dry up all their puddles.
Frogs fear defeated bull.
Destruction of enemy’s weapons.
The swallow and the hemp-seeds.
Snake gives away magic pills later used to kill him.
Preventing the birth of enemies.
Wise man destroys serpent‘s eggs.
Swallow advises hen against hatching out serpent’s eggs.
Prevention of hostility by inspiring fear in enemy.
Snake complains to Zeus that people step on him.
Uniting against a common enemy.
Two sheep kill a fox who has licked up the blood they have spilled in a fight.
Sheep-dogs stop quarreling to hunt wolf who has raided the flock.
Enemy brothers unite to fight a common enemy.
Prevention of hostilities by agreeing to demands while in danger.
Prevention of hostilities by disarming the suspect.
Dissuasion from suicide.
Crab takes hold of heron‘s neck and fearing attack cuts neck and kills him.
King takes measures against assassination.
King to avoid possible assassination singes his beard rather than have barber shave him.
King to avoid possible assassination has queen’s quarters searched before he enters.
Escaping before enemy can strike.
One bird escapes as hunter bends his bow; other remains and is shot.
Foolishness of surrendering weapons.
Lion suitor allows his teeth to be pulled and his claws to be cut.
Robbers persuaded to give hero sword with which they are afterwards killed.
Care against future tyranny.
Frogs demand a live king.
Kite as king of chickens.
Lion as king of animals reinstated after elephant is tired.
Avoiding places which have been fatal to others.
Fox sees all tracks going into lion‘s den but none coming out.
Avoiding power of future enemy.
Birds flee from cuckoo who, they believe, will later become a hawk.
Disregard advice of your enemy.
Palamides, having injured Ulysses, seeks advice from him.
Bird hears voices from within unhatched eggs and flies away: voices plot to dine on their bird-mother when they are born.
Avoiding enemy’s revenge.
Avoid enemies‘ revenge either by making peace and friendship or by killing them all.
Advice not to rob women while they are alone, for fear of returning husbands’ revenge.
Care against future imprisonment.
Monkeys planning to found a city desist lest with walls up it will be easier to catch them than before.
Inattention to danger.
Throstle giving all attention to sweet fruits is caught by bird catcher.
Man inattentive to the danger of drowning enters water to save treasure and is drowned.
Inattention to warnings.
Frog persists in living in puddle on road.
Swallows warn other birds against roosting in tree with glue.
Man disregards priest‘s warning that he will seduce his wife.
Warnings against certain peoples.
Hector warns Trojans against attacking the stronger Greeks.
Don’t play tricks on Gascons.
Approaching danger too familiarly.
Birds discuss the trap.
Fox jeers at fox-trap.
Avoiding things which are harmful by nature.
Thornbush blamed by fox for wounding him.
Care in selecting the creature to carry one.
Youth trusts self to horse over which he has no control.
Tortoise lets self be carried by eagle.
Crane persuades fish to let him change him from one lake into another: he eats fish.
Practical and impractical defences.
Belling the cat.
Defences by strengthening one’s own weakest spots.
Ears stopped with wax to avoid enchanting song.
Cotton put in ears so as not to hear abusive words.
Defence when one needs it most.
Armor ordered thin in front and thick in back, since it would be most needed in flight.
Defences in and out of season.
Wild-boar sharpens tusks when no enemy is in sight.
Man decides to make himself strong in peaceful times rather than wait until attacked.
Man slays another in order not to be slain himself.
Son slays father in order not to be slain himself.
Youthful fencer yields to infuriated opponent who has picked up a pestle.
Foolishness of king‘s taking a washerman for chief minister;
Alliances which make both parties more vulnerable.
Rat and frog tie paws together to cross marsh.
Jackal and leopard tie tails together for mutual protection.
Foolishness of alliances with the weak.
Foxes desert their allies, the hares, when they foresee defeat by the eagle.
Foolishness of attacking real allies.
Ass turns on his driver who would save him from falling over the precipice.
Tame doves close wild ones in trap and thus help common enemies.
Tame fox helps dogs against wild foxes.
Alliances with the strong.
Fox with lion protector goes hunting alone and is killed.
Foolishness of taking on too strong a partner: crow crowds sparrow out of its nest.
Tortoise joins peacock in dance.
Victorious ally feared by others.
Alliances with the intelligent.
Man, lion, and bear in pit.
Forethought in alliances -- miscellaneous.
Provision for the future.
Planting for the next generation.
King improves kingdom before leaving it to his sons.
Necessity of work.
Dervish who stops work.
King (queen) teaches children to work at all tasks to prepare them for life‘s possible hazards.
Planning for the greater office.
Looking for the keys of the abbey.
“Eat small fish now if you wish larger ones later.”
Safe provision for life not to be lightly surrendered.
Priest must give up his charge or his mistress.
Acquisition of wealth.
Be diligent and spend little: how to become wealthy.
Wealth is most important.
In time of plenty provide for want.
Ant and lazy cricket (grasshopper).
Improvident mouse eats grain stored for famine.
King for a year provides for future.
Wise man stores grain against coming famine.
Industrious ant works always at his harvest to keep it dry.
Food alone keeps off hunger.
City without provisions but with much money starves.
Make use of proper seasons for crops.
Lazy boy vainly asks God of the Seasons to delay the plowing season.
Kindness unwise when it imperils one’s food supply.
Eagle warns shepherds that wolf is eating sheep.
Forethought in provision for clothing.
Do not discard clothing till cold weather is over.
More than one swallow to make a summer.
Build shelter for the whole year.
Bear builds house of wood; fox of ice.
Truth the best policy.
Lady answers queen so straightforwardly she gets light punishment.
In planning future, profit by the past.
Frogs decide not to jump into the well.
Remove obstacles from path.
The only person in the bath.
All aspects of a plan must be foreseen.
The forgotten wind.
Advice after the event valueless.
Doctor gives advice after patient dies.
Beware of following an interested adviser.
Tailless fox tries in vain to induce foxes to cut off tails.
Noseless man persuades fools to cut off noses.
Tailless jackal persuades other jackals to cut off tails.
Crane advises fool to empty reservoir so he can reap all grain.
Fish refuse fox’s invitation to live on dry land and thus escape danger of fishermen.
Old age must be planned for.
Child finds gray hair in wicked father‘s head.
Fourth horse must carry all.
Adulteress prepares for old age.
Leave a loophole for escape.
Priest keeps in container relic which when kissed renders people immune from pestilence.
Mark the way one is going in an unfamiliar country.
Do not work yourself out of employment.
Cat only drives rats away;
Wisdom of concessions to power.
The lion’s share.
Lion divides the booty.
Fox refuses to mediate between lion and lioness.
King honors poet and critic: the first so that he will honor the king;
Ruler angered by evil spoken of him is placated by soft words of speakers.
Prime minister bribes priest to persuade king that ocean of milk he wishes sought for had curdled.
Fox with three hundred fables ready to tell against lion conveniently forgets them.
Flattery of the great.
Imprisoned musician defends himself.
Flatterer always agrees with king even in opposite opinions;
“High-born alone recognizes one of equal rank with himself.”
Flattery of the wicked to escape death at his hands: “This is an offering to my lord Esau from his slave Jacob”.
Dissenting minister to king: “Let the king do as seems good in his eyes”.
Unpleasant truths must be withheld from the great.
Liar rewarded by the apes.
Brother who conforms to naked people’s customs honored.
Muddy bath prepared for blemished king.
Tact in reproving the great.
King brought to sense of duty by feigned conversation of birds.
King living apart from wife brought to sense of duty by philosopher.
King called baker’s son: he has given the poet only loaves of bread.
King brought to sense of duty by woman‘s words.
Woman tactfully restrains amorous king.
A soft answer turneth away wrath.
Man called a rogue by a nobleman makes a joke of the insult.
Physician willing to believe in four persons.
King makes absurd statement about flowers.
With a silent person one is alone.
Care in advising a king.
Yogi advises yogi blood for making king‘s leaky tank hold water: king cuts off yogi’s head.
Keeping on good terms with hostile gods.
Dog asks raven why he sacrifices to Athene, since she hates raven because of his powers of augury.
Man plays fool to protect himself in dealing with king.
Man pretends idiocy so as to avoid compromising himself when summoned to testify by two rival queens before the king.
Man recounts unpleasant happening to king when in good humor and draws laugh;
Dealing with the great--miscellaneous.
The king and the cheap slippers.
Devil decides to leave of own accord.
Vanquished ruler in disguise gets audience with victor.
Mohammed goes to the mountain (tree) when the mountain will not come to him.
Reeds bend before wind (flood).
Ass foolish to kick against the pricks.
Fire burns man who doesn‘t understand it.
Wit interprets unfavorable decision of court as doing him great honor.
Consolation for misfortune found in food.
Consoled by a drop of honey.
Man on sinking ship eats salt.
Mouse (fly) dying in meat tub is happy that he has eaten to satisfaction.
Comfort in the contemplation of impossible pleasure.
Fox stumbles over violin.
Fox about to be hanged asks to be allowed to see geese.
Consolation by thinking of some good aspect of a situation.
“But by a fine fellow!”
Consolation by thinking of the past.
Unsuccessful fishermen console themselves that their earlier high hopes balance up their disappointment.
Mutual and undeserved compliments: donkey to camel, “What a beauty you are”; latter answers, “What a sweet voice you have.”
Consolation by a trifle--miscellaneous.
Doves in net console themselves because they think trapper’s tears are from pity for them.
The fox and the sour grapes.
Fox asking for favor set on by dogs.
Fox in swollen river claims to be swimming to distant town.
Jackal covers up his inability to cross stream by saying he is looking for shallowest part.
Clever jackal covers up his clumsiness in catching cows by saying he was running to and fro because he was looking for the fattest calf.
Dog driven out of dining room claims to be drunk.
Warrior having lost a city claims that he did not wish to sell it for a higher price.
Headless king and tailless tiger, each afraid of other, agree to be friends.
Scorned suitor consoles himself by realization that a wife who did not love him would be constant source of trouble.
Timid animal consoled when he sees others more timid.
More timid than the hare.
Lion comforted for his fear of the cock.
Man with unfaithful wife comforted.
Man with unfaithful wife comforted when he sees the queen‘s unfaithfulness.
Man with unfaithful wife comforted when he sees jealous husband who carefully guards wife cuckolded.
Man whose wife gives him bath only once a week comforted by one who does so once a year.
Poor man consoles self by thinking of misfortunes of rich.
Man compelled to live on peas takes comfort when he sees a man once rich eating the hulls.
Man in cold consoles himself thinking of rich men in hell or prison.
Clever person’s defeat pleases inferior.
Hare upbraided by sparrow for letting self be carried off by eagle rejoices when sparrow is carried off by hawk.
Enemy horses captured by lion join forces and become friends.
Consolation: spiritual recompense for temporal misfortune.
Consolation: priest tells blind man that even flies have eyes but only man has the inner eyes of the soul.
The seven daughters of Humility.
Humility of angels.
Humility one of the qualifications of a prophet.
Judge should possess humility and modesty.
Humility of the wise “Sons of the East”.
Wise man acknowledges his ignorance.
Men not chosen for their ignorance; else he should have reached heaven.
Wise man humble in death.
King orders piece of cloth shown after his death.
King refuses to have fine tomb erected for him since his stay on earth is so unimportant.
Rich man humbled by realization that he cannot take his wealth with him.
King has earthen vessels placed on table among the golden ones.
King shows humility by mingling with common people.
King David dances with common youths before the Ark of the Covenant.
King of humble lineage cannot be flattered.
Abbot to avoid vainglory receives judge in rags.
Opposing wise men humble themselves and become friends.
Empress sews and shows she is not too noble to work.
Noble and ugly holy man embraces man who calls him ugly, saying he loves those who see him as he really is.
Lowly masks as great.
Ass in lion’s skin unmasked when he raises his voice.
Jay in peacock‘s (pigeon’s) skin unmasked.
Crow tries to prophesy like raven: detected by his voice.
Weasel paints self to deceive mice.
Painted jackal admitted neither to the peacocks nor to the jackals.
King of jackals captured because of his large banner.
Lowly animal tries to move among his superiors.
Presumptuous wolf among lions.
Ass follows after lion and is punished.
Dog follows lion.
Ass who has worked with ox thinks himself equal to ox.
Frog heaps abuse on bullock, who scorns him.
Self-deception of the lowly.
Dog proud of his clog.
Bad singer thinks he is talented: driven from theatre.
Bad writer who praises himself reprimanded.
Flute-player thinks song meant for the prince is sung to him.
Ass who carried divine image thinks people bow before him.
Disdain of the wolf for the dog.
Gnats think they have thrown horse down.
Crow thinks harvesters are stealing his grain.
Woman in finery in church thinks people are standing up to see her when they rise at gospel reading.
Spider thinks that it has held back the wind.
Gnats apologize for lighting on bull’s horn.
Raven riding on bull’s horns thinks he has brought bull home.
Crow alighting on falling tree thinks his weight made it fall.
Glowworm thinks he shines like stars.
Fox thinks his elongated shadow at sunrise makes him as large as elephant.
Jackal falls into dye vat, tries to pose as peacock: detected.
Animals each think moon shines for his benefit.
Owl thinks echoes of his hoots are sounds of praise.
Rat imagines himself owner of camel.
Rag accidentally in king’s wardrobe thinks it is a ribbon.
Foolish boast of ancestry by lowly.
Mule as descendant of king‘s war-horse.
Fox claims that certain statues are of his ancestors.
Lowly tries in vain to be greater than he is.
Frog tries in vain to be as big as ox.
Fish swells with pride until it bursts.
Bird tries to puff itself up to look like peacock.
Titmouse ruffles feathers to seem big as a bear.
Servant plays at being emperor.
Page dreams of being king.
Servant asks master for arms of knighthood.
Peasant asks to be knighted.
Old simpleton resolves to become a senator.
Ambitious branch chosen king of trees.
Presumptuous man before the works of Michelangelo says: “I too am a master”.
Mole pretends that he sees, smells, and hears.
Flies try to drink water from elephant‘s ears.
One cock takes glory of another’s valor.
Ass in the potter‘s shop.
Kid perched on house jeers at wolf.
Hare demands equal rights for all animals.
Day after Feast Day disputes importance with Feast Day.

Presumptuous smith chants the Divine Comedy.
Dante beats a mule driver who chants the Divine Comedy.
Presumptuous officials disregarded by council.
Lazy woman resumes her work.
The quarreling sons and the bundle of twigs.
Sons united make living; separated fail.
Preacher teaches beaten Genoese the strength of unity.
Fight of lions and bulls.
Dog leader fears defeat because his forces are of different breeds.
Quails caught in net rise up in a body with net and escape.
Captured elephants pull all at once and escape from net.
United cocks defeat partridge.
Cranes fighting as allies defeat all enemies.
Cats unite in battle against a wolf.
Grain will be cut when farmer attends to it himself.
Stag found by master when overlooked by servants.
Gardener who plants vegetable tends it best.
Gods help those who help themselves.
Impossibility of pleasing everyone.
Weather to please one only.
Miller, his son, and the ass: trying to please everyone.
Death‘s three messengers.
Cranes disregard warnings and are killed.

Man disregards mother‘s warning and is punished.
Man disregards priest’s warning and is punished.
Value depends upon real use.
The cock and the pearl: prefers a single corn to a peck of pearls.
Baldheaded man finds the comb: it is useless.
Foolish dog finds treasure and dies rather than leave it.
Miser‘s treasure stolen.
Cure yourself before doctoring others.
Frog as beauty doctor unable to cure his own ugliness.
Doctor unable to cure himself scorned.
Bald man tries to sell hair restorer.
Pot calls kettle black.
Mother crab blames her children for not walking straight.
Drunk man makes sport of another man for being drunk.
Futility of trying to teach the stupid.
Raven killed by apes who will not receive his teaching that a shining stone is not fire.
Results of labor lost in a moment of procrastination.

Man to be judged by his own qualities, not his clothes.
Guests strike man who tries to interfere in their quarrel.
Rich Brahmin wearing poor clothing is treated as a beggar.
Never use your entire resources.
Man who never does any piece of work so well that he cannot improve it.
Value of silence.
Parson’s apology for not answering challenge: I have never regretted silence but have often regretted speech.
Man does not court ugly woman: she might say yes.
Time renders all things commonplace.
Woman tests enduring power of gossip by having a servant ride through streets on a flayed ass.
Fox is terrified on first seeing lion.
Futility of distant travel.
Man desirous of traveling sent six miles to deliver a letter.
Preciousness of untroubled sleep.
King buys spendthrift‘s bed.
Futility of trying to hide an obvious deed.
Horn will tell the tale.
Money does not always bring happiness.
The happy friar becomes unhappier as he receives ever more and more money.
Possession of gold turns humble servant into arrogant one.
King sees poor man far happier than himself.
Poor man returns to the emperor all save enough for comfort: wealth would take happiness from his simple life.
Ignoring the unpleasant.

When the sweet fails try the bitter.

Creditor: “The destroyed bond was a cubit in size.”
Stone as witness.
“Guilty man‘s stick will grow during night.”
“Thief has the feathers sticking on his head”:
To decide which is master and which servant they are to put heads through window and servant’s head is to be cut off.
Which is man and which demon in man‘s shape?
Accused woman to go three times around building naked: guilty one begins to strip off her clothes.

Pseudo-scientific methods of detecting.
Test of mother by weighing milk.
Love detected by quickening pulse.
Guilt detected by quickening heartbeat.
Adultery detected by spit marks on the wall.
Thief’s corpse carried through street to see who will weep for him.
Mother‘s weeping for thief made to seem natural.
Clever son falls from tree, so mother’s tears over dead body of father being carried through street will seem natural.
Woman breaks milk jars so that weeping for thief will seem natural.
Thief detected by building straw fire so that smoke escapes through thief‘s entrance.
Eaters of stolen food detected.
Eaters of stolen food detected by the giving of an emetic.
Animal thief of eggs detected when he comes to a spring to drink.

Thief detected by his answer to question.

Truth detected by spies listening to reactions of defendants at night.
Washing test: defendants given basin of water.

Man decides to spend 100 florins to become known.
The prodigy’s retort.
Two men meet in narrow passage.
Person asks: ”Whose fool are you?“ Answer: ”I am the Bishop of Durham‘s fool; whose fool are you?“ England: *Baughman.
Why soldier is silent before king: is always so when questioned by stupid person.
The account-book of mistakes.
Safe since no white man is near.
Where you got it last year.
Payers of cash favored.
The one to blow the whistle.
The weighted order-cards.
Unstable security.

Three silly pundits sent to a raja as the two-footed cattle he had demanded.

Letting in the light.

Peasants in city inn order whole portion of mustard.

Peasant surprised that king is not larger than other men.
Countryman misunderstands comforts of city.

Ignorance of dates.
All sins since the birth of Christ.
Family do not realize that Lent has arrived until it is Palm Sunday.

Ignorance of marriage relations.

Bridegroom gets into bed.
Absurd ignorance of sex.
Fool cannot tell sex of nudes, since they have no clothes on.
Foolish girl ignorant of what is happening at her first menses.
Ignorance of reading.
Fool weeps each time he reads a book to see how small letters have become: at school they were big and fat.

Fool thinks that “aforesaid” is a title of honor.

Dungbeetle thought to be bee.
Wolf thought to be colt.
Bear thought to be dog.
Ass thought to be hare.
Earthworm thought to be snake (or other monster).
Other animals thought to be a giant cat.
Rabbit thought to be a cow.
Tiger (lion, etc.) mistaken for domestic animal.
Tiger mistaken for goat.
Fool rides tiger thinking it to be a big male-goat.
Tiger thought to be dog.
Tiger mistaken for ass.
Thief mistakes leopard for calf (ass).
Lion thought to be donkey: drunkard rides it.
Thief thinks lion is horse.
Stupid husband mistakes tiger-cubs for jungle cats despite wife’s judgment.
Other mistaken animals.
Scotsman thinks moose is a mouse, asks what rats look like in this country.
Hunter mistakes louse on his eyelash for game.
Numskull thinks fireflies are mosquitoes carrying lanterns to find victims.
Bull mistaken for horse.
Calf mistaken for colt.
Cat‘s tail mistaken for worm.
Animal thought to be object.
Whale thought to be island.
Turtle thought to be an island.
Serpent is taken for island.
White mare thought to be church.
Glowworm thought to be a fire.
Fish thought to be chewed sugar-cane.
Wolf thought to be log of wood.
Snake thought to be flute.
Snake mistaken for a whip by a blind man.
Living toad or beetles thought to be lost food and therefore eaten by numskulls.
Man mistakes dragon for log, sits on it.
Bear mistaken for a floating log (blanket).
Blind men and elephant.
Fool mistakes dung-beetles for fruit: eats them.
Animal thought to be a person.
Animals mistaken for messengers.
Goose mistaken for a tailor.
Crab mistaken for tailor.
Bear on haywagon (on horse) thought to be the preacher.
The bear mistaken for a saint.
Crab caught on tiger‘s tail thought to be pursuing man.
Deer thought to be man with basket on head.
Bees (wasps) mistaken for Jutlanders, etc.
Dressed up monkey thought to be a nobleman.
Lobsters mistaken for Norwegians.
Bear mistaken for a foreigner.
Foolish wife believes goats’ heads are human heads.
Person thought to be an object.
Small priest covered with large hat thought to be a hat.
Girl mistaken for stone.
Sleeping soldier thought to be recumbent statue in chapel.
Person thought to be animal.
Shepherd taken to be she-ass.
Man taken to be sheep.
One person mistaken for another.
Horsemen thought to be men mounted on cattle.
Other creatures with mistaken identity.
Giant thought to be a hill.
Dead man is thought to be alive.
Dead mistaken for the living.
Fool lays his hand on demon in the dark, believing it is male goat he has come to steal.
Object thought to be animal.
Big tree thought to be snake.
Old sausage (roll) taken for frightening animal.
Object thought to be a turkey.
Bush thought to be elephant.
Island thought to be large dog.
One object thought to be another.
Pumpkin thought to be an ass‘s egg.
Boy thinks terrapin hatches from bedbug eggs.
Potatoes mistaken for “irregular eggs”, or “eggs of the earth.”
Dog mistakes mussel for an egg.
Coins thought to be red beans.
Coins thought to be uncooked cakes.
Culture hero’s pubic hair thought to be bear hair.
Pubic hair of ardent husband‘s wife thought to be calf’s tail by peasant in tree.
Man puts food bowl on head thinking it a helmet.
Fish bones in soup thought to be underdone peas.
Fools think evening star is morning star.
Cotton pods knocked off by bullock thought to be lumps of bullock‘s fat.
Excrements thought to be meat and therefore eaten.
Excrement thought to be berries.
Gun thought to be clarinet: one man blows, another presses the “keys”.
Boot mistaken for an axe-sheath.
Foolish tiger thinks dog’s tail is a gun.
Frog thinks cattle are distant country.
Eight-oared ferry-boat mistaken for an animal which must have long legs to wade the stream.
Objects thought to be the devil.
Steamship thought to be the devil.
Watch mistaken for the devil‘s eye.
Glowing wheel supposed to be the devil.
Things thought to be ghosts.
Robber or dog in church thought to be a ghost.
Cows in church thought to be ghost.
Dropping dough thought to be a ghost.
Sound of water dripping on dinner pail thought to be ghost using pick in mine.
Noise in house thought to be ghost.
Man sleeping in stable (abandoned cabin) thinks entering animals are ghosts: kills them.
Animal with lighted candle thought to be ghost.
Person in white thought to be ghost.
Sleep-walker thought to be a ghost until discovered.
Person in haunted house shoots off all his toes thinking they are ghosts.
Thing thought to be corpse.
Butter cask thought to be a dead man.
Things thought to be spirits.
Laughter of boy thought to be spirits’ laughter.
Animals thought to be the devils or ghosts.
Grasshopper thought to be the devil.
Crab thought to be the devil.
Ass thought to be the devil.
Man sees Hereford cow at night; thinks it is devil, says,
Man addresses colt: “Abide, Satan! I am a righteous man and a psalm singer.”
Cat mistaken for devil.
Fox in coffer thought to be devil.
Black sheep thought to be the devil.
Man thought to be a devil or ghost.
Man costumed as demon thought to be devil; thieves flee.
Woman thought to be devil; thieves flee.
Man mistaken for Famine and Cholera in person.
Priest exorcising demon mistaken for demon and beaten to death.
Man thought to be devil by lion.
Men, on first seeing wives with hair, think they are witches and run away.
Lion thinks man astride him is monster: frightened.
Man reported to be dead so that people flee from him as from a ghost.
Things thought at night to be other frightful object.
Windmill thought to be holy cross (church, God).
Clock ticking thought to be gnawing of mice.
Numskull thinks his shadow is a man pursuing him.
Shadow mistaken for thief: is beaten.
Monkey seeing tiger attack his shadow is frightened so that he falls from tree.
Reflection in water thought to be the original of the thing reflected.
Drinking the moon.
Rescuing the moon.
Diving for cheese.
Wolf tries to drink well dry to get cheese.
Dogs by river try to get food in river by drinking the river dry.
Demon tries to recover object from river by drinking it dry.
Moon‘s reflection thought to be gold in water.
Jackals jump into well after drums and are killed.
Dog drops his meat for the reflection.
Diving for reflected enemy.
Shooting at enemy’s reflection in water.
Man throws stone at own reflection in water.
Frog leaps into water after elephant‘s reflection.
Diving for reflection of beautiful woman.
Woman dives in water three times after reflected image of man peering down from a tree.
Ugly woman sees beautiful woman reflected in water and thinks it is herself.
Ogre sees beautiful woman reflected in water.
Man does not recognize his own reflection in the water.
Simpleton thinks his reflection in jar of melted butter is thief;
Goose dives for star, thinking it a fish.
Fools see bee‘s nest reflected in water: try to carry off the well.
Fool sees golden-crested bird reflected in water.
Diving for reflected fruit.
Elephant frightened at agitated reflection of moon in water.
Picture mistaken for original.
Dove sees painted cups of water and dashes into them.
Mask mistaken for face.
Statue mistaken for living original.
Image in mirror mistaken for picture.
Foolish demon sees his reflection in trickster’s mirror and is convinced he has been captured.
Moonlight thought to be substance.
Men build hedge to keep in the moonlight.
Breath in the cold thought to be tobacco smoke.
Words in a foreign language thought to be insults.
“I don‘t understand.”

Not of legitimate birth.
Doctor’s expressions misunderstood.
Conversation by sign language mutually misunderstood.
Other misunderstandings of words.
Similar sounding words mistaken for each other.
To cover house with straw.
Unusual word misunderstood.
Daughter says “Sobur” (wait) to her father when he asks what to bring from the journey.
Numskull referring to a forgotten name keeps saying “I have lost it.”
A fool given money to buy something to eat; goes around asking for a thing called “something.”
Setting sun mistaken for fire.
Other things with mistaken identities.
Old woman‘s sneeze mistaken for gunfire.
Animal cries misunderstood.
Owl’s hoot misunderstood by lost simpleton.
The old maid answers the owl‘s hoot, saying “Anybody, Lord!” or giving the name of the young man she wants.
Frog’s cries misunderstood.
Turkey‘s gobble misunderstood by man lost in woods.
Rooster’s crow interpreted.
Henpecked husband leaves home.
Other sounds misunderstood.
Seeds rattling in pods thought to be insults.
Rabbits think sound of waves is great danger to them.
Fermenting dough: “Woe to you .
Hissing of fire thought to be noise of cooking muffins.
Noises fire is making misunderstood.
Snoring sounds misunderstood.
Numskull thief thinks snoring sleeper is asking for food.
Cooking processes misunderstood.
Mushrooms shrink in water.
Boiling milk thought to be overflowing.
Numskull thinks his prayers have stopped milk boiling over.
Boiling pumpkin thought to be talking.
Boiling pot on the floor thought to be self-cooking.
Fish dancing about in cooking pot appears to be many.
Handful of black pepper taken into mouth instead of cooking it in food.
Savory tea.
Sheep’s head has eaten dumplings.
All the beans cooked for one meal.
Stupid servant cooks all the rice for one meal.
Numskull thinks boiling pot is threatening him: breaks pot.
Numskull stays till he has finished.
Did the calf eat the man?
Fool thinks gold is being destroyed when snails crawl over it.
Fool thinks belly is speaking to him; stabs himself.
Animal‘s action misunderstood.
Urination of bull thought to be bleeding.
Physical phenomena misunderstood--miscellaneous.
Fools think thorn bush doesn’t sting at night.
Simpleton sleeping in cold room breaks window to let the cold out.
Fool wakes with sleeping mat over head and thinks it is still night.
Swimming (fishing) in the flax-field.
Trying to swim in the mist.
Sweeping with a stick instead of a broom.
Misunderstanding of church customs or ceremonies causes inappropriate action.
Misunderstandings concerning images of Christ.
Christ accused of trying to fool the people.
Christ’s image has broken his arm.
The Lord has departed.
Numskull knocks the figure of Jesus from the ass.
Bishop struck for breaking the peace.
Numskull thinks the extinguishing of lights at the church presages a fight.
Move away from Moslem land so that Allah need not be feared.
Fatal bread.
Other misunderstandings of the communion.
Turkish ambassador misunderstands Christian ceremonies.
Christian laws are profitless, Turkish ambassador says.
The falcon not so good as represented.
The king no priest’s son.
The obedient log.
Numskull throws the dishes out.
Jumping into the river after their comrade.
Numskull thinks the bishop‘s snoring is his death rattle.
Numskull shoots grasshopper which lighted on the shoulder of his friend and kills friend.
Boy strikes at a fly on his sister’s breast: it turns into nipple and girl thinks it due to brother‘s caress.
One man strikes at partridge which has lighted on second man’s head.
Numskulls lose corpse and bury live person instead.
Goat chewing cud angers fool, who thinks goat is mimicking him.
Fool not recognizing coins lying on roadside leaves them.
Man thinks own toe is snake‘s head and cuts it off.
Useless surgical operation from misunderstanding.
Numskull (female devil) thinks her pubic hair has been telling her lies and pulls it out together with the skin.
Fool cannot answer as his mouth is full;
Bird protruding from king’s stomach cut out with swords: king killed.
Child‘s stomach split open to cure him of wandering.
Serfs congratulate their master.
Numskull prepares brother’s wedding (father‘s funeral).
Inappropriate action from misunderstanding--miscellaneous.
Fool believes realistic story.
Story told about a deer: fool starts chase.
Jackdaw tries to swallow sparks from glowworm.
Numskull strikes all matches in order to try them.
Nobody can move it.
Gift to animal or object.
Gifts to frogs.
Numskull throws money to frogs so that they can count it.
Numskull feeds his wheat to frogs.
Numskull throws money to frogs to repay them.

Gifts to birds.
Gift to object.
Fool stops hole with money.

Creaking limbs.

Helping the cuckoo.
Animals or objects kept warm.
Fool makes shoes for animals as well as men, since he expects a cold winter.

Warming the stove with wool.
King orders houses built to keep howling jackals warm in winter.
Relieving the beast of burden.

Objects ascribed human feelings.
Kernel tries to escape death.
Complaint of the porridge pot.
The homesick wave.
Coin weeps.

Men drag carts on to roof to shade it from the sun.

Wants the organ to come and play for her.

Stones thought to reproduce.

Cow (hog) taken to roof to graze.

Fools try to hedge the cuckoo so that they will have summer
Deer belled and enclosed like goats jump fence and escape.

Nest built in tree for fish.
Fish will climb trees like buffaloes.
Absurd ignorance about milking animals.
Fool does not milk cow for a month so that she will give plenty for a feast.

Divided ownership of cow.
Fool asks owner of oxen why he does not milk them since he is not working them.

Cow killed in order to get all the milk at once.

The cat and the candle.

Fisherman fails to make fish dance to his flute.

Numskull tries to shake birds from tree like fruit.
Breeding fine horses from an ass.

Where the ducks ford.
The two extra pounds.
Fool cuts off tails of oxen so that they will look like fine steeds.

Fool believes that he has begot child with his sister by an earbox.

Absurd practices connected with crops.
Numskulls sow cooked grain.
Sowing cheese to bring forth a cow.
Sowing salt to produce salt.
Planting a hog in order to grow pigs.

Sowing needles (like seed).
Harvesting early for half a crop.
Stones watered to make them grow.

A hole to throw the earth in.
