How he looks in his sleep.

Holding in the heat.

As tired as if he had walked.
Drying snow to make salt.
Fire and water mixed to make sacrifice.

Woman runs after guest to tell him he must restore her husband whom he has unintentionally killed.

Simpleton drives goats into a well, because he thinks it would be cooler for them.
Hot sickle put into water to cure its fever.
Substitute for the corpse.

Trying to catch light in a mouse-trap.
The yeast as an afterthought.

Trying to stretch the beam.
Protected by the needle.
The wall accuses the crowbar.

Foolish fight with the sun.

Stupid woman swims on the roof.
Tree pulled down in order to give it water to drink.
Fool tries to purify cotton by burning it (as the goldsmith does with gold).
Numskulls are affected by heat from stove which has no fire in it.
Mouth and ears stopped up lest wisdom escape.
Person does not know himself.
Numskull‘s beard cut off: does not know himself.
Woman’s garments cut off: does not know herself.

Man does not know himself from another identically clad.

Fool does not recognize his own house and family.
His pupils grab a dog‘s tail and think it is their master’s.
Man does not recognize his name when it is called: he is accustomed to hear his nickname.
Numskulls cannot find their own legs.
Numskull asks doctor which leg (own) is hurting him.
Numskull cannot find ass he is sitting on.
Numskull doesn‘t recognize his own horse.

Inability to find object one is carrying.
Man searches for axe which he carries on his shoulder.
Woman cannot find pastry which is sticking to her posterior.
Fools try to fight with man inside of drum who seems to make the noise.
Opium-smoker on journey asks his way about; ends up at his own house.
Counting wrong by not counting oneself.
Numskulls count selves by sticking their noses in the sand.
There are ten horses; then when he is mounted there are only nine.
Culture hero throws coconuts to various islands, but forgets one he stands on: hence none now on that island.
Are there nine or ten geese?
Three girls distressed by seemingly impossible task of going and returning together
The interrupted calculation.
Keeping the measure by stretching out the arms.
Numskulls buy things in common: each pays full price.
Numskulls buy church in common: each pays full price.
Three brothers buy cow for common use;
Actor forgets and speaks in his own person.
In Passion Play the Christ says, “I am thirsty”; the thief on the left speaks up, “I too.”
Fool forgets master’s message.
Fool believes plea of not guilty even though he has seen man injure him.
Law student forgets his speech.
Hero keeps on leading his horse without discovering that it is dead.
Given things for self and relatives, fool forgets to take his own.
Wise man short-sightedly scorned for his advice.
God‘s mercy contrasted with man’s short-sightedness.
Quarrel and fight over details of air-castles.
Man plants hedge: sheep will leave wool on the thorns and bring riches.
To build a palace in the sky: hawk as architect is let fly in the air.
Fools cast lots for royal purple of queen who is still alive.

Toad having found money daydreams and is run over.
Foolish illustration of argument.
Which way the sheep shall return.
Foolish logician upsets ghee in argument.
How was the town burned?
Distress over imagined troubles of unborn child.
Queen grieves herself to death over fate of her children after her death.
Servant plans to deceive his master by refusing to eat.
Foolish waiting.
The hungry fox waits in vain for horse‘s scrotum (lips) to fall off.
The daw waits in vain for the figs to ripen in winter.
Men (animals) wait in vain for nuts to fall from a tree.
Waiting in vain for fruit to fall from a non-fruitbearing tree.

Wolf waits in vain for the nurse to throw away the child.
Dog waits to be hit with meat.

Hare waits in vain for leaves to fall from palm tree.
Hare waits in vain for man’s hand to fall off.
Sacrifice equal to the reward.
Sacrifice of one son to get another.
Three foolish wishes.
Short-sighted wish.

Short-sighted wish: grain to grow without beards.
Short-sighted wish: all he pulls on will follow.
A man without a stomach.
Short-sighted wish: camel wishes a long neck.
Old woman demands something that she would remember all her life: her nose cut off.
Same wishes used wisely and foolishly.
Wise and foolish wish: keep doing all day what you begin.
Wise and foolish wish: help in whatever one is doing.
Twice the wish to the enemy.
The transferred wish.
Transferred wish wisely used as well as unwisely.
Two transferred wishes used unwisely: redeemed by wise use of third.
Woman disdainfully throws away pills;
Wife granted wish for beauty, elopes with prince.
Absurdly modest wish.
Absurdly modest wish: no lights on certain night except in her own house.

Wife wishes to be turned to gold.
Foolish wish: to destroy all flies and spiders.

Foolish bargain: horse for cow, cow for hog, etc.

One-third for the price of one-fourth.

Nose cut off to get it out of the light.
Improving the wife’s face by cutting off her nose.

Taking the short-cut.
One contestant chooses straight path through stones; other circles about and wins.

Stupid giant, seeing how fat he has become, wants to eat himself up.
How to save the rice.
Stupid cowherds apply hot iron to temples of unconscious man to revive him.

Drying snow on the stove.

Monkey jumps into water after a butterfly.
Hedgehog and crab jump from boat after turtle.
Woman tries to climb rope of excrement and urine.

Fool re-enacts the accident.
How was the pigeon killed? Fool aims stone at inquirer saying, “I struck him like this.”

Trickster eats scratch-berries.
Trickster eats medicines that physic him.
Numskulls eat medicine that physics them.
Numskull starves himself.
Fasting the first month.
Numskull brings about his own capture.

Animal caught in animal carcass.

Death through lack of foresight.
The louse invites the flea.
Dogs of wolf color join the wolves.
Bee rests on water lily which closes over it at night and kills it.

Camel and ass together captured because of ass’s singing.
King attempts to visit the spirit world underground and dies in a tunnel.
Foolish interference in quarrel of the strong fatal to the weak.

Jumping into the breeches.

Lacing the shoes.
Short-sighted use of fire.
Burning the temple to attain notoriety.
Fool whose house is burning puts wood on the fire.
Quenching the burning boat.
Carrying the plow horse so as not to tramp up the field.
Numskulls carry one another through mud and the others back in order that not all get dirty.
Sedan-bearers must carry master about searching for dog since they have refused to search.
Short-sightedness in rowing.
Rowers pull in opposite directions.
Rowing in a boat which is tied up.
Carrying load up hill to roll it down.
Short-sighted lover is slow to follow up advantage.
Porridge eaten in different rooms.
The slaughter of the ox.
Short-sightedness in carpentry.
Short-sightedness in boat-building.
Ship built with a wooden saw.
The ogre tars the hero’s boat, thinking to injure him.
Dupe makes boat of mud.
Attempts to make canoe of sand.
Building boat of clay.
Short-sightedness in roofing.
Does not need roof when it is fair; cannot put it on when it rains.
Fool roofs his house on the inside.
Builders throw away beams from the scaffolding until it all falls down.
The axes thrown away.
Bird nest of salt melts away.
Man on camel has doorway broken down so he can ride in.
Short-sightedness in caring for live-stock.
The shepherd who cried “Wolf!” too often.
Shepherd shuts up the lion in the yard with the live-stock.
Wolf almost locked up in the stable by the shepherd.
Wolf locked up with the sheep.
Short-sighted fool loses his food.
Sleeping trickster‘s feast stolen.
Getting a sword to lift the cheese.
The bird boasts about capturing the rabbit.
Deer lost through premature celebration.
Fool kills chickens by throwing them off a balcony against a stone.
Crocodile goes after the second child.
Trickster travels while fish cook: they burn up.
Man saves trouble by milking cow directly into his mouth.
How to remove hairs from salt.
Foolish demands before death.
His last request: a red cap.
Wholesome food for the day of hanging.
Having the head dressed before hanging.
Hang me right away so I can get back to work.
Short-sightedness in dealing with children.
Anticipatory whipping.
Priest beats wife before purchasing food since he wishes her to cook it in particular way.
Scolding the drowning child instead of helping him.
Absent-minded nurse lets child down into well instead of bucket.
Man lets his infant son play in river.
Numskull is sent to fetch children.
Numskull kills his children trying to cure their illness.
Fool lets wine run in the cellar.
Fool tries to dry up spilt wine with meal.
Drinking gruel by making hole in pot.
No room left for the feast.
Master sets servant example by eating rind first: fills up and never reaches the fruit.
Burning up the seal.
A fleeing fox loses an eye in the briars.
Disastrous hesitation.
The dog between the two castles.
Who shall go first?
Bird overcareful about food suitable to its color is killed by eagle.
Two prisoners use up their hour of grace disputing over road to take home.
Princess who is too choosy finally marries an idiot.
Short-sightedness in case of fire.
Whose duty to put out fire?
The polluted clothes.
Dearly bought disgrace.
“If you had hanged me you would have really been in trouble.”
Trickster’s false creations fail him.
The bear riding the horse lets his paws fall on the horse‘s flanks.
The man who wanted to be dead one day.
A fool releases a bear while the master is away.
The messenger without the message.
Message after a week.
Fool has himself buried because he stinks.
Raven steals the robes of Red Willow Men and finds them useless.
People pelt each other with food.
Grain shot down with guns.
Carpe diem.
Bewailing a calamity that has not occurred.
Absurd shortsightedness--miscellaneous.
Alarm sounded foolishly.
Fool rings bell to announce that he has won at chess.
Woman to sound bell for help in childbirth persuaded to sound false alarms: not heeded when help is needed.
Persons build a wheelbarrow too large to come out of shed.
Nine men try to lift bull over the fence.
Short-sighted economy.
Numskull is glad to hurt his feet instead of his shoes.
Differences in animal nature overlooked.
Frogs reprove ass for lamenting when he falls into morass.
Why the sow was muddy.
The murderous master.
Ass brays on hearing a conch shell.
Effects of age and size absurdly applied.
Two fifteen-year old slaves ordered: fool brings one thirty years old.
Priest to have maid at least fifty years old: gets one aged twenty and one aged thirty.
Burial in old grave to deceive angel.
Wooden anchor would hold if it were only large, thinks the fool.
The reef is old, the ship new.
Swift when only a calf.
The Zodiac grows up: the Kid becomes the Goat.
Boat expected to grow into ship.
Peasant no longer wants a horse since the new born foal is so heavy to carry.
Our children know local road; odd that grown stranger does not.
Illogical use of numbers.
Each of two persons wants to sleep in the middle.
A profitable fight: three for one! A priest boasts of his
The seventh cake satisfies.
If the horse can pull one load he can pull two.
Twenty better than ten.
More than twenty commandments.
Selling his half of the house.
Dentist duped to pull out two teeth for one because of the expensiveness.
Man prefers small oysters, since he will get more to the hundred.
Numskull finds that one feather makes a hard pillow, thinks a sackful would be unbearable.
Absurd generalization from a particular incident.
Peas will burn.
Conclusion: youth and age are alike.
Waiting at the well for the thief.
Waiting in the graveyard for the thief.
Waiting for the thief to return for the bolster.
Waiting for the thieves to return for invoice of goods stolen.
Human milk as best diet (for baby).
Man is servant of the animals (for he supplies feed for them).
Men must have been calves once (for they are fond of milk).
Oil is cheap (or spilling oil is good luck).
Fool carries his wife to the remedy instead of the opposite.
Dipping into cold water to cure fever, since hot iron is so cooled.

Dupe persuaded to get into grass in order to learn new dance.
Crocodile hides in strawstack and is burned to death.
Dupe allowed to guard ”king‘s litter“: sticks in mud.
Gun as tobacco pipe.
Deer persuaded to butt head into tree.
Serpent‘s jewel is covered with spiked helmet so that when he tries to recover it he strikes and is spiked to death.
Dupe digs till he dies of exhaustion.
Dupe persuaded to transform self into animal.
Man dupes animals into turning their tongues upside down.
Duck persuades cock to cut off his crest and spurs.
Dupe induced to incriminate himself.
Trickster teaches a dupe a strange language.
The laborer teaches his master birds’ talk.
Teaching Latin.
Peas strewn on stairs so that person will slip.
Fairy induces hero to dive into lake which makes person old.
Dupe tricked into sitting on hot iron.
Fox persuades bear to lie in the haycock and wait for sheep.
Dupe tricked into breaking tabu by lying.
Men tricked into bathing in ”disease-water“.
Dupe sleeps on the ”king‘s bed“: falls into well beneath and dies.
Blind men duped into fighting.
Blind men duped into fighting: money to be divided.
”I don’t believe you have a gold coin.“
Blind men duped into fighting: stolen meat.
Blind men duped into fighting: strings leading to water removed.
Ogres (large animals, sharp-elbowed women) duped into fighting each other.
Enemies duped into fighting each other.

Object thrown into air causes enemies to fight over it.
Bird lighting on the heads of group of men causes them to kill one another with blows on the head.
Undesignated present starts quarrel for its possession.
Liar brings about fight between dupes.
Trickster tells lies to fishes and causes them to fight.
Jackal tells tales so as to get buffalo and tiger to kill each other;
Liar brings enmity between friends.
Trickster attempts to bring friends to fight.
Calumniators try to bring friendly kings to fight, but fail at last.
Woman makes trouble between man and wife: the hair from his beard.
Woman makes trouble between man and wife (to lick husband‘s body).
Woman makes trouble between man and wife: to keep certain rendezvous.
Woman induces men to fight over her and kill each other.
Falsified message brings about a war.
Men disrobe and report they have been attacked: bring about war.
Message falsified to bring about death of lovers.
Dissension aroused in army by casting suspicion on general.

Goddess arouses heroes‘ jealousy and eternal fighting.
Treacherous counselor persuades king’s son to woo his
God persuades hero to substitute a false bride for his father;

Ogre‘s (dwarf’s) beard caught fast.
Dupe caught in crack in ground.
Ogre helps tortoise who snaps jaws to and catches him.
Bending the tree.

Fox rings the bell.

The lover’s gift regained.
Lover’s gift regained: the broken (removed) article.

Through power of saint, man is caused to assume lover’s form and sleep with princess.
Handsome man substituted for ugly as bridegroom: wins bride.
Robber bridegroom.
Penniless bridegroom pretends to wealth.
Penniless wooer: patch of land.
Penniless wooer: money in hand.
Penniless wooer: helpful animal reports master wealthy and thus wins girl for him.
Penniless wooer.
Man wins girl’s love by pretending to wealth and nobility.
Forged credentials used to win girl.
”All of these are mine,“
Slave poses as treasurer‘s son and carries letter purporting to ask for hand of merchant’s daughter in marriage.
Monster disguises and wins girl.
Ugly fish borrows skin of handsome fish for courtship and marriage.
Ogre imposes on widow by assuming form of dead husband.
Marital impostors--miscellaneous.
Husband poses as wife‘s brother.
Parents exchange children.
Son of the king and of the smith exchanged.
Two mothers exchange their children, a boy and a girl.
Queen changes her own ugly twins for slave’s pretty son.
Woman substitutes child for her own and sells it.
The false heir.
Nurse exchanges children so that the preferred child will be assured of wealth.
Man is made to believe that his married daughter has borne a child.
Barren woman pretends to bear child.
Woman pretends to be mother of child chosen to be king.
Midwife takes child and substitutes it for king’s stillborn child.
Queen passes off girl-child as boy by having pandits say raja must not see his son for twelve years.
Barren wife makes child by magic and claims it as her own.
False daughter: accepted as one‘s resurrected child.
Impostors abandon (or kill) their companion and usurp his place.
Impostors throw hero overboard into sea.
Impostor tries to push foster brother into the water and then cuts rope so that he drifts alone out on the sea in boat without oars.
Impostors abandon hero in lower world.
Impostors kill hero.
Impostors throw hero into pit.
Impostors throw hero into prison.
Impostor leaves hero alone on island.
Impostor abandons hero on high hill.
Impostors claim reward (prize) earned by hero.
Impostor forces oath of secrecy.
Impostor forces hero (heroine) to change places with him (her).
Impostor (magician, demon) takes the place of the king.
Impostors steal rescued princess.
Impostors exposed by girl at her wedding.
Impostor claims to be father of princess’s child.
Impostor impersonates dead count.
Rascal pretends to be dead man‘s heir and receives money.
Disguised flayer.
Disguised flayer tightens skin to look beautiful.
Impostors tricked into carrying hero in box.
Impostor demands box in name of king.
Imposition by sham sickness.
Person pretends sickness can be cured only with death (humiliation) of another.
Mother-in-law’s head is shaven, face blackened and she is led around city on ass-back as only cure for malady of daughter-in-law.
Sham warrior.
Boastful fly-killer: ”seven at a blow“.
Boastful elephant killer: killed at one blow.
Runaway cavalry-hero.
Runaway cavalry hero tears out limbs of dead trees.
Sham-warrior intimidates soldiers with his boasting.
Sham-warrior boasts and is employed at palace.
Tiger intimidated by boasting of the sham-warrior.
Boastful coward frightened by conspirators.
Ordinary man assumes high sounding name and challenges enemy chief to single combat.
Sham prince (nobleman).
Brahmin takes shape of a prince.
Servant takes prince‘s horse and clothes and passes self off as prince.
Poor boy said by helpful cat to be dispossessed prince.
Poor boy said by helpful animal to be dispossessed prince (wealthy man) who has lost clothes while swimming (in shipwreck).
Better things at home.
Brothers pose as princes, deeming their parentage not worthy of their merit.
Impostor claims to be earl‘s son in exile.
Adventurer poses as son of dead king.
Wooing emissary poses as king and suitor, but is refused.
Impostor appears with letter authorizing that he be set on the throne.
Thieves set up poor weaver as prince and thus get possession of tribute and gifts.
Sham brave man.
Coward boasts that he has frightened bear away.
Sham rich man.
Helpful cat borrows measure for his master‘s money.
Drunken man by pretending to want to buy an elephant makes king think him rich.
Sham physician.
Sham physician cures people by threatening them with death.
Man undertakes to cure fat abbot of stomach ailment.
Patients frightened from hospital by harsh treatment.
Sham physician pretends to diagnose entirely from urinalysis.
Pepper as universal remedy of sham doctor: accidentally works.
Sham physician predicts the sex of the unborn child.
Sham physician: using the flea powder.
Sham physician: making the girl grow up.
The sham physician and the devil in partnership.
demon kills people so his pupil can resuscitate them and get reward.
Sham physician refuses to take his own medicine: unmasked.
Sham physician gives relative a medical degree.
Ignorant youth buys a medical degree.
Ignorant doctor draws his prescriptions by lot.
Sham physician hands out prescriptions haphazard.
Sham wise man.
Sham wise man gives a purgative and helps find a lost horse.
Sham wise man claims to find stolen goods by incantation.
Sham wise man hides something and is rewarded for finding it.
Sham wise man sees jewel hidden and is rewarded for finding it.
Sham wise man declares who committed the theft: robbers.
Sham wise man does not know where his own house is.
Sham wise man stays alone feigning study.
Sham wise man (girl’s confederate) interprets pretended dream for girl.
Sham wise man pretends knowledge from dream: really overheard conversation.
Sham wise man burns house where he pretends to keep his marvelous books, and is free from being called again.
Sham wise man accidentally predicts weather correctly.
Boy, posing as magician, agitates purported all-knowing pig‘s head in front of his enemies, identifying them as dishonest men.
Sham teacher.
Sham churchman.
Sham parson (priest).
Peasant as priest preaches on the troubles of laymen.
Sham parson repeats same expression over and over or says a few words of Latin.
Parody sermon.
Sham parson: the sawed pulpit.
Sham priest dupes man into believing he can discover treasure.
Sham holy man.
Jackal as sham saint.
Pretender as pope.
Woman in disguise becomes pope.
Devil disguised as monk.
Sham bishop.
Sham abbot.
False prophet.
Mohammed puts seed in his ears and when doves trained to feed there come, he tells people that they bring messages from God.
Sham magician.
False magician exposed by clever girl.
Sham magician promises to induce love by magic.
Master posing as magician plays tricks on his servant.
Sham magician belches fire to frighten dupes.

Sham astrologer.
Sham crystal-gazer.
Alchemist.

Juggler promises to fly from one house to another.

Sham traveler.
Warrior buries oversized armor so as to convince posterity of soldiers’ gigantic size.
Servant poses as master.

Sham deity.
Weaver poses as deity.
Man behind statue (tree) speaks and pretends to be God (spirit).
Husband answers behind the statue when wife wants to know how to fool him.
Trickster hides in hollow tree and eats food he has persuaded his wife to bring to feed a bird.
Man behind the tree threatens his debtor.
Boy behind the tree tells woman about the bad food he gets.
Maid behind statue of Virgin advises the mistress to give the servants better food.
Husband behind saint‘s statue advises wife to spin.
Wife behind tree advises husband against having his wife work.
Husband as God behind the tree forces his wife to confess adultery.
Man as God behind the tree forces the girl to admit having an illegitimate child.
Girl behind the tree advises the unwilling suitor.
Wife behind tree advises the husband about his marital duties.
The man behind the crucifix says ”Good Evening“ to the drunk man, who thinks Christ is speaking to him.
Hidden man behind image gives unwelcome answer to suppliant: image blamed.
Sexton behind crucifix tells old maid she will have no husband;
Sexton behind statue tells old maid praying for a husband to raise her foot to her neck.
Trickster concealed in sacred tree advises that he is to marry the princess.
Trickster in tree advises that tree and fruit belong to him.
Impostor acting as God in tree suspected and tree burned.

Oracular images occupied by spirits or priests who give the answers.
Statue made to raise its arm.
Sham miracle.

Betrayal by a kiss.

Man pretends to kiss relative: bites him instead.

Fox’s tail drops and frightens animals.

Hiding from the strange animal.
Ferocious animal frightened by ass braying.
Devil frightened by threatening to bring mother-in-law.

Parson is tricked into giving up his room.
Tiger frightened away from man‘s tree refuge by man’s stick and rope.
Wife, to drive away parasite priest, tells him husband has gone to get drunk and will kill him with rice mortar on his return.
Ogre frightened at rustling.
Tiger frightened at sound of clashing knives: thinks it is leak in house of which he is afraid.
Bear frightened by wife‘s sneezing.
Wooden image frightens away invaders.
Animals help in military victory.
Sparrows of Cirencester.
Fire tied to foxes’ tails: destroys enemy‘s cities and fields.
Bees thrown into redoubt drive out enemies.
Bees carried in drum attack and defeat attacking army.
Ashes transformed into bees, wasps, scorpions and snakes drive invading army away for hero.
Mice and hogs let loose put elephant cavalry to flight.
Elephant drunk with toddy sent to attack enemy.
Horses frightened by instruments of war are backed into enemy’s ranks.
Birds frighten enemy‘s horses so that they throw their riders down.
Wild horses with bags containing stones tied to their tails, driven into enemy‘s camp to cause stampede.
Horse with basket of powdered peppers sent into hostile camp: enemy overcome.
Hot pepper mixed with flour supplying enemy camp.
Wild fawn sent by saint into hostile army, so that all follow it and leader (enemy of saint) is slain.
Strategy to get into enemy city: huge rat makes a burrow.
Women spread shawls on enemy’s path and entangle them.
Fresh hides spread so that enemy slips and falls.
Treasure cast down crushes besiegers.
Treacherous priests prolong mass to let enemy destroy city.
Women throw ashes in eyes of attacking soldiers, so that they are defeated.
Man blinded by throwing dust in his eyes: he is robbed.
Disguise to enter enemy‘s camp (castle).
Disguise to spy on enemy.
Owner admitted into his own castle, captured in his absence, in guise of a monk.
Disguise as musician to enter enemy’s camp.
Disguise as pilgrim to enter enemy‘s camp (castle).
Disguise as old man to enter enemies’ camp.
Rabbi feigns death to be carried out of the besieged city and to approach enemy.
Weapons disguised permit entry to enemies‘ camp.
Woman disguises as man to enter enemy’s camp.
Disguise in killed enemy’s clothes to enter enemy‘s castle.
Disguise as woman to enter enemy‘s camp (castle).
Disguise as beggar (pauper) to enter enemy‘s camp (castle) or to spy.
Disguise as merchant to enter enemy’s castle.
Disguise as leper to enter enemy‘s camp.
Disguise as carpenter (tradesman) to enter enemy’s camp.
Disguise as juggler to enter enemy‘s camp.
Disguise as churl (bachlach) to enter enemy’s hall.
Capture by hiding warriors in baskets on back of oxen driven into enemy‘s camp on pretence that food is being brought.
Man disguised as animal sent among enemy that first blood be spilled by other side.
Woman saves herself from soldiers by receiving them joyfully rather than fearfully.
Capture of castle by feigning death.
Spies’ false report of enemies‘ weakness brings on premature attack.
Enemy’s ships fired by use of fireship.
Enemies defeated by setting forest afire.
Enemy induced to give up siege.
Enemy induced to give up siege by pretending to have plenty of food.
Enemy induced to surrender city by show of wealth on part of besiegers, who shoot golden apples over walls.
Enemy soldiers persuaded by show of great wealth and generosity of king to desert to his side.
City is falsely promised to enemy.
Trickster admits defeat: enemy and friends invited to fort for ceremony and then attacked.
Besieger scatters beads in protecting hedge: besieged destroy hedge to find beads.
Enemy deceived into overestimating opponents: retreat.
Sound of artillery is simulated to overawe enemy.
Persons run wagon back and forth over a corduroy bridge to simulate sound of artillery.
Sounds of mock battle scare away attacking force.
Sounds of battle in playhouse scare away attacking soldiers.
Sham doctor prescribes medicine for king‘s army;
Enemy induced to give up siege by making it look as if the besieged have got reinforcement.
Military strategy--miscellaneous.
Marauder pretends beggary that king will underestimate his power.
Division of warriors hidden in pit on battlefield.
Largest part of fleet does not emerge until late in battle.
Treacherous king participates in battle only when he sees who is likely to win.
Treacherous ruler of city under siege sends sons to deliver city to enemy.
Postponing of payment asked in order to get time to gather reinforcements.
Besiegers drowned by diversion of river.
Military strategy: city won by turning river from its course through city.
Shammed discussing of peace while getting reinforcements.
Cauldron containing lighted torch brought into enemy‘s camp ostensibly to be used for serving food: torch uncovered as signal for attack.
Fairy mist mistaken for smoke of enemy’s burning ships.
Hero causes confusion in enemy camp in dead of night: army men fall upon one another, convinced the enemy has infiltrated their camp.
Poisoned food sent to enemy camp.
Enemy leaders invited to banquet and poisoned.
Brambles heaped in ford to halt enemies.
Deceiving the higher powers (God, the saints, the gods, fate).
Heaven entered by a trick.
Heaven entered by trick: permission to pick up cap.
Heaven entered by trick: demanding back the charity gift.
Heaven entered by trick: ”wishing sack“ thrown in.
Heaven entered by trick: sitting on Peter‘s chair.
Heaven entered by trick: slipping in along with holy person.
Heaven entered by trick: angel tricked by drink into telling woman how to enter.
Gods tricked into help in escaping one’s fate.
Ingeniously worded boon asked of God combines riches,
Dog sent ahead so as to avoid seeing husband transformed.
Enemies reconciled by gifts which the one‘s son tells are sent from the other.
The returned box on the ears.
Entering a garden by swimming down a stream that flows into it.
Temporary advantage gained by pretending to yield in a combat.
Person allowed to win first game so that he will play for higher stakes.
Warrior consents to flee for the sake of future victory.
Enemies deceived through shammed flight.
Ammunition saved till enemy has used his.
Hero sleeps during the first part of battle and emerges only later.
Ruler diverts attention from misgovernment by beginning a war.
One animal injures another by deception.
Bird plucks another bird’s feathers out.

Tying cat to balky horse’s tail to make him move.
Man tricked to be one‘s sworn brother in order to secure his help against his mother.
Demon enters person and refuses to leave until wishes have been fulfilled.
Attempt to kill by throwing knife.

Local Legends

Man sells soul to devil.

Formulas for selling one‘s soul to
Man sells soul to devil for visit home in boat that sails through sky.
Man sells soul to devil for magic power to escape capture.
Man sells soul to devil for devil’s doing one specific job.
Person sells soul to devil in return for the granting of wishes.
Devil agrees to help man with robberies.
Devil as helper of robber refuses to let women‘s ornaments be stolen.
Devil at gallows repudiates his bargain with robber.
Devil as substitute for day laborer at mowing.
Devil to help gambler in exchange for one task yearly.
With his whole heart: devil carries off judge.
Devil bargains to help man become priest.
The devil helps man study for priesthood.
The devil makes the herdsman’s son a priest in return for a whistle.
Devil bargains to help man win woman.
Servant makes pact with devil denying Christ to secure nobleman’s daughter.
Contract with the devil destroyed.
Pacts with the devil, sealed in blood, made ineffective by a saint.
Other devil contract motifs.
Bargain with the devil for an heir.
Devil fetches man contracted to him.
Devil appears in great storm, takes away soul of person contracted to him.
Devil flays corpse of person contracted to him.
Man contracted to the devil responds to call by voice: ”The hour has come but not the man.“
Devil carries off hunt-loving priest.
Body of devil’s disciple is removed from coffin by devil.
Devil puts body of convert on a sea monster which takes it away.
Familiars guard and protect those who have pact with the devil.
Familiar devours whoever does not keep pact with devil.
Beheading bargain.
Hag offers to run race with men on condition that the one left behind shall be beheaded.
Man umpires dispute in exchange for guarantee of safety.
Blind promise (rash boon).
Person who never refuses a request.
Eyes exchanged for food.
Horse, clothes, and members of rider‘s body exchanged for food.
In return for magic shirt from girl hero is to stay in Ireland for three years.
Free keep in inn exchanged for good story.
Prince to give up life in exchange for learning a secret.
Three deformed witches invited to wedding in exchange for help.
Life spared in return for life-long service.
Life spared in return for poetic mead.
Life spared for bringing a dreaded enemy without weapon.
Life bought for gold.
Life bought with promise of reparations and healing of enemy.
Bargain: woman rides naked through streets to obtain freedom for citizens.
Peace bought for husband.
Bargain to save face.
Opponents agree not to fight and are thus undefeated.
Bargain: to divide all winnings.
Dividing the winnings: half of the bride demanded.
Dividing the winnings: presents (favors) from man‘s own wife.
Bargains and promises between mortals and supernatural beings.
Mortal fosters fairy child to prevent destruction of crops.

Series of lucky successes.
Husband (lover) arrives home just as wife (mistress) is to marry another.
Return home to one‘s own funeral.
Wife finds lost husband just as he is to marry another.
Ruler makes ready to abandon barren wife and marry another.
Incest accidentally averted.
Man about to consummate marriage with own mother; accidentally prevented.
Man in love with his own sister accidentally learns her identity.
Son returns on day his mother is to be married to another (though her husband still lives).
Prophecy of future greatness fulfilled when hero returns home unknown.
Stranger accidentally chosen king.
Naked soldier becomes general.
Fool passes as wise man by remaining silent.
Hero’s (heroine‘s) identity established as he (she) is on the point of being executed.
Hero unwittingly helps fee’s sons: rewarded.
What is in the dish: “Poor Crab”.
Doctor know-all accidentally saves raja.
Objects accidentally picked up used to overawe ogress.
Numskull’s outcry overawes tiger who is carrying him on his back.
Hero attempting to escape from tiger plays music and tiger follows.
Stupid man grabs tiger in the dark, ties it up, and saddles it, believing it to be a horse.
Person reported lost joins unwittingly in search for himself.
Missing girl reveals identity and saves man condemned for kidnapping her.
Man sent away from battlefield to deliver message the only survivor of battle.
Apparently dead woman revives as she is being prepared for burial.
Apparently dead woman revives when dropped.
Passengers on a boat are terrorized by a cutthroat.
Fugitive in tree urinates from fright: pursuers think it rain and leave.
Man falls out of tree and frightens tiger away.
Grinding stones carried by men seeking refuge in tree-top fall, killing their enemies below.
Hawk carries off necklace from bathing queen and drops it by lucky girl, who gets reward.
Other lucky accidents.
Father and brother accidentally return home just as they are most needed in fight.
King‘s son comes home just at his father’s funeral, when the heritage has to be divided.
Companions arrive as hero is about to be killed.
Orphan gets wife because swollen creek prevents marriage to someone else.
Boy while cutting trees comes to one which happens to be bound up with the life of an ogre.
Overheard wish is realized.
King (prince) accidentally finds maiden and marries her.
King (prince) finds maiden in woods (tree) and marries her.
Hero finds maiden in (magic) castle.
Hero finds maiden in (magic) garden.
Prince sees maiden at church and is enamored.
Lovers meet at temple.
Prince (king) finds girl floating on water in basket: marries her.
Prince sees heroine at ball and is enamored.
Prince first sees heroine as she comes forth from her hiding-box.
Princess concealed in trunk and sent to beggar, who marries her.
King marries girl who finds lost object of his.
Princess catches raja‘s golden bird; he trails it to her palace.
King marries girl who finds his lost ring.
Lovers first see each other on shores of lake.
Hero finds maiden at fountain (well, river).
Lover sees beloved first while she is bathing.
Man stumbles on bathing maiden.
Accidental meeting with the son of the only person who can overcome curse on hero.

Girl sees man as he lies sleeping by wayside.

Joseph and his brethren.

Kings chosen by lot.
Winner of contest to be king.

King chosen by contest.
The one of two giant brothers who performs the greatest feat and procures the wildest dog elected as king.
The one of two giant brothers who gets the most skillful princess elected as king.
Owner of magic object chosen as king.
King chosen on basis of strength and exploits.
He who can open palace door to be king.
Amasser of largest fortune to be king.

Character of kings.
Hunting a madness of kings.
Injustice deadliest of monarch’s sins.
Tyrannical king.
Usurper imposes burdensome taxes.
King who intends rape killed.
Good king never retreats in battle.
Dead king carried into battle in his war-chariot.
King in battle hides in ditch, with earth piled around him.
Just king brings good fortune upon people.
Four duties of king to subjects: devotion, protection of subjects, justice, and increase of his kingdom.
Clever king knows everything in advance.
King banishes nobleman whose castle he wants.
Nobility of character a mark of kings.
King is superior to all in strength, beauty, largeness, etc., and usually has victory.
Uxorious king neglects duties.
King avenges lack of homage.

Particular practices of kings.
Prisoners released as celebration of king’s success.
King will not permit a one-eyed man in his presence.
King playing chess when important news arrives.
King orders all gold brought to him.

King asks all newcomers what they can do and expects a prompt answer.
Law that nobody may give the king bad tidings.
Kings have seat on hills.
King angry at hero who rides straight into the castle without permission.

King’s stronghold on island.

King does not eat much during years of famine in order not to forget the hungry.
Adventures of kings.

King himself works at brick building so that subjects cannot complain of enforced labor.

Hospitality for (three) years.
Salt of hospitality.
Guest given refuge.
Nobleman forces escaping prisoner to accept his hospitality.
Guest in disguise or under false name.
Refugee entertained in holy place (church, monastery, etc.).
Hosts refrain from telling guest of death in household.
Host greets guest with gifts.
Host treats guest with food and everything possible.
Guests fed before being questioned.
Guests‘ life inviolable.
Host surrenders his wife to his guest.
Guest begets son with his host’s daughter.
If host does not return, the house shall belong to the guest.
Barmecide feast.
Strangers entertained by family to whose hitching-ring they happen to tie their horses.
Refusal to receive preferred help until series of stories has been told.
Selfish guest expels host.
Shabby hospitality forces guests to leave.
Guests accused of greediness.
Poor person makes great effort to entertain guests.
Poor host and his wife kill themselves because they are unable to entertain expected guests.
Wife scolds husband‘s hospitality, as he really has nothing to give.
Poor peasant closes the eyes in order not to see guest eat: later suicide.
King demands work, sport or entertainment from winter guests.
Christian king makes baptism a condition for hospitality during the winter.
Sitting in a circle of feasts.
Druids as teachers.
Teacher dies of pride over success of pupil.
Student enters competition with his master.
Student challenges his fencing master.
Teacher threatens to curse pupils if they disobey.
Faithful servant.
Faithful servant dies for his master.
Faithful servant kills his master‘s murderer and is killed in turn.
Faithful servant wants to follow on dangerous quest, where he alone is killed.
Hero’s charioteer faithful to master till death.
Faithful servant remains at home and fights for exiled hero.
Faithful servant sacrifices sons to save life of king.
Faithful nurse tries to save tyrant’s daughter by exposing her own in her place.
Abandoned maiden helped by her faithful nurse.
Faithful servant dies avenging master‘s death.
Captain will not betray king’s secret.
Faithful servant undergoes torture for sake of his master.
Crow lets itself be caught so as to save king of crows.
Faithful servant entrusted with care and education of crown prince.
Faithless servant.
Faithless men-servants corrupt the maids in the household.
Servant planning to possess his master’s goods.
Master demands that servant tell him of his faults as well as of his good qualities.
Son insists on following father‘s trade.
Peasant.
Peasant refuses to sell possessions to king.
Peasant and his wife in hut near castle as contrasts to king and queen.
Peasant is cutting wood in front of his house as guests arrive.
Wounded hero finds shelter and is cured in peasant‘s house.
Hero stays overnight in peasant’s house, to which he accidentally comes, and where he gets advice and direction.
Shepherd.
Shepherd as hero.
Life of shepherd proper preparation for ruler.
Swineherd.
Hero as rabbit-herd.
Ferryman.
Eternal ferryman.
Ferryman puts oar into king’s hand and he must remain ferryman.
Hunter.
Collier.
Hero as collier.
Judge.
Jackals as judges.
Lawyer.
Lawyers punished in hell.
Tongue of dead lawyer found to be lacking.
Physician.
Physician hides eyes as he passes graveyard.
Doctor who can cure can also poison.
Physician killed for fatal diagnosis.
“Skillful” physician compelled to help carry away the bier of his dead patient.
Fairy as physician.
Female physician.
Scribe.
Scribe who cannot read his own writing.
Clergy.
In fear of clerics pagans flee into fairy mounds.
Parson (priest).
First of animals and fruits belong to priest.
Hermit.
Monks.
Untrained monk becomes skillful wright (smith) through power of saint.
Monks as converted druids.
Woman disguised as monk enters monastery.
Druid (poet, learned man).
Druid inspires great respect and fear.
Person assailed by druid loses treasure.
Women druids.
Simon Magus as druid.
Druid performs sacrifices.
Druids perform human sacrifice.
Druids as priests.
Druidic (heathen) baptism.

Advice (instruction) from druid.
Poet (druid) as satirist.
Fear of druidic lampoon as activating power.
Druid as physician.
Wounded soldiers healed by bath in pool of milk through power of druid.
Druid as judge.
Poet.
Extemporaneous composition by poets.
Extensive repertory of poets.
Difficult language used by poets.
Poets and fools closely allied.
Blind poets.
Women poets.
Bard.
Poet‘s rod.

Excessive demands of poets.
Rivaling poets.
Druids as rath-builders.
Druids (poets) boil spell.
Musician.
Harper.
Miscellaneous learned professions.
Astronomers.
Financiers and merchants.
Merchant.
Merchants as spreaders of news.
Usurer.
Wealthy usurer prays that the sons of the rich will become mad.
Usurer stops lending money.
Tailor.
Tailor occupies God’s throne for a day.
Tailoring only trade devil cannot learn.
Tailor punished in hell.
Busy tailor asks soldier to mount watch in his place.
Baker.
Baker and devil walking together.
Miller.
Water-miller.
Why millers are thieves.
Cabinet-maker.
Brave soldier and timid cabinet-maker as companions.
Weaver.
Why weavers are the most unhappy of men.
Why weavers have patience.
Barber.
Barbers as bunglers of plans.
Barbers cunning and greedy.

Hatter.

Woodsman.
Other artisans.
Printer.
Soldier.
Soldier who has had both hands severed fights with his teeth until he is killed.
Soldier dies happy on learning of enemy‘s rout.
Soldier is ordered to set fire to enemy’s armada.
Woman instructs in art of arms.
Actor.
Actors banished along with vagabonds.

Twelve robbers.

Painter (artist).

Juggler (conjurer).
Philosopher.
Treacherous philosophers.
Criminal allowed to choose his method of execution.
Chooses to die of old age.
Man condemned to lose his eye is allowed to choose the instrument.
Condemned woman may be freed by marrying a rogue.
Release from execution at a woman’s request (by marriage to her).
Criminal may fight against odds rather than be judicially executed.
Pardoning of criminal comes too late.
Youngest of judges first to give decision.
Crime less serious if committed at request of a lady.
Cities of refuge.
Complacent judge disregards the confession.
Laws.
Lex talionis.
A nose for a nose.
Bringing suit in law courts.
Foreigner may not bring suit.
Madman may not bring suit.
Fool not to be punished for his crime.
Slave may not bring suit.
Legal security.
Poet may not act as security.
Foreigner may not act as security.
Contracts.
“It is a debt if it is promised.”
Contract made by madman void.
Contract made by woman without her husband void.
He nearest to blood of slain man must avenge his death.
Legal principles.
“To every cow belongs its calf,”
“To every son belongs his mother”

Law-making.
Heptads.
Laws made at yearly feast.
Laws made at feast every seven years.
Miscellaneous legal customs.
Army.
Band of professional warriors.
Army of young men.
Soldiers chained (tied) together to prevent flight from battle.
Clerics exempted from military service.
Hero drives retreating warriors back into battle.
Boy corps.
Law requiring military service of women revoked through influence of saint.
Conflicts with the recruiting officers.
Retainers not required to go to battle under overlord except for pay.
Only 700 subjects of under-king required to serve under overlord on any one hosting.
“Battle seeds” (semen bellicosum).
Battle formations.
Battle-pen.
Superior troops distributed throughout army to prevent their soldierly qualities from being too obvious.
Phalanx.
Roof of shields.
War-machines.
Haircut as preparation for war.
Weapons.
Poisoned weapons.
Battle-cairn.
Defeat in battle.
Submission indicated by defeated lying with conqueror‘s sword between teeth.
Corpses of dead foes dismembered.
Heads of fallen enemies piled up after battle.
“Publication of slaying.”
Jawbone cut from slain opponent.
Gate of captured town (castle) to be widened until overlord’s spear can pass through crosswise.
Challenge to battle.
Challenge by turning left side of shield toward enemy.
Challenge to battle by hurling javelin skyward.
Military customs.
Warrior not entitled to ransom if captured without arms.
Pledge with enemy to be kept.
Stones erected where enemy falls.
Customs concerning single combat.
First to reach field of combat has choice of weapons.
Warrior who begins combat has right to desist.
Choice of weapons alternates each succeeding day.
“Men‘s truth” (fir fer).
Warrior engaged in combat with one-armed opponent allows one hand to be bound to his side.
Warrior disgraced by slaying of those under his protection.
Warrior dies with face toward foe.
Divorce given to wives before leaving for battle.
Tournaments.
King is persuaded to rescind ban on tournaments.
Tournament: to avenge death of king.
Women meet when bathing.
Trumpet blown before house of one sentenced to death.
Charon‘s fee: putting coin in dead person’s mouth to pay for ferry across Styx.
Newcomers forced to pass the night with ruling princess.
People weep when child is born.
Bridle goes with horse when horse is bought.
Servant must keep horns and hide of his cattle that are slain.
Fasting (as a means of distraint).
Fasting against God.
Clerics fast against God for revelation.
Fasting against the Devil.
Fasting against fairies.
Fasting against saints.
Fasting by saints causes tree worshipped by pagans to fall.
Fasting to enforce saint‘s dues.
Calves not let to cows during fast.
Strangers to be given precedence over man at home.
Customs concerning recognition of rank.
Couches provided for men of high rank.
Cuts of meat distributed according to rank.
“The champion’s portion.”
Rank among children recognized by quality of appointments and food.
Color worn signifies rank.
Precedence shown by position of shield (flag).
Long hair prized by Irish heroes.
Young not to precede old.
Feasts.
Customs connected with eating and food.
Feast (hospitality) endures for three days and three nights.
Feast (hospitality) endures for seven days and seven nights.
Injured husband will not kill a naked man.
Only the brave to wear beards.
With only opponent’s arms.
Hero unwilling to answer questions before he is dressed.
Customs concerning bells.
Bells hung at every corner of ship.
Bells on horse‘s mane.

Hut for invalid to prevent noxious odor.
boasting of sexual prowess.
Woman veils self as expression of surprise.
Pulling a man’s beard as an insult.
Fur made of beards of conquered kings.
Cutting off a man’s (woman‘s) hair as an insult.

lighting lamp with king’s moustache.
Footwashing as sign of reconciliation.
Old person commits suicide when strength fails.
Touching head as sign of acceptance of bargain.
Feet (legs) seized in supplication.
Customs connected with dueling.
Duel: shooting and catching arrows in turn.
Pulling out hair as sign of grief.
Tearing garments as sign of grief.
Mourning customs.
Greeting customs.
Greeting in God‘s name.
Voyagers have right to ask landsman first question.
Patriotism.
Wolves of his own country dearer than dogs of another.
Mother of invalided soldier says of his limping: “Every step will remind you of your virtue.”
Common citizen saves the honor of his country.
Scipio plunges into burning pit to save Rome from destruction.
Roman undertakes to kill Hannibal.
National unity preserved by expulsion of all foreign elements.
Aristotle rises from sick bed to rush into battle for his country.
Aversion to burial in foreign soil.
Patriotism: king learning that nation will triumph whose king dies in battle, allows self to be killed.
Particular nations (races).
Jews.
Diseases (plague) invoked to combat overpopulation.
Hospitality rewarded--opposite punished.
Gods (saints) in disguise reward hospitality and punish inhospitality.
Kind and unkind.
Moderate request rewarded; immoderate punished.

Lion divides slain bullock.
Humble rewarded, haughty punished.

Good thoughts rewarded, bad punished.
Foolishness brings a man to death, quiet calm to fortune.
Deity descends and makes king and wronged subject change places.

Man frees slave (incognito prince):

Saint gives a man all his credit for good deeds so that the man may go to heaven.

Reward for giving counsel.
Reward for almsgiving.

One rupee given away for charity incidentally brings back ten rupees.

any boon that may be asked.

Immunity from death by violence as reward.
Descendants of man who endured pain without crying out not to meet violent deaths.

admission to heaven.

release from hell.
Release from hell as reward for repentance.
Saint‘s requests for releasing souls from hell.
Saint requests that on Doomsday he may bring out of hell, for every hair of his chasuble, seven condemned souls.
God grants to saint the boon that no one buried in any of his churches shall go to hell.
God grants to saint the boon that two persons are to be rescued from hell by him “to the end of the world.”
Saint requests that any person appealing to him at death shall escape hell.
holy person to be buried and resurrected in one place.
God gives “peace and favorable weather” in consequence of enactment of good law.
Family line of good man rewarded.
Child given as reward for prayer.
Crowns and palms as reward.
Blessings.
Criminal intent punished.
Murder punished.
God revenges murder after thirty years.
Enormity of kin murder.
Emperor punished for his many murders.

Woman murders son’s wives.
Suicide punished.
Killing an animal revenged.

God punishes murder of brother-in-law by having murderer’s male heirs die.

Punishment for murder of co-wife.
Punishment for wholesale massacre of tribe.

Theft punished.
Theft from dwarf (witch) revenged.
Grave-robbing punished.
Punishment of theft: origin of sweating.
Stolen animal’s meat impossible to cook.
Abduction punished.
Cannibalism punished.
Treason punished.
Devil plagues impious people.
Devil takes shape of old woman to punish impious nuns.
Personal offences against gods punished.
Discourtesy to god punished.
Discourtesy to messengers of the Gods punished.
Punishment for opposition to Christ at crucifixion.
Blasphemy punished.
Seaman who defies God shipwrecked.
Dam builder remarks that God Almighty could not sweep completed dam away.
Man vows to recover loose boat or go to hell trying.
Party of horsemen detained by bad weather vow to reach town whether God will or no.
Disobedience to God punished.
Lack of trust in God punished.
Doubt of veracity of goddess‘ statement punished.
Theft from water-deity punished.
Punishment for desecration of holy places (images, etc.)
Stone in church sheds blood to foretell coming plunder of church.
Miraculous flow of blood from desecrated building or object.
Punishment for desecration of host.
Renegade priest punished by death for allowing heathen to defile the host.
Punishment for heaping indignities upon crucifix.
Foul portrayal of Jesus on the Cross brings punishment to the artist and the man responsible.
Magic storm as punishment for profaning of temple.
Punishment for desecrating church (shrine, idol).
Stones fall in churchyard, punish desecrators of church.
Magic storm as punishment for desecrating of temple.
Bold woman who danced naked in church is stricken with leprosy.
Thieves who attempt to steal from churches or shrines are miraculously rendered powerless to get out, and walk in a circle.
Desecrated church burned by burning straw carried by sparrow.
Hand stuck for beating an idol.
Punishment for desecration of holy temple utensils.
Punishment for neglect of services to gods (God).
Neglect to pray punished.
Neglect to thank gods punished.
Neglect to sacrifice punished.
Neglect to hear confessional punished.
Priest joins devils after death because he lets woman die without confession.
Neglect to attend church punished.
Failure to observe holiness of Sabbath punished.
Punishment for neglect of mass.
Virgin Mary appears to lady who neglected to hear mass.
Failure to do penance punished.
Neglect to fast punished.
Neglect to fast punished by sight of dragon ready to carry man off to hell.
Musician flogged for eating a kid on Friday (day of fast).
Neglect to study scriptures punished.
Neglect to study Tora punished.
Failure to circumcise child punished.
Failure to finish period of mourning punished.
Neglect of clerical duties punished.
Monk neglecting to prostrate self at canonical hours expelled from monastery by saint and dies on seventh day.
Punishment (fine) for not giving benediction on finished work.
Punishment for failure to give customary offering to gods.
Punishment for betraying confessional.
Punishment for scoffing at religious teachings.
Heresy punished.
Punishment for denying pagan gods.
Punishment for doubting Buddha‘s religion.
Punishment for leaving holy orders.
Hermit leaving his cell to become robber falls and breaks his neck.
Mutinous clerics expelled in shapes of swine.
Punishment for opposition to holy person.
Punishment for slaying king under holy protection.
Punishment for imprisoning person under holy protection.
Punishment for looking at saint’s corpse.
Saint (hero) drives chariot over person who displeases him.

Punishment for change of religious faith.

Punishment for leaving Palestine.
Punishment for yielding to temptation by the devil.
Cursing punished.
Man put in moon for cursing God.
Punishment for deceiving (divine) emperor.
Idolatry punished.
Adultery punished.
Desire to commit adultery punished.
Lover refuses to take back unfaithful paramour.
Incest punished.
Cohabitation of godfather and godmother punished.
Father-daughter incest punished.
Punishment for man who makes advances to sister-in-law.
Father of incestuous children punished.
Incontinence punished--miscellaneous.
Punishment by extinction of royal line for sexual incontinence.
Suspected incontinence unjustly punished.
Prostitution punished.
Harlot punished by being burned (in hell).
Punishment for forcing a girl to become prostitute.
Seduction punished.
Attempted seduction punished.
Punishment for taking concubine.
Punishment for taking heathen wives.
Punishment for consorting with one of lower class.
Tiger instead of girl in box tears lecherous teacher to pieces.
Punishment for ravisher.
Ravisher is forced to marry girl and then is executed.
Punishment for attempted rape.
Knight who ravished nun captured when she miraculously appears before him on his horse and holds reins until he is taken.
Prostitute with venereal disease sent to lecherous king.
Punishment for refusal to marry after girl is pregnant.
Mortal‘s attempt to defile goddess punished.
Goddess killed for infidelity with mortal.
Punishment for desertion of fairy mistress.
Punishment for banishing wife at wish of paramour.
Punishment for refusal to have children.
Punishment for abortion.
Punishment for breaking betrothal.
Wife stealing punished with death.
Sodomy punished.
Sodomy punished by death.
Sodomist rebuked by youth.
Bestiality punished.
Homosexuality punished.
Girl punished for becoming pregnant.
Punishment of woman who prefers mortal lover to gods.
Punishment for clandestine lover of princess.
Refusal of conjugal relations punished.
Treachery punished.
Intended treachery punished.
Treacherous wife punished.
Treacherous wife abandoned by lover for fear of treachery.
Impostor punished.
Lying (perjury) punished.
Death as punishment for perjury.
False judging punished.
Bribed false judge punished.
Unjust judges punished in hell.
Punishment for (undeserved) satire.
Blotches on face of satirist (judge) as punishment for wrongful satire (judgment).
Judge must yield bench to son because he had made a false judgment.
Punishment for undeserved curse.
Punishment for breaking promise.
Man promises more to church than he can possibly provide: punished.
Hypocrisy punished.
Devil comes for hypocrite.
Flattery punished.
Debtor punished.
Debtor deprived of burial.
Devil condemns rich man who does not repent until ready to die.
Woman on visit to world of dead may not return until she pays debt to dead.
Avarice punished.
Devil carries off rich man.
Devil carries off rich man at death.
Avaricious man has neck broken when top of his treasure chest falls on him.
Avaricious miser tries to eat his adored money and chokes to death.
Avaricious woman and her gold consumed by hell’s fires which burn in her grave.
Usury punished.
Devil comes for usurer.
Dead usurer fed molten silver by devil.
Usurer refused burial.
Usurer punished in hell.
Church built by usurer’s money made to collapse by devil.
Swindler punished.
Devils carry away stones of church built with ill-gotten money.
Devil suffocates swindling merchant.
Use of false weights and measures punished.
Remover of landmarks punished.
Stinginess punished.
Covetousness punished.
Ingratitude punished.
Ungrateful children punished.
Devils carry off girl who abuses her mother.
Girl cruel to her mother is slain by God.
Ungrateful ruler is deposed.
Woman eats flesh and leaves cat only bones of fish cat has caught for them.
Ungrateful king raises old woman‘s rent; miraculous punishment.
Irreverent young people punished by outraged old man.
Reproach concerning physical deformity (blemish) punished.
Cruelty punished.
Cruelty to animals punished.
Punishment for cutting off bird’s tongue.
Man slits tongue of magpie so that it can learn to speak.
Punishment for breaking bird’s nest.
Boy reaches into bird‘s nest for pigeon’s eggs.
Cruelty to sick persons punished.
Cruel mutilation punished.
Slave-driving punished.
Uncharitableness punished.
Uncharitableness to holy person punished.
Priest will not bury dead unless paid in advance.
Refusal to grant request punished.
Punishment for mockery.
Hard-heartedness punished.
St. Peter’s mother dropped from heaven because of hardheartedness.
Punishment of hard-hearted masters in other world.
Inhospitality punished.
Inhospitality to saint (god) punished.
Inhospitality to orphans punished.
Abuse of hospitality punished.
Monkey destroys nest of bird who has made sport of him.
Injustice punished.
Sack of flour pushed down on peasant who accuses his wife of theft from it.
Slander punished.
Jealousy punished.
Envy punished.
Envy punished: the found purse.
Scolding punished.
War-making punished.
Quarrelsomeness punished.
Fault-finding punished.
Punishment for finding fault with God‘s works in heaven.
Devil carries off fault-finding people.
Punishment for finding fault with God’s forgiveness of sin.
Fault-finding with God‘s handling of weather.
Bad temper punished.
Scandal-mongering punished.
Laziness punished.
Women who will not sew are cast from community.
Dirtiness punished.
Unthriftiness punished.
Disobedience punished.
Impudence punished.
Discourtesy punished.
Pride punished.
Devil torments old man who has laid aside his humility.
Vanity punished.
Woman‘s vain display punished.
Devil impersonates woman’s maid at her toilette.
Vain woman has her cheeks miraculously burned.
Husband rubs off paint from wife‘s cheeks.
Husband puts soot on wife’s cheeks to discourage her from using paint.
Vain woman wears corset so tight that it stifles her to death.
Clothes-proud woman trips over long skirt.
Jackal demands to be praised as god: runs with pack of hounds.
Boldness punished.
“God has no use for me, and the devil will not take me.”
Immoderate request punished.
Request for immortality punished by transformation into tree.
The devil‘s likeness.
Curiosity punished.
Inquisitiveness punished.
Punishment for gambling.
Captured animals avenge themselves.
Dancing punished.
Devil punishes girl who loves to dance.
Drunken dancers punished.
Jesting punished.
Devil carries off jester.
Freemasonry punished.
Freemasons forced to dance till they sweat blood.
Punishment for singing worldly songs.
Prince of devils gives up seat to man who goes to hell for singing worldly songs.
Punishment of evil magician who has caused plague.
Evil speech punished.
Punishment for talking too much.
Gossiping punished.
Uxoriousness punished.
Disrespect punished.
Chain of punishments.
Punishment of children for parents‘ offenses.
Punishment not meted out to persons below twenty years.
Punishment comes in seventh generation.
Death as punishment.
Husband kills returning adulteress.
Adulterer killed.
Man (fairy) kills wife‘s lover.
Faithless wife (mistress) seized by husband’s (lover‘s) poet, who leaps to death with her in his arms.
Death for repeated adultery.
Husband kills wife and paramour.
Punishment: winning as wife and then killing.
Undesired suitor hiding under girl’s bed is killed.
Undesired suitor killed asleep in his tent.
Death of father (son, etc.) as punishment.
Death as punishment for treachery.
Man killed at once for treacherously slaying overlord.
Woman who disrobes to attract attention of hostile fighter killed.
Hero kills mutilators of girl.
Death as punishment for murder.
Death as punishment for ravisher.
A man in every house in the land killed as punishment for abduction by their king.
Death as punishment for reproach concerning physical deformity (blemish).
Death as punishment for impudence.
Man killed because of scornful singing.
Death as punishment for desecration of holy places (images, etc.).
Desecrating a sanctuary (saint’s house) by murder punished.
Hanging as punishment for stealing from a church.
Maidens slain in revenge for deaths of young men.
Death as punishment for thievery.
Charge of theft avenged by assault.
Death as punishment for spying on uncanny persons.
Death as punishment for dropping on emperor’s coat.
Punishment: millstone dropped on guilty person.
Punishment: hanging.
Threat of hanging.
Hanging as punishment for theft.
Hanging as punishment for adultery.

Punishment: burning alive.
Burning as punishment for uxoricide.

Demons burn heretics at stake.

Punishment: boiling in oil (lead, tar).

Punishment: imprisonment in white-hot iron house.
Punishment: burning and scattering ashes.
Punishment: crushing in rice mill and scattering ashes.
Punishment: dancing to death in red-hot shoes.
Punishment: king hung between two fires.
Woman cast on husband‘s funeral pyre as punishment.
Punishment: being eaten by animals.
Punishment: being eaten by demon.
Punishment: being eaten by dogs.
Punishment: transformation to deer which is devoured by dogs.
Punishment: tying man to horses and setting vicious hounds after him.
Mice devour hard-hearted man.
Punishment: man eaten by worms (snake).
Cobras placed in boxes and given to cruel parents, so that they are bitten.
Punishment: being fed to lions (wild beasts).
Punishment: being devoured by tiger.
Bears devour the wicked.
Wolves kill person for quenching holy fire.
Wolves and birds eat bodies of slayers of poet.
Heretic preaching against God’s creation worried to death by fly.
Punishment: being eaten by fish.
Punishment: drawing asunder by horses.

Punishment: dragging to death tied to horns of a bull.

Punishment: being gored to death by elephant.
Punishment: dropping and dashing to pieces.
Murderess forced to leap from cliff.
Traitor thrown into pit so that he sticks to the waist and is then chased out of the country.

Husband substitutes leaky vessel so that his wife and paramour are drowned.

Spitting in face as punishment.

Exposing mistress‘s person (excepting face) to her husband (paramour’s friends).

The Eaten Heart.
Man sends his daughter the heart of her lover.
Adulteress made to drink from paramour’s skull.

Punishment: eating ashes instead of food.
Punishment: eating ashes (coal) mixed with food.
Princess (queen) compelled to keep an inn.

Princess serves as menial.
Second wife (slave) must serve as menial.

Queen made to scare crows away in fields.
Punishment: man must do women‘s work.
Princess must sell goods on market as punishment.

Husband fondles second wife in presence of first as punishment for adultery.
Noble person must live in hovel.
Princess married to lowly hero must live in slave quarters.

Indignity to corpse as punishment.

Line of kingship taken from king who defies saint.

Removal from priesthood as punishment.
Punishment: unseemly exposure of body.
Lazy wife taken naked in bundle of straw to a wedding.
Beard shaved as punishment for murder.
Moustache pulled out as punishment.
Other humiliating punishments.
Humiliating kiss as punishment.
Humiliation through kissing a leper as punishment.

Debtor clerics forbidden churchly offices.
Penance for three years and a half for eating horseflesh.
Humiliating marriage as punishment.
Humiliating penance: king to rub nose five times on red hot griddle.
Unremitting torture as punishment.
Punishment of Sisyphus.
Punishment of Tantalus.
When hungry man tries to gather fruit it flies out of his reach.
Punishment: delicious food always fills with maggots just as man is about to eat it.
Punishment of Loki.
Punishment of Prometheus.
Punishment of Ixion.
Punishment of Io.
Unremittent thirst as punishment.
Salt food without drink as punishment for man who accepts Christianity.
Ceaseless humming (singing) as punishment for immoderate request.
Spirit in hell must bathe people endlessly.
Wandering as a punishment.
The Wandering Jew.
Punishment: wandering till iron shoes are worn out.
Tribe’s long wandering in wilderness as punishment.
Wandering after death as punishment.
Skull of suicide must roll in dust until it has saved a life.
Punishment: carrying corpse of murdered man.
Punishment: carrying corpse of murdered man until stone as long as murdered man is found.
Punishment: carrying corpse of murdered man until another can be induced to take it.
Punishment: performing impossible task.
Performing impossible task as punishment for murder.
Punishment: filling leaky vessels with water from a bottomless jar.
Punishment: binding together sand and string.
Punishment: ridding country of pests.
Substitutions for penances.
Murderer does penance.
Robber does penance.
Life-long penance for brother-sister marriage.
King who loved to give death sentence accepts penance of always postponing sentence until thirty days period of examination has passed.
Penance in wilderness as punishment for men who left holy orders to marry.
Warrior retires to a cloister which he later defends against robbers.
Tedious penances.
Doing penance till green leaves grow on a dry branch.
Penance: crawling on knees and watering a dry staff until it blooms.
Penance: carrying water in mouth from a distance and watering dry staff until it blooms.
Penance: carrying bag of stones (one for each murder) on the back until it falls off.
Penance: carrying iron hoop on head until it falls off.
Penance: pasturing black sheep until they become white.
Penance: ferryman setting people over a stream until relieved by another.
Penance: holding midnight mass until someone will make responses.
Penance to be done until seven spires of Benares are reduced to powder and rebuilt.
Self-torture as penance.
Self-crucifixion as penance.
Penance: killing oneself with wooden knife.
Penance: creeping naked through thorns.
Penance: pilgrimage with hands and loins weighted with iron.
Penance: iron band forged round a man’s waist.
Penance: hanging for a thousand years head downward over a fire of chaff.
Penance: wearing friar‘s cord about bare skin.
Penance: man wears huge serpent coiled around him in lieu of clothing.
Humiliating penances.
Penance: crawling to Rome on knees.
Penance: crawling to grave on knees.
Penance: walking on all-fours like beast.
Penance: eating food offered to dogs.
Penance: living under stairs as mendicant.
Penance: planting garden and offering free hospitality to all.
Penance: slain cats, dogs, etc. to be hung up and covered with grain by man who has killed them.

Penance: performing all services asked for by anyone.

Penance: keeping self suspended on two iron hooks placed under armpits.

Wife refuses to become unfaithful although she knows her husband to be so.
s naivitй proves her fidelity.
Wife hides husband’s unfaithfulness from emperor and even shelters his mistress.

The faithless widow.

Faithless widow ready to marry messenger who brings news of husband‘s death.
Faithless widow offers city to killer of her husband if he will marry her.
Faithless widow’s heartlessness repels the new suitor.
Faithless widow marries slayer of husband.
Woman deserts husband for unworthy lover.
Woman consorts with leper.
Adulteress chooses loathly paramour.
Adulteress poisons husband in order to be with swineherd.
Woman enamored of repulsive and abusive lover.
Faithless wife pays her paramour for enjoying herself with him.
Wronged wife goes to wronged husband.
Husband transforms himself to test his wife‘s faithfulness.
Woman enamored of an unknown knight in a tournament loses interest when she finds that it is her husband.
Old man married to young, unfaithful wife.
Adulteress on her death-bed reveals the illegitimacy of her children.
Series of husbands try in vain to control adulteress.
Fight between husband and lover for kingdom and wife.
Woman reveals whereabouts of husband to enemy in revenge for desertion.
Woman reveals whereabouts of husband to hungry bear in revenge for desertion.
Man unfaithful even on wedding night.
Object stolen (left) as token that infidelity has been discovered.
Substituted sword.
Faithlessness in marriage--miscellaneous.
Adulterous wife convicted commits suicide.
Husband and wife (king and queen) each unfaithful to other.
The shrewish wife.
Man ejected from heaven for folly of marrying twice.
Christ, not having married, knew nothing about suffering.
Man reprimanded by judge for marrying several times.
Avoiding the shrewish wife.
Belfagor.
Devil flees shrewish wife and enters body of a duke.
Late husband chooses to remain in Purgatory rather than to return to his shrewish wife.
Husband chooses to go to hell rather than join shrewish wife in heaven.
Man in hell declares that life there is much better than on earth with his wife.
Man had rather remain transformed to mule than to live with his shrewish wife.
Man forces devil to take back the shrewish wife.
Minstrel throws wife into sea: her tongue the heaviest thing on board.
Thief overhears and oversees quarrel of two jealous wives.
Taming the shrew.
Shrew tamed by setting another shrew against her.
Husband dons armor and forces the household to shout: “Long live the Master!” Takes off his breeches and dares his wife to put them on.
Wife becomes obedient on seeing husband slay a recalcitrant horse.
Husband tries to reform wife by killing a recalcitrant horse in her presence.
The wicked queen reformed.
Shrewish wife driven from home but when in danger, runs to husband and receives protection.
St. Peter’s wife meets him with a broom handle.
Socrates and Zanthippe: “After thunder rain”.
Strength in words, in herbs, and in stones.
The browbeaten husband from under the table: “The man always has a man‘s heart.”
Husband will not search for shrewish wife who has run away from him.
Shrewish wife gives husband heating every morning.
Husband consoled by seeing woman even more shrewish than his wife.
Wife beats her husband and eats up everything he earns.
Fakir thankful for shrewish wife: she is a thorn in his flesh and warns him from neglecting the ways of righteousness.
The overbearing wife.
Unsuccessful search for man who can rule his wife.
Cock shows browbeaten husband how to rule his wife.
King sees how male stork kills his unfaithful wife.
Monkey (jackal, etc.) shows husband how to rule his wife.
King tells jackal his statistics are wrong since there are more men than women.
Wife threatens husband with death if he will not tell secrets.
Prize for husband who rules his wife.
Man claims prize (boots) as ruler of his house, but is afraid to carry the boots lest he soil his clean shirt and anger his wife.
Men rulers in their house asked to sing.
Wife threatens suicide if she does not have her own way.
Vexed woman brings pot down on husband’s head in presence of guest.
The nagging wife.
Nagging wife drives husband to prepare for suicide.
Woman advised that nagging will never make a husband virtuous.
Saint composes hymn to free himself from the mala vita in which he lives with his wife.
The disobedient wife.
The husband shows his wife poison to avoid: she takes it and dies.
Husband forbids wife to ride on the dog: she immediately does so and is bitten.
Man with obedient wife looks young; with disobedient, old.
Man forbids wife to open chest.
Husband warns wife not to enter empty furnace.
Disobedient wife punished.
Wife refuses to bring husband warm water: is beaten.
The obstinate wife or husband.
The obstinate wife: cutting with knife or scissors.

The obstinate wife: the third egg.
The obstinate wife: insists on eating three of the five eggs.
The dish which the husband detests and the wife keeps serving him.
Obstinate wife refuses to take cover off boiling kettle.
Man warns his wife that he has dreamed that she is attacked by a wolf.
The quarrelsome wife or husband.
Quarrel between husband and wife explained by their having been previously a tiger and a dog.
Quarrelsome wife conquered by silent husband.
Medicine against quarrelling: the wife must take one dose and keep it in her mouth for ten minutes as soon as her husband is angry.
Quarrelsome wife reproved by a good whipping.
Jealous wife or husband.
Heavenly maidens are not jealous.
Woman jealous of a fair maid in her house.
King’s wives jealous of his attention to pet animal.
Jealousy of rival wives.
Wife exposes bald head of second wife to disgrace her.

Decision not to punish a jealous husband: he already suffers enough.

Jealous husband kills nightingale which his wife gets up to hear.
Woman‘s scented hair attracts deer: husband jealous.
Jealous king causes massacre of handsome young captives.
Husband’s unjust jealousy forces wife to commit adultery.
Wife repays husband’s supposed adultery by doing likewise.
Jealous husband objects to wife‘s enjoyment of intercourse: thinks she has had previous experience.
Jealous husband spends all his earnings as skillful smith
Trickster sends jealous wife after husband: steals food.
Jealous wife ties husband to her so that he cannot get away to meet another woman.
The curious wife.
The curious wife: wait and see.
