Girl betrays pregnancy by dropping milk on brother.
Jewess must entreat Virgin before she can bear her child.
Place and conditions of childbirth.
Birth of child in forest.
Child born of woman abandoned in pit.
Child born to an apparently dead mother in her grave.
Blind wives fall into a pool where they give birth to children.
Children born in dungeon.
Child born in tree.
Child born in stable.
Child born during snowstorm.
Noise of battle precipitates birth.
Child born on flagstone.
Woman bears twins at end of footrace (with king‘s horses).
Child born on beach.
Twins born in tent; mother abducted.
Boy is born in a wrapping of fine cloth.
Precautions at childbirth.
Avoidance of evil spirits at childbirth.
All locks in house to be shot during childbirth.
Knots to be untied at childbirth.
Knife (other sharp instrument) as childbirth precaution.
Accompaniments of childbirth.
Couvade.
Husband goes into seclusion at wife’s pregnancy.
Couvade imposed on man during wife‘s menstruation.
Pains of woman in childbirth repeated in person of the man.
Calamities at birth of hero.
King leaves bell with his wife for her to ring so he will know when her child is born.
Parturition.
Childbirth assisted by magic.
Husband acts as midwife when no woman is available.
Birth of holy person painless.
Childbirth assisted by angel.
While saint‘s mother was giving birth to the child, she grasps a stout rod which roots and becomes a sturdy tree.
Childbirth assisted by sacred stone.
Birth through the mother’s side.
Child removed from body of dead mother.
Child born of dead mother in grave.
Twins freed from dead mother’s body as body rots.
Cesarean operation upon a woman at childbirth as a custom.
Piglings cut from bodies of sows and reared.
Extraordinarily long labor at childbirth.
Prolonged labor: woman has childbirth pains for 100 days but is not delivered.
After-birth (placenta) becomes a demon.
Hero is born by splitting mother‘s womb.
Child helps mother in severing his navel string.
Precocious infant.
Child born full (nearly) grown.
Child stronger than mother on day of birth.
Child speaks at birth.
Child two months old speaks.
Child speaks prematurely on first birthday.
Infant born blind immediately drowns self.
Infant saint rebukes mother’s impiety.
Child born with all his teeth.
Child born with hairy mane.
Newborn child kisses dying mother.
Precocious hero leaves cradle to go to war.
Child stands (walks) at birth.
Child born circumcised.
Multiple births.
Many children at a birth.
Four children at a birth.
Six children at a birth.
Seven children at a birth.
King and queen have seven sons, all named Maine.
King has six (seven) sons, all named Lugaid.
Nine children at a birth.
Five children at a birth for four successive years.
Forty sons born in one day.
Extraordinary number of children in family.
King with fifty sons (daughters).
King with 60,000 sons.
Multiple birth as result of relations with several men.
Woman ravished by three brothers bears triplets.
Triplets killed by tribe at birth.
Extraordinary number of animals at birth.
Four calves to one cow at a birth.
Extraordinarily frequent childbirth.
Woman bears child every month.
Child born each day for seven days.
Birth of twins.
Birth of twins an indication of unfaithfulness in wife.
Twins born one with ear of other in mouth.
Immediately after birth of twins one puts the other in his mouth:
Last born twin conceived first.
Motifs associated with the placenta.
Spirits make child from placenta.
Childbirth--miscellaneous motifs.
Co-operative birth.
Boy cut in two: each half becomes a boy.
Birth trees.
Birth with veil brings luck.
New-born child reincarnation of recently deceased person.
Where children come from.
Children brought by the stork.
Newborn boy placed in the lap of bathing queen by vulture.
Children brought by midwife.
Children said to come from underworld.
Children said to come from a well.
Children said to come from cauliflower.
Children said to come from stones.
Simultaneous births.
Simultaneous birth of (domestic) animal and child.
Hero born in hour of Christ’s Nativity.
Woman strives to delay birth until auspicious day.
Child with several mothers.
Barrenness or impotence induced by magic.
Magic remedies for barrenness or impotence.
Magic potion as remedy for impotence.
Milk of hornless, single-colored cow drunk by man to make wife fruitful.
Unlucky for a woman to look on the face of a childless person.
Milk suddenly appears in woman’s dry breast.
Milk medicine fills woman’s breasts with milk.
Sign hung out informing brothers whether mother has borne boy or girl.
Naming of children.
Angel names child.
Children named by numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.).
Ambitions of father transferred to child at moment of conception.
Infant bathed in milk.
Weapons and horses procured for boy at his birth.
Divine nurse.
Suckling of children.
Child nourished by sucking its own fingers.
Child nourished by sucking thumb of a god.
Child miraculously suckled by his father.
Witch (fairy) suckles child.
Children magically prevented from suckling.
Child miraculously suckled by saint.
Saint has two paps--a pap with milk and a pap with honey: with these he suckles two infants.
Saint feeds children by cutting off cow‘s teats and pouring milk into them.
Children miraculously suckled by angel.
Milk magically appears in woman’s breast so as to nourish orphan.
Abandoned child saved by seagulls; milk furnished by doe; angel brings bell as drinking utensil.
One woman suckles many babies.
Dead mother‘s breasts furnish sufficient nourishment for her baby during two years.
Man suckled by dog (wolf): called Mac Con (Son of Dog).
Girl suckled by wolf has nail “like a wolf’s nail.”
Saint suckled by wolf.
Child nourished by sucking the eyeballs of snake-mother (frog-mother) who left it.
Child born of slain mother cares for itself during infancy.
Diabolical child kills his wet-nurses.
Supernatural growth.
Precocious speech.
Women old from their birth.
Precocious wisdom.
Precocious boy supports his widowed mother and himself by use of his wits.
Precocious young child demands weapons.
Boy reared in ignorance of the world.
Future hero as child isolated from world kills increasingly larger game with superior weapons.
Hero learns his name at time of first adventure.
Orphan inquires about parents.
Illegitimate child of nun.
Mother of illegitimate child given as pledge for his crime.
Test of legitimacy of children: exposure to asps.
Child betrays his own illegitimacy.
Paramour leaves token with girl to give their son.
Sword left for posthumous son to kill father’s murderer.
“Keep it if it is a girl; send it to me if it is a boy.”
“Kill it if it is a girl.”
Father orders the mother to send the expected illegitimate boy to him when he can perform certain feats.
Hero leaves bedmate keys to treasure chamber for the son she is supposed to bear.
Illegitimate child taunted by playmates.
Child cries because his father is unknown.
Illegal to care for illegitimate child.
Adoption by suckling.
Adopted child reproaches his foster mother and is returned to his real mother.
Rich but stingy couple adopt young man as their son: everybody is happy.
Adopted child deserted when own child is born to couple.
Real mother preferred to foster mothers.
Children prefer foster mother.
Childless couple adopt animal as substitute for child.
Childless woman adopts a serpent (transformed man).
Substitute for a child.
Adopted child identical with real child reared with him.
Each likes his own children best.
Animals ridicule foolish pride of owl in the beauty of his son‘s really hideous feet.
Hero a posthumous son.
Devil substitutes himself for new-born child.
Twins.
Twin adventurers.
Hostile twins.
Twins who look exactly alike.
as twins are reared one born earlier becomes continually weaker, the other stronger.
Quadruplet heroes.
Triplets (as heroes).
Children sleep in village dormitory.
Small trespasses punished; large crimes condoned.
Ass punished for stealing mouthful of grass; lion and wolf forgiven for eating sheep.
Animals confess sins to one another: fox and wolf forgive each other; punish ass.
Animals confess sins to lion holding court.
Penitent in confession worries about little sins and belittles the big ones.
He who steals much called king; he who steals little called robber.
Wolf punished for theft; kings honored.
Largest burdens laid on smallest asses: best offices to most ignorant men.
Unworthy rewarded instead of the worthy.
Fool laughs at the absurdities he sees about him.
Dwarf king (fairy) laughs at the absurdities he sees about him.
Philosopher laughs at the vanities and sins of the world.
The fathers have eaten sour grapes and the children‘s teeth are set on edge.
Justice depends on the point of view.
Hen complains that man eats her, but she eats ant.
A gift of property silences criticism.
Man complains of injustice of gods‘ wrecking ship because of one man’s sin.
Wolf objects to lion stealing sheep from him although he has himself stolen it.
Judge reduces penalty when accused is his own son.
Theft to avoid starvation forgiven.
Swallow killed in court house by snake laments injustice in house of justice.
Wolf unjustly accuses lamb and eats him.
Cat unjustly accuses cock and eats him.
Crow exercises rights of strong over dove who cannot defend self.
Smallness of offense no excuse when hunter prepares to kill lark.
Cock killed by his captors in spite of his plea of usefulness to man.
Nobleman murders one of the people.
Nobleman who kills one of the people is brought to justice only after long delay.
Rich man (king) seizes poor widow’s (nun‘s) cow.
King seizes old woman’s cow.
King seizes poor man‘s lamb.
Nobles ruin peasant’s (widow‘s) crops with impunity.
Lion cub killed by bull gives lioness no right to complain.
Wolf as commander orders all booty divided, but keeps his own.
Ruler exiles subject for trivial remark.
Ruler forces bishop to ordain ignorant priest.
Praise what your master likes and scorn what he dislikes.
Dividing after God‘s fashion: little to poor, much to rich.
Priest has no friends until he becomes bishop: then they flock to him.
Wealth is relative: beggar with horse, wife, or dog considered rich by poorer beggar.
Grass serves as pleasant couch for poor.
Every man has his price.
Every woman has her price.
Bid raised for queen’s favors until she hesitates.
Jester takes cow and tells king people have plenty of milk, for “he who is warm thinks everyone else is.”
Optimist becomes pessimist when his money is stolen.
Man so constantly enriched by God that he cannot give all his goods to the poor.
Great possessions bring great risks.
Dove‘s pride in her large brood linked with fear for their loss.
King in exile neglected, but courted when he regains throne.
Price of object depends on where it is on sale.
Many books do not make a scholar.
Many books do not make a scholar: youth tricks mother by carrying many books.
Beard on she-goats do not make a male.
Big voice: little creature.
Mountain in labor brings forth a mouse.
The skeleton in the closet.
Apparently happy woman discloses the skeleton of her slain paramour.
Hypocrite is acclaimed as saint after his death.
Man rejects bride because she seems immature.
Other ways in which appearances deceive.
Revelations of a satyr.
At a funeral of a child a satyr reveals that the real father (officiating priest) sings while the cuckold weeps.
At a hanging the witnesses are bigger thieves than the culprit.
Peasant wishes to exchange places with monks.
Handsome exterior does not indicate beautiful soul.
An ugly face does not mean an ugly soul.
Stories to show that one’s name does not alter his condition.
Like parent, like child.
Crab walks backward: learned from his parents.
Hind, like his mother, flees before the hounds.
Farmer‘s son and noble’s reared in country.
Alleged son of king proved to be bastard when he displays habits of his true father.
Father, like son, acts foolishly at king‘s court.
Butcher’s son becomes cruel and atrocious ruler.
Dungbeetle prefers his dunghill to all other smells.
Beetles treated with as much honor as oxen will not learn to act as oxen.
Hog goes to bath but wallows in the mud.
Scorpion, in spite of himself, stings the turtle carrying him across the stream.
Wolf loses interest in the sermon when he sees a flock of sheep.
Heron (crane) loses interest in heaven if there are no snails.
Dog allowed to warm self in house begins to bark.
Fawn, in spite of his fine horns, runs from the dog.
Tiger son of human mother scratches her and licks her blood.
Tiger father of human child licks its blood.
Nature will show itself--miscellaneous.
Thieving nature of the fox will show itself.
Prostitute will deceive new lover as always.
Washerman as minister thinks of washing and fails the king.
Newly rich cannot resist call for distribution of food to beggars.
Familiarity takes away fear.
Fox finally converses with lion whom he had feared at first.
Men at first frightened at camel take him into their service.
Man soon learns to stand the smells of the tannery.
Farmer prefers stable smells to flowers.
Knight doesn’t want to go to heaven if there are no hunting dogs there.
Longing for accustomed food and living.
At feast cat chooses rat meat; other animals cannot eat it.
Shepherd in king‘s palace sickens for country air.
Former slave sickens for accustomed food.
Peasant girl married to king longs for peasant ways of eating.
Peasants fed white bread demand the rye bread to which they are accustomed.
Fisher and hunter exchange catches for variety: soon return to original food.
Dissatisfied workmen exchange work: still more dissatisfied.
Beasts and fishes exchange places: fatal to both.
Mill horse when taken to war keeps going in a circle, as he has learned in the mill.
Habit of dishonesty (thievery) cannot be broken.
Dishonest silversmith restless until silver ornament is mixed with alloy.
Thieves cannot quit plundering.
Power of habit--miscellaneous.
Habitual food and drink continued even when it is harmful.
Conservatism defies reason.
Conservative but absurd way of slaughtering hog stubbornly kept.
Enmity between fisherman and dweller on the river.
Ox likes loving strokes of man; flea fears them.
Collier and fuller cannot live together: one makes things clean, the other soils them.
Nightingale cannot lodge with birds whose nest is made of manure.
Royalty unable to endure coarse entertainment.
Coarse food, etc., sends adulterous king back to his wife.
Animals try unsuccessfully to exchange food.
Good weather for one is foul for another.
Bird wants sunshine, worm clouds.
What is one man‘s food is another man’s poison--miscellaneous.
Lions despise what asses admire (braying).
Ass indifferent to enemy‘s approach: he could be no more miserable than now.
Eagle killed with arrow made with his own feather.
Tree cut down with axe for which it has furnished a handle.
Blind man crosses a narrow bridge which his guide is afraid to attempt.
Two blind men succeed in fooling each other about their blindness.
Futile attempt to explain to a blind man meaning of “white”.
Man unable to persuade wife to confess misdeed to priest succeeds when he makes her drunk.
No great knights now because no great kings.
To have good servants a lord must be good.
Monk under pressure from abbot forgives the crucifix which has fallen and hurt him.
Monk leaves monastery when he sees a devil there tempting brethren.
Hermit having rebuked youth falls himself when exposed to the same sin.
Monk rebukes brethren who succumb to temptation.
No place secret enough for sin.
Lying is incurable.
Liar cannot be healed even when taking bath in the Ganges.
False repentance of the sick.
False repentance of the sick, rich man.
King grows lean from fear of death.
Hares fearing death outrun pursuing dogs.
The hare’s last will.
Courage conquers all and impossible is made possible.
The bad custom in the world: the young die as well as the old.
Time seems short to those who play, long for those who wait.
Suffering healed by time.
Cat ceases catching rats as soon as he is given a home in a monastery.

Religious sacrifices--miscellaneous.
Rising smoke as sign of acceptance of sacrifice.
Protection of sinners by confession.
A man without a confessor is a body without a head.
Confessor as “soul-friend”.
Confession brings forgiveness of sin.
Sincere confession miraculously obliterated as sign of forgiveness.
Woman confesses murder: unharmed by execution fire.
Confession of monk who intended to rob monastery brings forgiveness.
Prior pardons sinning friar who has confessed.
Sinner confesses before sinning and thus is pardoned.
Sinner’s tearmarks on written confession cause bishop to pardon his sins.
Condemnation because of death without confession.
Miracle to permit confession.
Unshriven man restored to life in order to confess.
Dumb man recovers speech in order to confess.
Miraculous manifestation at confession.
Confession of sins of a pilgrim calms a great storm at sea.
Easy confession not effective.
Man returns from dead to protest against priest who has been too easy with him at confession.
Confession without giving up sin punished.
Penance magically concluded by confession.
Confession--miscellaneous motifs.
Search for confessor.
Monks shrive selves clean under threat of complete exposure of their sins by brother possessed of fiend.
Miracle attests fact that man does not need to confess.
Sodomist makes sport of confession.
Unnecessary for husband to confess as his wife has already done it for him.
Penitent brings manuscript of sins to confession.
List of sins: schedule is returned miraculously cleansed of all his sins.
Confessor and penitent exchange confidences.
The devil goes to confession.
Extortionate confessor demands golden statue.
The eaten god.
Flesh of Artemis eaten as quail or bear.
Unconsecrated host.
Host taken away from sinful priest.
Unconsecrated host ineffective.

Miraculous working of the host.
Host cures disease.
Princess sick because toad has swallowed her consecrated wafer.
Man who has received sacrament overcomes enemy, a blasphemer.
Clothes of knight who kneels in mud before host as it passes miraculously kept clean.
The stolen sacrament.
Jews bribe woman to steal host for them: miraculous manifestations.
Horse kneels before stolen sacrament.
Sacred image miraculously appears on stolen sacrament.
Stolen sacred hosts put into coffin.
Sacrament--miscellaneous motifs.
Man considering self unworthy to receive host given it by God himself.
Wicked woman unable to endure presence of host at mass.
Sacrament effective even from unworthy priest.
Vision of sacrament in form of young child.
Sacred image appears on host.
Host given as pledge to keep one‘s word.
Voice from grave asks that it be opened.
Sick men die and go to hell because they hesitate to take sacrament.
Woman who eats before communion cannot swallow the wafer.
Masses work miracles.
Imprisoned miner kept alive by masses performed by his wife.
Hearing masses causes triumph in tournament.
Masses release souls from hell (purgatory).
Holy man has his own mass.
Faithful attendance at mass outweighs evil deeds.
Mass said for dead; they arise and say “Amen”.
Pebble put in box each time mass is heard.
The canonical hours.
Mass--miscellaneous motifs.
Werwolves hold mass.
Angel holds mass in church on the day that the king absents himself for sake of hunting trip.
Learning to pray.
Man who does not know how to pray so holy that he walks on water.
Worldly-minded learn to pray by thinking of their usual business.
Woman shows that the Lord’s Prayer is the best.
Woman taught that it is better to pray before Christ‘s image than before a saint’s.
“Beatus” best prayer for saving condemned souls.
Miraculous power of prayer.
Man saved from lechery through prayer.
Continuous prayer sustains man through frightful vigil.
Prayer before battle brings victory.
Objects supplied through prayer.
Prayer restores shattered vessel.
Mariners saved from maelstrom through prayer.
Prayer at saint’s flagstone averts trouble.
Prayer brings death to enemy.
Prayer for protection on journey to land of dead.
Prayers of devout woman free husband from death and imprisonment.
Prayer of sinner changes his color from black into white.
The clever brothers work, the foolish brother only prays; finally he acquires all the property.
Saint‘s Paternoster outweighs ox.
Reciting martyrology will prevent decomposition of body of one who recites it.
Prayer said by saint into his right hand restores displaced eye of opponent.
Prayers of family comfort prisoner.
Prayer unfastens boy’s fetters.
Man worships devil‘s image in order to secure advancement.
Purpose of prayer.
Prayer for good harvest.
Prayer for shower of gold.
Prayer on special occasions.
Prayer as ceremony.
Prayers at sunrise and sunset.
Prayer with face toward east.
Repeated circumambulations with prayer.
Handwashing before prayer.
Prayer shawl.
Prayers answered--miscellaneous.
Skill in theft granted as answer to prayer.
Stones sold at funeral wakes.
Funeral rites by druids.
Various ways of disposing of dead.
Dead placed on boat.
Dead burned on pyre.
Coffin buried upright.
Hero buried in armor, standing with face toward land of enemies.
Person buried in standing position with friends about him.
Man buried upright beneath kitchen stairway in order that he may watch his family.
Head buried one place, body another.
Corpse buried face down.
Dismemberment before burial.
King buried in his war car.
Christian buried in stone coffin.
Christian buried in wooden coffin.
Burial in grave-mound.
Chiefs buried in hidden caves.
Lion buried in stone cave with gold letters.
Corpses exposed in tree.
Aversion to burial in “strange city”.
Restrictions on burial.
Funeral rites forbidden.
Only usurers to carry body of usurer to grave.
Bones of dismembered person assembled and buried.
Money tied on corpse thrown overboard from ship in order to secure burial.
Shipwrecked each get a piece of the chief’s gold ring in order to have gold with them in death.
Commemoration of death.
Calves kept separate from cows in commemoration of hero‘s death.
Drinking festival in memory of the dead.
Wedding and funeral festival on same time.
Professional mourning.
Funeral song sung over dead.
Funeral games.
Funeral sermon.
Witty funeral sermon.
Accompaniments of burial.
Ornaments (arms, chariots) buried with hero.
Shoes buried with the dead.
Treasure buried with the dead.
King buried with immense treasure in the ground of an artificially dried river
Men buried with dead chief.
Captain buried with his crew.
Animals buried with the dead.
Preparations for burial.
Dead washed (in river).
Dead washed and hair combed.
Dying hero wants to be buried in the clothes of his brother who killed him.
Dead is undressed.
Dead not to be buried naked.
Dead rubbed with red paint.
Funeral rites-miscellaneous.
All dead are buried after battle.
Hero buried as unknown merchant in foreign country.
The first day of summer.
Festival of Beltane (== May Day).
Whitsuntide.
Midsummer.
Feast of Saint John the Baptist.
Harvest-festival.
Festival of Samhain (Hallowe‘en, Tara [Temair]).
Festival of Imbolg (Brigit, Candlemas).
Feast of the new moon.
Festival of Cenn (Crom) Cruaich.
Sabbath.
Jewish automaton will not work on Saturday.
Manna does not descend on Sabbath.
Misfortune ascribed to breaking Sabbath.
Various events, from creation to Resurrection, that occurred on Sabbath.
Christmas.
Little Christmas.
Fasts.
Christ in the desert overcomes devil by fasting.
Fast to prevent pestilence.
Fast improves health.
Saint causes two youths to be fed with the best food, says one is doomed to go to hell, the other will practice austerity in his old age.
Fasting to secure a prosperous journey.
Fasting on “Golden Fridays” as charm against certain misfortunes.
Lent.
Christ‘s forty-days’ fast called “His Lent”.
Saint remains silent during Lent by holding stone in mouth.
Holy man eats pork and beef in Lent because pig is raised
Easter.
Passover.
Baptism.
Girl having been stolen by mountain-folk must be baptized anew.
Tails fall off mountain spirits when they are baptized.
Metamorphosis brought about by baptism.
Baptism of infants.
Sea bath as purificatory rite.
Circumcision.
Hymns.
Excommunication.
Lightning strikes excommunicated person who enters church.
Priest shows power of excommunication over host.
Pirate excommunicated, goes on pilgrimage as penance.
Religious pilgrimages.
Sign of the Cross.
Sign of cross protects from injury.
Sign of cross prevents child from being stolen from cradle.
Sign of cross prevents garment from burning.
Man dies because he has killed a man with the sign of the cross on his forehead.
Martyr with sign of cross on his heart.
Punishment for profane use of the cross.
Miraculous manifestations to scoffers of the cross.
Praying with arms extended so as to form a cross.
Loaf bursts in oven because sign of cross has not been made over it.

Romans won’t include Jesus in their pantheon because of his poverty which they hate.

Vision in which king sees his four sons changed into lion,
Vision of future.

The only king ever saved in spite of himself.

Saint gives calf to wolf.
Generosity.
Philanthropist will give his spurs if someone will drive his horse for him.
Munificent monarch.
Emperor thinks day lost when he gives no gifts.
King will not eat breakfast till gifts are given.
Man divides money into three parts: (1) for the poor, (2) for pilgrims, (3) for himself and family.
Man lets himself be sold as slave so as to practice generosity.
Brahmin steals to feed guests (deities).
Generosity toward enemy.
Ruler pardons his enemies.
Man pardons his assailants.
Ruler pardons emissary who has come to murder him.
Wronged knight conquers enemy and then pardons him.
Conqueror returns defeated man’s wife and family to him.
Conqueror spares city.
Ruler reproaches son for bringing him the head of his fallen enemy.
Man saved through intercession of enemy.
Man pays fine for enemy who is falsely accused.
Captor contributes to captive‘s ransom.
Warrior gives steed to his enemy.
Calumniated woman intercedes for accusers.
Man’s life spared through the intercession of the daughter he has wronged.
Champion grants requested boon of safe convoy to his enemies.
Chieftain spares enemies whom he takes unawares (unarmed).
Chieftain who takes king unawares, spares him on condition that chieftain be called “lover” by women of king‘s tribe.
Hero in battle refuses to slay charioteers, women, or physicians.
Ruler generously settles quarrel between loser and finder of money.
Nobleman’s generosity enables impoverished lover to entertain his lady.
Impoverished nobleman offers wife to ruler.
General sends for king so that the latter may get credit for victory.
Prince donates all including a tooth.
Ruler protects thief.
Ruler rewards man who would curb him.
The generous correction.
King rewards knight with large sum of money.
Novel sign of death.
Youngest brother shares wealth with older brothers who foolishly lost theirs.
Generous person refuses no man anything.
Generous king gives away his only eye.
Hospitality as a virtue.
Man (king) prefers death to loss of reputation for hospitality.
Man looks for strangers so as to bestow hospitality on them.
Woman shelters son’s murderer out of charity.
Murderer goes to victim‘s son and asks to be killed.
Bishop exchanges places with prisoner so as to have him return to his mother.
Envious man sets out to kill one who is noted for his generosity.
Emperor friendly to everyone.
Man never listens to scandal.
Man speaks no evil.
Equanimity of the comedian.
Equanimity of the enslaved unfortunate.
Minister always says, “It is for the best,” when anything happens.
Patience.
Gratitude.
Man weeps with gratitude to God because He did not make him hideous as toad.
Self-sacrifice.
Woman drinks poison that son may be king.
Woman sacrifices life for son‘s honor.
Man leaps from vessel into jaws of sea-beast so as to save remaining passengers.
Saint threatens to take place of homicide in hell unless soul is released.
Obedience.
Bravery.
King Richard leads host to victory by leaping his horse overboard.
Heroism.
Badly wounded warrior continues fighting.
Warrior refuses to delay battle in return for promise of long, happy life.
Loyalty.
Man constrained to flee with leader‘
Loyal friends refuse to fight against disgraced comrade.
Cowardly to leave battle while lord is alive.
Fakir rewarded by prince with a life of luxury in city chooses to return to his monkey friends in jungle.
Justice.
Man picked to judge bull-fight because he is “no fairer to his friend than to his foe.”
Upright judge refuses a bribe: he is responsible to a higher tribunal called Conscience.
Conscientiousness.
Man never breaks his word.
Oil well digger runs out of money, leaves the country, forgetting to tell his driller.
Man keeps promise to return to be eaten by tiger: let go without harm.
Rabbi returns jewel found with bought ass.
Peacefulness.
Honor.
Prostrate soldier asks his enemy to stab him in the chest instead of the back in order to save his honor.
Laziness.
Contest in laziness.
Man lets legs burn in fire rather than move them.
Man is burned to death because he is too lazy to put out spark.
Lazy man’s belongings burn.
Man too lazy to open eyes to see where fire is burning.
Three lazy beggars burn alive rather than run away from burning castle.
Mother calls to daughter to tell her that she (daughter) is standing on a live coal.
Man will not lift knife to cut rope about to hang him.
Man will not move in bed when water drops in his eyes.
Man so lazy that he will not wipe his running nose.
Man floating in river too lazy to drink.
Man too lazy to pick up berries (dates).
The lazy servant.
Lazy servant gets others to perform his duties.
Servant to call his master at daybreak:
Servant to close door at night: leaves it open so that he will not have to open it next morning.
“If it is day, give me food; if it is night, let me sleep.”
Boy to see whether it is raining: calls dog (cat) in and feels of his paws.
Boy to see whether there is fire in the house: feels of cat to see if she is warm.
The boy eats breakfast, dinner, and supper one immediately after the other; then lies down to sleep.
Lazy boy always says that it is raining.
Lazy boy says he cannot walk.
Servant tells master to cover his face: no need to put out lamp.
The lazy wife.
Lazy wife in soiled dress thinks husband is bringing her a new dress from market.
Cat beaten for not working.
Lazy wife throws bread out of window instead of putting it back into oven.
Why he beats her.
Wife too lazy to spin.
“Who will not work, shall not eat.”
Lazy husband.
Other lazy persons.
Lazy mother given shoes of cotton; son knows that she will not wear them out.
Lazy girl does not know where the spring is.
Lazy man asked direction only points with his foot.
Lazy dog wakes only for his meals.
Man in mud too lazy to take hand extended to help him up.
Lazy son-in-law: afraid of a dog.
Ruler is too lazy to stop quarrels.
Man with stolen fig in his mouth submits to having cheek lanced rather than open his mouth.
Man is so lazy that he starves rather than open his mouth for food to fall in when it falls from trees.
Learning a trade in bed.
Lazy man asks if wood is split before he accepts it as a gift.
Lazy man is being taken to poorhouse or out of town or to cemetery to be buried alive.
Lazy man misses seeing the sheriff‘s funeral; he is facing the wrong way as the procession passes.
Man digs three potatoes in one day: one dug, one being dug, one about to be dug.
Man weeds garden from cushioned rocking chair, using fire tongs to reach weeds.
Slovenliness.
The slovenly fiancйe.
Woman becomes clean only after three washings and the use of three pounds of soap.
Rancher is not recognized by his wife and family after he has cleaned up in town at hotel.
Vanity.
Old woman reaches town before vain fop who stops to adjust clothes.
Expenditure of money for vanity.
Plain people made rulers have vain display.
Peacock admires self in mirror.
Wasp seeking fame stings courtiers: killed.
Wealthy man pretends enjoyment of good music.
Use of strange language to show one’s high education.
Jackal forces all animals who come to drink to praise him like a king.
Boastfulness.
Neglected wife given trifle boasts of it.
Cowardice.
Hunter wants to be shown lion tracks, not lion himself.
Coward boasts when there is no danger.
Ass insults dying lion.
Fox insults caged lion.
Crow sits on sheep’s back; afraid to sit on dog‘s.
Dogs tear up lion skin: fear living lion.
Coward gloats over robber slain by another person.
Monkey safe in tree insults gorilla as “broken face”.
Cowardly soldier turns back when he hears raven’s croak.
Queen mother shames cowardly son and companions.
Cowardly spider rushes at fly but hides when wasp appears.
Coward gives his purse to thief with lame excuse.
Cowardly bridegroom flees elephant and loses bride.
Illness from fear.
Swooning from cowardice.
Indecision.
The man who only tasted wine.
Gluttony.
Greedy animal eats poisoned fruit in spite of warning.
Gluttonous wife eats all the meal while cooking it.
New son-in-law given choice of meals eats all.
Pupil eats cakes given as alms for his master.
Husband eats wife’s share of food as well as his own.
Disobedience.
Monk obedient only as long as work is agreeable.
Petulance.
Dissatisfaction.
Hog tired of his daily food.
Dissatisfied fox.
Dissatisfied rivers complain against sea.
Peacock dissatisfied with his voice.
Monk dissatisfied with things as he has them is admonished to take what he receives from God.
Sparrow dissatisfied with pond water wants to go to sea.
Profligacy.
Profligate wastes entire fortune before beginning his own adventures.
Inconsistency.
Prince penalizes cursing, although he himself curses.
Woman admires marvelous shot of hero which kills deer, but angers him when she begs mercy for the deer.
False modesty.
Look! look! she cries from the barrel.
Curiosity.
Talkativeness.
Greed.
Cauldron of greed.
Harlot weeps when her impoverished lover leaves her to think that she has left him his coat.
Visiting friends take everything from house of dying man.
Visitors of sick stag eat up all his provisions so that he starves.
Hospitable man impoverished by greedy guests.
Wolves devour an ox without leaving a share for the rightful owner.
Snake and weasel stop fighting in order to catch mouse.
Father-in-law sued for breach of contract because he does not die in two years as he has predicted.
Hog with broken leg refuses to tell another where peas are to be found.
Eats up the money.
Thieves quarrel over booty: owner comes.
Greedy person (animal) gets hand (head) stuck in food jar.
Greedy man tries to stuff food into his nostrils as well as into his mouth.
Stinginess.
Fox spoils his food rather than divide with ape.
Man had rather be burned alive than to share food with a guest.
Stingy dead woman raises her head to correct account of laundress, who is overcharging her daughter.
Stingy man forced to share his money when he lies and says he has none.
Stingy woman will not give soup to man until she spills it.
Stingy king will not hire soldiers: defeated.
Spider in stingy woman‘s house grows thin.
Stingy horse refuses ass little feed, though he promises much for later time.
Stingy man cancels invitations to his guests.
Drummer drums for own wedding so as to save expense.
Stingy men love possessions so much that they wear out their feet to save shoes.
Stingy man and his servants.
Farmer gets help up early in morning for a light breakfast: a glass of water and a lantern.
Stingy farmer encourages help by promise of hot lunch.
Master insists that maid whistle when she brings in the dessert.
Master insists that servants whistle as they pick strawberries so that they cannot eat any.
The stingy man and his animals.
A stranger notices that man’s cows need feed, feeds them.
Man who insists on using everything that is useful.
Man finds a bunghole lying around loose, has cooper build a barrel around it.
Man saves sausage skins, sends them back for refilling.
Stingy man does not eat butter; only looks at it and enjoys the thought.
Wife of stingy man prays that her husband become sick so that she can get better food.
Wife keeps half of the money she plans to give for a shrine.
Miserliness.
Miser’s heart found in his strong-box.
Miserly husband spies on wife to see that she does not eat too much.
Miserly husband spies on wife, lest she cook too much.
Miserly wife exposed to guests by her husband.
Man is so miserly that he never drinks wine until it becomes strong.
Friar so miserly that he stays in ditch three days before “lending” a hand to his rescuers.
Miser dreams that he spends some money.
Miser decides not to commit suicide.
Miser is given rope to hang himself.
Miser appoints himself as the sole heir of his own estate.
Miser decides to kill his pigs himself.
Miser is rebuked by friend.
Miser dies because he will not buy a candle.
Dying miser tells son to extinguish candle just as soon as he dies.
Miser runs back home to put out lamp left burning.
Miser is kidnapped and held for ransom.
Wood dealer prays for raja‘s death so that he can sell sandal wood for funeral pyre.
Miser tries to reduce sacrifice promised to god.
Miser prays to enter heaven with his clothes on: gold coins sewn into undergarments.
Ingratitude.
Man dismissed after years of service with a pittance.
Usurer’s ingratitude toward servant.
Monster ungrateful for rescue.
Rescued animal threatens rescuer.
Man ungrateful for rescue by animal.
Crane pulls bone from wolf‘s throat: wolf refuses payment.
Lion rescued from net by rat: eats rat.
Tiger has thorn pulled by man: attacks man.
Hunter beats dog which has grown old in his service.
Dog tries to bite man rescuing him from well.
Ungrateful fox hits with tail the man who carries him across stream.
Man kills whale which carried him home across sea.
Man who has been rescued from pit tries to kill his monkey rescuer for food.
Ungrateful ape plucks feathers from heron who has carried him across water.
Ungrateful wanderer pulls nut tree to pieces to get the nuts.
Wanderers in shade of plane tree blame it for not bearing fruit.
Grateful animals; ungrateful man.
Man rescued from drowning kills rescuer.
Whales rescue drowning king who planned to kill them.
Snake kills ungrateful tamer.
Tiger returns rope to former captor: rewarded by having tail cut off.
Man kills his rescuer in order to collect reward.
Knight is ungrateful for rescue in battle.
Ungrateful Brahmin brings his wild goose rescuer to king as remedy against leprosy.
Ungrateful brothers plot against rescuer.
Benefactor falsely accused of theft by ungrateful youth.
Woman who saves suitor from death is later condemned to die by the ingrate.
Kind magistrate is victim of ingratitude.
Ruler persecutes his friends and is kind to his enemies.
Man beheads rescuer for leaving him so long in pain.
Man ungrateful for life saved because rescuer helped others also.
Ungrateful Jew steals horse of Christian who has lent it to him.
Man beats people bearing him gifts.
Workers (builder) killed when secret building or grave is finished.
Person compared to nettle, which stings the hand that protects it.
Ingratitude from ignorance.
Man fails to feed his animal rescuer.
Man sets dogs onto bear after bear has carried him home to safety.
Man demands ever larger gifts.
Man trades an egg for a needle, demands treat of a gill of rum, the traditional reward for traders.
Man works his horses to death, then complains that borrowed horse overeats.
Wizard makes pupil think himself Emperor and exposes pupil’s ingratitude.
Hardness of heart.
Hardhearted horse allows ass to be overburdened until it is crushed.
Old bullock deserted and left to die.
Man overloads and starves camel.
Man helping another across stream drops him when he learns that he has lost his high position.
Man unable to weep for hardness of heart.
Hardhearted person refuses reprieve for father’s murderers.
Permission refused to drink from water tank.
The dog in the manger.
Dishonesty.
Priest uses fortune dishonestly made to erect monuments to himself.
Inhospitality.
Love of publicity.
Three envoys debate as to which of them should be received with the greatest honor.
False pride.
Humble man after speaking to king disdains his own family.
Ass after associating with lion disdains his own family.
Stubbornness.
Two stubborn goats meet each other on a bridge.
Woman’s stubbornness causes loss of chance to go on pilgrimage.
Two-facedness.
Man winks both at buyer and seller.
Changeableness.
Sister gives due honor and regard to brother only in times of his prosperity.
Jealousy.
Sheep jealous of dog because he does nothing.
King kills architect after completion of great building, so that he may never again build one so great.
Architect kills pupil who has surpassed him in skill.
Architect commits suicide when he discovers that his pupil has surpassed him in skill.
Raven wants to be as white as a swan.
Jealous fox betrays wolf to peasant and then appropriates wolf‘s cave and food.
Raven jealous of partridge’s way of flying.
Jealousy of Venus in the love of Psyche and Cupid.
Ruler who is jealous of his subjects‘ happiness prohibits their games.
The crying child.
Violence of temper.
Man demonstrates his violence of temper.
Prayer that overbearing knight’s illness be increased.
Temper lost from reading history.
Monk loses temper at cup and breaks it.
Violence of judge‘s temper leads him to have men given death sentence unjustly.
Insult worse than wound.
Insolence.
Contentiousness.
Extortion.
Man extorts large price for betel leaf from addict.
Envy.
Goose and turkey envious of peacock point out its ugly legs and voice.
Lack of patience.
Active imagination.
The boy: “If I had one and then got two more, I should have three.”
“I surely saw a hundred wolves (snakes).”
“I am not alone!” Man travelling alone through the forest at night, is afraid of robbers.
Eagerness for combat.
Eager warriors go through tent wall.
Warriors contend with each other until battle starts.
Man will not allow food served to strangers until a man of them wrestles with him.
Host requires deed of bravery before feast is eaten.
Man will not do a woman‘s bidding.
Extreme prudence.
Magic help sent to enemy.
Refusal to fight wounded enemy.
Long life sacrificed that descendants may be kings as prophesied.
Thrift.
Thrifty merchant tells son that even a snake laid by will be useful.
Taciturn man.
Man is rebuked for loquaciousness when he speaks after thirty-seven days.
Moving home simple for poor man.
Red pepper for the slow ass: man tries it on himself.
Man interrupted each time he tries to eat something.
Man continually interrupted from eating answers in rhymed monosyllables.
Accidental cannibalism.
The dream of marking the treasure.
Man dreams that he is rich.
Pig licks sleeping man’s lips: man thinks he is being kissed.
Wager with overdressed youths that servant can carry a large bucket of water upstairs.
Use of itch-producing ointment.
Ridiculous nakedness or exposure.
Woman exposed to ridicule when her wig is snatched off by a monkey.
Man given ride on a hemp-dresser.
Deaf men and their answers.
Deaf persons: search for the lost animal.
Deaf peasant: travelers ask the way.
Two persons believe each other deaf.
Deaf peasant: the wedding invitation.
Deaf man on the bridge.
The deaf man and the proud nobleman.
Misunderstood words lead to comic results.
The deaf man with the bird in the tree.
Deaf man visits the sick.
“Good day.”
Buyer and deaf seller.
The deaf parson.
The deaf bishop.
Deaf litigants and deaf judge misunderstand one another.
Travelers pass through Wesley.
Deaf husband orders deaf wife to prepare a certain dish: misunderstanding.
Misunderstanding and quarrels in family of deaf.
The wife who saw double.
The squint-eyed son and the bottle.
One-eyed man as appraiser of horse.
Blind man and the bull.
Blind man reaches his home hanging on ox‘s tail (or in other ridiculous situation).
Nearsighted knight mistakes own servant for one of the enemy.
Blind man strikes woman thinking she is buffalo.
Blind son-in-law visits his wife’s family: gets into difficulties.
Blind men trying to kill pigs with clubs strike one another.
Blind man in awkward position pretends to see.
The wry-mouthed family.
Man calls convention of all long noses.
The humor of stuttering.
Each of four stutterers thinks the others are ridiculing him.
Stutterer tries to give alarm.
Humor of ugliness.
Blind, lame, and deaf as witnesses in court.
The humor of small stature.
Dwarf king falls into porridge-pot at court of human king.
Dwarf poet forced to swim in drinking-horn of human being.
Tiny ambassador put on horse with long stirrups.
Short magistrate wears a high helmet.
Humor of lameness.
Lame man taken on hunt in wheel chair beats the dogs home when they tree a spook or when a bear gets after them.
Humor of bad singing.
Audience of one hired to listen to egoistic dismal-voiced singer.
Humor of fatness.
Six short, fat husbands married to six tall, fat wives try absurdly to kiss them at the threshold on their wedding day.
Fat man so unwieldly he fishes from his window in the street.
Millers as thieves.
The honest miller.
Priest commends the poor miller.
Why no millers in hell.
Monks get revenge on millers.
Oversight of the thievish tailor.
Thievish tailor cuts a piece of his own coat.
Thieving tailor can hide stolen cloth even in needle-and-thread tube.
Tailor always associated with goat.
Tailors cowards as warriors: go home to their needles.
Butcher wonders that man who has been buying his meat for seven years can still be alive.
Ugly cobbler continually threatens to throw his last at people.
Shoemaker drinks more than his portion of “drink of lies”, which has been prepared for all to partake of equally.
Jokes on weavers.
Why no weavers in hell.
Jokes about barbers.
Client flees when cobwebs are brought in to medicate cuts.
Barber uses cut hair to staunch cuts.
Jokes on fishermen.
Talkativeness of the fishwives of Paris.
What will happen when there are so many lawyers.
Beggar frightens lawyer into giving by telling him of all the lawyers in hell.
Dying like Christ--between two thieves.
Lawyer who tries to practice without lying fails.
Dying lawyer says, “I appeal”.
Dying lawyer asks delay.
Nero has reserved place in hell for lawyers.
Lawyer thrown back into mud when rescuers learn that he is a lawyer.
Lawyer loses tongue in death because he sold it in life.
Miscellaneous jokes about lawyers.
Eloquent lawyer makes obviously guilty client doubt his own guilt.
Guilty of everything connected with the seven senses.
Foreigner wonders why city with so many judges has not been destroyed.
Music teacher charges double for those who have taken music before.
Master of seven liberal arts begs from wagoner.
Jokes on doctors.
Doctor cures palpitation of heart: patient stops breathing.
Head cut off to cure snakebite.
Eyedrops prescribed for stomach ache so that patient can see what he eats.
Foolish doctor performs useless operation.
Man with cheeks stuffed with food operated on to remove swellings.
Doctor called to attend sick man immediately gives orders for the funeral.
Parson put to flight during his sermon.
Sexton’s dog steals sausage from parson‘s pocket: parson flees.
Sexton puts needle in sacramental bread: parson sticks his hand.
Sexton arranges wasp-nest so that parson sits on it.
Tame bear tied to church bells.
One-eyed parson in dimly lighted church joins the wrong couples.
Parson rides ox into church.
The hog in church.
Parson preaches so that half the congregation weeps and half laughs.
Parson smears his hand with butter.
Parson is to let a dove fly in the church.
At the blessing of the grave the parson’s ox breaks loose: “Now the devil has him.”
The corpse with his feet cut off.
The devil in the cemetery.
Robbers mistake man for devil (the “sheep” speaks, “Gently, gently!”).
The parson who said there is no devil.
If his son were only a fool he would let him study to be a priest.
A bad year for priests: few funerals.
Enmity between priests and monks: chickens and eggs.
The hungry parson and the porridge-pot.
Stupid man tries to take honey from jug at night while visiting.
The parson put out of countenance.
The large loaves need a large oven.
Grace before meat.
The boy applies the sermon.
“What says David?”--Boy: “Pay your old debts.”
Parson “Where did the father stay?”--“He stayed to hold the oxen.”
Where was Christ when he was neither in heaven nor
Names of persons in the Trinity.
Sermon about the rich man.
The parson sings like a goat.
The dream: all parsons in hell.
All devout women in hell.
Parson and sexton at mass.
“I can’t hear you.”
Whistling at mass.
Parson’s poor horsemanship.
Chaplain on bucking mule.
Parson refreshes himself during the sermon.
Parson takes a drink of liquor during the sermon.
Parson takes a chew of tobacco during the sermon.
Cock crows at church and the sexton awakes and begins to sing.
The parson has no need to preach.
No need to give sermon about saint again.
The woman whose name was “Worthy.”
Chapel endowed with fifty blows for the friar.
Jokes on monks.
Bishop willing to admit castrated man as monk: wishes all were in the same condition.
Jokes on parsons--miscellaneous.
Man heeds what he thinks to be call to the ministry.
Young man plowing corn sees letters “P.
Jokes on fortune-tellers.
Fortune-teller shows others how to get rich but remains poor himself.
Barber alone praises usurer.
Usurers do not reply.
Devil will not carry usurers to hell but will drag them by the legs.
Only usurers can carry the corpse of the usurer.
Usurer encourages sermons against usury, so that his competitors will cease activity.
Only prostitutes can carry the corpse of a prostitute.
Begging cripples hurry away from shrine lest they be healed and lose their livelihood.
Cohabitation between lunatics brought about for sport.
Jokes on freemasons.
Jokes about travelers.
Jokes about hunters.
Man chased by bear to camp claims that he brought it in thus since he did not want to carry it.
How the Jews were drawn from heaven.
Trickster breaks up Jewish marriage ceremony and seduces the bride.
Battle between lice of Strassburg and of Hungary.
Learning the Bavarian language.
Why Arabians are liars.
Blason populaire.
The old maid in bed.
A youth promises to marry an old maid if she will sit all night on the roof.
The meal of beans.
The wolf steals the old maid.
The mother trains the old maid to speak properly.
Drunk man lying under his bed thinks he is lying in his shroud.
Drunk man goes to the king and wants to buy an island.
Drunk man at the wedding.
Drunk men try to see one another home.
Drunk man sees everything revolving and waits for his house to come to him.
Drunk woman thinks she is in heaven.
Drunk recruits make war on a haystack.
Drunken volunteer firemen bungle their work.
One lie a year.
Liar comes to believe his own lie.
Lie used as catch tale.
The teller reduces the size of his lie.
The liar reduces the size of his lie when his brother steps on his toes to remind him of his lying habits.
Liar reduces the size of his yarn when challenged.
Lying contests.
Master brought to say, “You lie!”
Greatest liar made king of Schlaraffenland.
Claim of property based on unusual lie.
The liar: “I have no time to lie today”; lies nevertheless.
Boy to deceive his uncle: induces uncle to climb tree before deception begins: this is the deception.
Would not lie for a trifle.
Man has servant corroborate his lies.
The second liar corroborates the lie of the first.
Lie: sea has burned up.
Other stories about liars.
The incorrigible liar.
Church member who has been called to task about his lying habits tells another lie in expressing his concern for his weakness.
The liar outdoes the tricksters who try to catch him in a lie.
Lie concerning birth of hero.
Lie concerning babyhood and boyhood of hero.
Lie: death of extraordinary man.
Lie: persons with remarkable bodily parts.
Lie: remarkably tall person.
Lie: great weight of large person.
Lie: great girth of large person.
Lie: remarkably thin persons.
Lie: remarkable eater.
Lie: remarkable drinker.
Lie: remarkable chewer.
Lie: remarkable spitter.
Lie: remarkable blower.
Lie: person with remarkable hearing.
Lie: person with remarkable voice.
Lie: person of remarkable sight.
Lie: other motifs pertaining to extraordinary senses or bodily powers.
Remarkable lifter.
Whole village lifted.
Fight on old woman‘s hand.
Elephant (camel) put in pocket as a curiosity to show friends.
Wind blows group of persons into woman’s eye.
Lie: remarkable carrier.
Lie: man ties up 700 camels in a corner of his sheet.
Lie: remarkable thrower.
Beautiful girl seated on large lotus flower holding big elephant in each hand which she devours and throws off alternately.
Lie: child throws out elephant‘s carcass.
Lie: remarkable catcher.
Lie: remarkable hitter or striker.
Lie: remarkable breaker.
Lie: remarkable bender.
Lie: remarkable twister.
Lie: remarkable squeezer.
Lie: remarkable pincher.
Lie: strong puller.
Man draws sixty (300) carts of wood.
Lie: remarkable pusher.
Lie: remarkable killer.
Lie: hero responsible for topographical features (lakes, rivers, etc.).
Lie: other strong physical reactions.
Lie: hero breaking wen causes wall to fall down.
Lie: extraordinary bodily skills.
Lie: remarkable swimmer.
Lie: remarkable diver.
Lie: remarkable jumper.
Lie: remarkable kicker.
Lie: remarkable oarsman.
Lie: remarkable fighter.
Lie: remarkable wrestler.
Lie: remarkable smith.
Lie: skillful flayer.
Lie: skillful axe-man.
Axe of wax cuts jungle.
Lie: remarkable logger.
Lie: remarkable rock driller.
Lie: remarkable carpenter.
Lie: remarkable thresher.
Lie: remarkable user of whip.
Lie: remarkable roper.
Lie: remarkable rider.
Lie: man rides unusual riding animal (lion, deer, etc.).
Lie: man rides cyclone.
Lie: remarkable cook.
Lie: the great inventor.
Lie: person displays remarkable ingenuity or resourcefulness.
Lie: axes ground on boulders rolling down hill.

Symbolic color: red.
Red garment to show anger of king.
Red as symbolic of martyrdom.

Symbolic color: brown.
Brown hair as sign child is descended from goddess.
Symbolic color: purple.
Purple is symbol of royalty.
Yellow a lucky color.
Ring broken as token of broken engagement.
Princess crushes lotus-flower to show that she will be submissive.
Gray hair the symbol of departed usefulness.
Cloud (mist) as symbol of misfortune.
Olive branch symbol of peace.
Symbolism: not to fight alone.
Arthur’s Round Table symbolic of round earth.
Message or orders given symbolic action.
Inverted shoes at doors to indicate banishment.
Black dummy to indicate banishment.
Sign language.
Language of flowers.
Lovers‘ assignation by symbolic messages.
Symbolism of the mass.
Lamb as symbol of Christ.
Allegorical game.
Nudity as sign of anger.
Nudity as sign of madness.
Symbolic wounding of king.
Symbolic names.
Three trees called “Grief,” “Dark,” and “Dumb-Mouthless Oak.”
Symbols of divinity.
Mill turned by the water of the grace of God as symbol of saint.
Symbolism: needle and thread--sexual intercourse.
Warriors identically equipped (brothers).
Lodge-Boy and Thrown-Away as joint adventurers.
Dreadnaughts.
Hero “son of seven mothers”.
Supernatural origin of hero: magic conception.
Eldest brother as hero.
Boyish exploits of hero.
Hero with extraordinary animal companions (cock, goat, cow, horse).
Boy hero.
Culture hero precocious.
Hero at first nameless.
Fool as hero.
Destined hero.
Hero born out of wedlock.
Beardless hero.
Giant heroes.
Death of hero.
Return of the hero.
Achilles heel.
Left eye only vulnerable spot.
Spot below right ear only vulnerable one.
Leprosy cured by holy water except on thumb.
Man can be injured only in armpits.
Unique deadly weapon.
Person can be killed only by red-hot spits being thrust through soles of his feet.
Giant ogre can be killed only with iron club he carries (with own sword).
Unique source of weakness.
Unique bait for fish.
Vulnerability only by one person.
Only one person can overtake hero.
Sword which will break in only one peril: this known only to the maker of the sword.
Ogre vulnerable only when his face is turned away when he is struck.
Only one way to besiege certain city.
Ring fits only one person.
Only one ferule fits certain staff.
Vessel from which nothing can be drunk save through certain tube.
Only one person refuses to weep at hero‘s death.
All trees except aspen refuse to make Christ’s cross.
All snakes but one placated by music.
Unique survivor.
